cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 001. Justiciability
cards.front: Justiciability
cards.backPlain: A case must be justiciable to be heard in federal court. This means there must be an actual case or controversy. To determine whether a case or controversy exists, the case must satisfy requirements for: 1. Standing; 2. Ripeness; 3. Mootness; and 4. The political question doctrine.
cards.frontPrompt: What does it mean for a case to be justiciable in federal court, and what four doctrines determine justiciability?
cards.cloze: A case must be {{c1::justiciable}} to be heard in federal court. This means there must be an actual {{c2::case or controversy}}. To determine whether a case or controversy exists, the case must satisfy requirements for: 1. {{c3::Standing}}; 2. {{c4::Ripeness}}; 3. {{c5::Mootness}}; and 4. The {{c6::political question doctrine}}.
cards.easyContent: For a case to be heard in federal court it must be justiciable, meaning there is an actual case or controversy. Justiciability turns on standing, ripeness, mootness, and the political question doctrine.
cards.mediumContent: A justiciable case is one that can be heard in federal court because it involves an actual case or controversy. To determine justiciability, courts ask whether the plaintiff has standing and whether the dispute is ripe, not moot, and not barred as a political question.
cards.hardContent: A case must be justiciable to be heard in federal court, which requires an actual case or controversy. Courts determine whether a case or controversy exists by asking whether the plaintiff has standing, whether the dispute is ripe for review, whether it is not moot (i.e., a live controversy exists at all stages), and whether it avoids issues that are non-justiciable under the political question doctrine.
cards.mnemonic: Think SRMP for justiciability: Standing, Ripeness, Mootness, Political question.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::justiciable}} case involves an {{c2::actual case or controversy}} and turns on {{c3::standing}}, {{c4::ripeness}}, {{c5::mootness}}, and the {{c6::political question doctrine}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 002. Standing
cards.front: Standing
cards.backPlain: A party must have a concrete interest in the outcome of a claim to have the claim heard in federal court. 1. Requirements: 1.1 Injury: The plaintiff must have suffered some injury or show a likelihood of imminent injury. 1.2 Causation and redressability: The plaintiff must allege that the defendant caused the injury and that the court can grant a proper remedy. 1.3 No generalized grievances: The plaintiff cannot sue solely as a U.S. citizen or taxpayer to compel the government to act in a particular way. 1.3.1 Exception: Taxpayers have standing to challenge specific government expenditures that violate the Establishment Clause. 2. Congress: Congress cannot automatically confer standing, but it can create new rights that, if violated, may give rise to standing.
cards.frontPrompt: What is Article III standing in federal court and what are its requirements, including the rule and exception for generalized grievances?
cards.cloze: A party must have a {{c1::concrete interest}} in the outcome of a claim to have the claim heard in federal court. 1. Requirements: 1.1 {{c2::Injury}}: The plaintiff must have suffered some injury or show a likelihood of imminent injury. 1.2 {{c3::Causation and redressability}}: The plaintiff must allege that the defendant caused the injury and that the court can grant a proper remedy. 1.3 {{c4::No generalized grievances}}: The plaintiff cannot sue solely as a U.S. citizen or taxpayer to compel the government to act in a particular way. 1.3.1 Exception: {{c5::Taxpayers have standing to challenge specific government expenditures that violate the Establishment Clause}}. 2. Congress: Congress cannot automatically {{c6::confer standing}}, but it can {{c7::create new statutory rights that, if violated, may give rise to standing}}.
cards.easyContent: Standing requires that the plaintiff have a concrete stake in the outcome, shown by injury, causation, and redressability, and may not rest on generalized grievances as a citizen or taxpayer except for certain Establishment Clause expenditure challenges.
cards.mediumContent: To have standing in federal court, a plaintiff must show (1) injury-in-fact, actual or imminent; (2) causation and redressability—i.e., the injury is fairly traceable to the defendant and likely to be remedied by the court; and (3) no generalized grievance—plaintiffs generally cannot sue solely as citizens or taxpayers to force the government to follow the law, except that taxpayers may challenge specific government expenditures that allegedly violate the Establishment Clause. Congress cannot simply declare that people have standing, but it can create statutory rights that, when violated, supply the injury component.
cards.hardContent: Article III standing requires that a party have a concrete interest in the outcome of the case. The plaintiff must show: (1) Injury: an actual injury or a likelihood of imminent injury; (2) Causation and redressability: the injury must be fairly traceable to the defendant’s challenged conduct and likely to be remedied by a favorable court decision; and (3) No generalized grievances: the plaintiff cannot sue solely as a U.S. citizen or taxpayer to compel the government to act in a particular way. The main exception is that taxpayers have standing to challenge specific government expenditures alleged to violate the Establishment Clause. Congress cannot automatically confer standing by statute, but it may create new statutory rights; violation of such a right can satisfy the injury requirement.
cards.mnemonic: Standing = ICR + No GG (taxpayer EC exception).
cards.clozeLite: Article III {{c1::standing}} needs {{c2::injury-in-fact}}, {{c3::causation and redressability}}, and {{c4::no generalized grievance}} (except {{c5::taxpayer Establishment Clause expenditures}}).

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 003. Third Party and Organizational Standing
cards.front: Third Party and Organizational Standing
cards.backPlain: 1. Third-party standing: A plaintiff with standing may assert the rights of a third party where the plaintiff has suffered injury and either: 1.1 The plaintiff's injury adversely affects his relationship with third parties. Example: A doctor can assert patients' rights in challenging abortion restrictions; a bar owner can assert underage males' rights in challenging a ban on beer sales to underage males. 1.2 The injured party is unlikely or unable to assert his own rights. Example: An association can challenge a law requiring disclosure of member identities, because members could not challenge the law directly without revealing their identities. 2. Organizational standing: 2.1 Direct injury: Organizations always have standing if the injury is to the organization itself. 2.2 Suits on behalf of members: Organizations may sue on members' behalf if: 2.2.1 There is an injury to the members that would give members standing to sue individually; 2.2.2 The injury is related to the organization's purpose; and 2.2.3 Neither the claim nor the relief requires participation of individual members.
cards.frontPrompt: When may a plaintiff assert third-party standing, and what are the requirements for an organization to sue on behalf of its members?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Third-party standing}}: A plaintiff with standing may assert the rights of a third party where the plaintiff has suffered injury and either: 1.1 The plaintiff's injury {{c2::adversely affects his relationship with third parties}}. Example: A doctor can assert patients' rights in challenging abortion restrictions; a bar owner can assert underage males' rights in challenging a ban on beer sales to underage males. 1.2 The injured party is {{c3::unlikely or unable to assert his own rights}}. Example: An association can challenge a law requiring disclosure of member identities, because members could not challenge the law directly without revealing their identities. 2. {{c4::Organizational standing}}: 2.1 {{c5::Direct injury}}: Organizations always have standing if the injury is to the organization itself. 2.2 Suits on behalf of members: Organizations may sue on members' behalf if: 2.2.1 There is an {{c6::injury to the members}} that would give members standing to sue individually; 2.2.2 The injury is {{c7::related to the organization's purpose}}; and 2.2.3 Neither the {{c8::claim nor the relief requires participation of individual members}}.
cards.easyContent: Third-party standing allows a plaintiff with standing to raise someone else’s rights when his injury affects his relationship with them or they are unlikely or unable to sue. Organizations may sue on their own injuries or on behalf of members if members would have standing, the injury relates to the organization’s purpose, and the claim does not require individual member participation.
cards.mediumContent: A plaintiff who already has standing may assert third-party rights if he has suffered injury and either (1) that injury adversely affects his relationship with the third party (e.g., doctor-patient, business-customer), or (2) the rights-holder is unlikely or unable to assert his own rights (e.g., anonymous association members). Organizations have standing if they are directly injured, and they may assert associational standing for members where (1) members would have standing, (2) the injury is germane to the organization’s purpose, and (3) neither the claim nor the requested relief requires individual members’ participation.
cards.hardContent: Third-party standing permits a plaintiff who already has Article III standing to raise the rights of a third party where the plaintiff has suffered injury and either (1) the plaintiff’s injury adversely affects his relationship with the third party, such that he is an effective proponent of their rights (as in doctors asserting patients’ abortion rights, or bar owners asserting the rights of underage male customers), or (2) the injured rights-holder is unlikely or unable to assert his own rights (as in associations challenging disclosure requirements that would expose their members). Organizational standing exists where an organization is directly injured. In addition, organizations may sue on behalf of members if: (1) members themselves would have standing (injury, causation, redressability); (2) the injury is related or germane to the organization’s purposes; and (3) neither the claim asserted nor the relief requested requires the participation of individual members (e.g., where only declaratory or injunctive relief is sought).
cards.mnemonic: Associational standing: 3 Ms — Member injury, Mission-related, Minimal member participation.
cards.clozeLite: {{c1::Third-party standing}} lets a plaintiff with {{c2::his own standing}} raise others’ rights if {{c3::relationship is affected}} or {{c4::rights-holder can’t/likely won’t sue}}. {{c5::Associational standing}} needs member standing, germaneness, and no individual participation.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 004. Ripeness and Mootness
cards.front: Ripeness and Mootness
cards.backPlain: 1. To be justiciable in federal court, a case must contain a ripe claim and a live controversy (i.e., it cannot be moot). 2. Ripeness: The dispute must have matured sufficiently to warrant a decision; the plaintiff is not entitled to review of a law or government act before it has been effectuated. 3. Mootness: A live controversy must exist at all stages of review. If the circumstances causing the plaintiff's harm cease to exist after the plaintiff files suit, the case must be dismissed as moot, unless an exception applies. 3.1 Exception: Wrongs capable of repetition but evading review: Arises where the injury ceases before complete litigation of the claim, but the plaintiff can reasonably expect to be subject to the same harm in the future. Example: A disabled bar examinee seeks an injunction because of denied accommodations and cannot complete the exam before his case is heard; the case is not moot because he will need to take the bar exam again. 3.2 Exception: Voluntary cessation by defendant: The defendant has ceased the acts giving rise to the plaintiff's suit, but can resume them at any time. 3.3 Exception: Class action lawsuits: Only one member of the class must have an ongoing injury.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the difference between ripeness and mootness in justiciability, and what are the main exceptions to mootness?
cards.cloze: 1. To be justiciable in federal court, a case must contain a {{c1::ripe}} claim and a {{c2::live controversy}} (i.e., it cannot be {{c3::moot}}). 2. {{c4::Ripeness}}: The dispute must have matured sufficiently to warrant a decision; the plaintiff is not entitled to review of a law or government act before it has been effectuated. 3. {{c5::Mootness}}: A live controversy must exist at all stages of review. If the circumstances causing the plaintiff's harm cease to exist after the plaintiff files suit, the case must be dismissed as moot, unless an exception applies. 3.1 Exception: {{c6::Wrongs capable of repetition but evading review}}: Arises where the injury ceases before complete litigation of the claim, but the plaintiff can reasonably expect to be subject to the same harm in the future. Example: A disabled bar examinee seeks an injunction because of denied accommodations and cannot complete the exam before his case is heard; the case is not moot because he will need to take the bar exam again. 3.2 Exception: {{c7::Voluntary cessation by defendant}}: The defendant has ceased the acts giving rise to the plaintiff's suit, but can resume them at any time. 3.3 Exception: {{c8::Class action lawsuits}}: Only {{c9::one member of the class must have an ongoing injury}}.
cards.easyContent: Ripeness asks whether a dispute has developed enough to be decided now, while mootness asks whether there is still a live controversy at all stages. A case is not moot if the wrong is capable of repetition yet evading review, if the defendant voluntarily ceases but can resume, or in class actions where at least one class member remains injured.
cards.mediumContent: For justiciability, a case must be ripe and not moot. Ripeness bars claims brought too early, before a law or government act has been implemented enough to create a concrete dispute. Mootness bars claims that become academic after filing—if the plaintiff’s injury has disappeared and no exception applies. Exceptions to mootness include: (1) wrongs capable of repetition but evading review, where the injury ends too quickly to fully litigate yet is likely to recur to the same plaintiff; (2) voluntary cessation by the defendant, where the defendant stops the challenged conduct but remains free to restart; and (3) class actions, where the case can continue so long as at least one class member has an ongoing injury.
cards.hardContent: A federal case must involve a ripe claim and cannot be moot. Ripeness requires that the dispute has matured sufficiently to warrant judicial decision; courts generally will not review a law or government action before it is effectuated and causes a concrete injury or imminent threat. Mootness requires that a live controversy exist at all stages of review; if the circumstances causing the plaintiff’s harm cease after suit is filed, the case must usually be dismissed as moot. However, a case is not moot where: (1) the wrong is capable of repetition yet evading review, as when the injury ends before the litigation can conclude but the same plaintiff can reasonably expect to face the harm again (e.g., repeated bar exams or pregnancies); (2) the defendant voluntarily ceases the challenged conduct but remains free to resume it; or (3) in class actions, at least one member of the certified class continues to suffer an ongoing injury.
cards.mnemonic: Ripe is ready; moot is over—R before M in time.
cards.clozeLite: For justiciability, a case must be {{c1::ripe}} and {{c2::not moot}}. {{c3::Ripeness}} bars claims brought too early; {{c4::mootness}} bars cases when the injury disappears unless an {{c5::exception to mootness}} applies.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 005. Political Question Doctrine
cards.front: Political Question Doctrine
cards.backPlain: Federal courts will not adjudicate certain constitutional issues that constitute political questions. 1. Political questions involve issues that: 1.1 The Constitution commits to another branch of government (i.e., not the judiciary); or 1.2 Are inherently incapable of judicial resolution or enforcement. 2. Common political questions deemed non-justiciable include: 2.1 Actions under the Guarantee Clause (republican form of government); 2.2 Challenges to the conduct of foreign policy; 2.3 Challenges to impeachment and removal proceedings. 3. Non-political questions deemed justiciable include: 3.1 Production of presidential papers or communications.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the political question doctrine, and what are common examples of non-justiciable and justiciable political question issues?
cards.cloze: Federal courts will not adjudicate certain constitutional issues that constitute {{c1::political questions}}. 1. Political questions involve issues that: 1.1 The {{c2::Constitution commits to another branch of government}} (i.e., not the judiciary); or 1.2 Are {{c3::inherently incapable of judicial resolution or enforcement}}. 2. Common political questions deemed {{c4::non-justiciable}} include: 2.1 Actions under the {{c5::Guarantee Clause}} (republican form of government); 2.2 Challenges to the conduct of {{c6::foreign policy}}; 2.3 Challenges to {{c7::impeachment and removal proceedings}}. 3. Non-political questions deemed {{c8::justiciable}} include: 3.1 {{c9::Production of presidential papers or communications}}.
cards.easyContent: Under the political question doctrine, federal courts refuse to decide certain constitutional issues that are committed to the political branches or lack judicially manageable standards, such as Guarantee Clause claims, foreign policy challenges, and impeachment procedures.
cards.mediumContent: A political question is a constitutional issue that federal courts treat as non-justiciable because the Constitution assigns it to another branch or because it is inherently unsuitable for judicial resolution. Typical non-justiciable political questions include suits under the Guarantee Clause (republican form of government), challenges to how the political branches conduct foreign policy, and challenges to impeachment and removal proceedings. By contrast, some matters involving the President, such as disputes over production of presidential papers or communications, are usually considered justiciable.
cards.hardContent: The political question doctrine bars federal courts from adjudicating certain constitutional disputes that are either textually committed by the Constitution to another branch of government or are inherently incapable of judicial resolution or enforcement due to the lack of judicially manageable standards. Common examples of non-justiciable political questions include challenges brought under the Guarantee Clause (which guarantees each state a republican form of government), challenges to the political branches’ conduct of foreign policy, and challenges to impeachment and removal processes in Congress. However, not all cases involving the President or other branches are political questions; for example, disputes over the production of presidential papers or communications have been treated as justiciable and subject to judicial resolution.
cards.mnemonic: GFI: Guarantee Clause, Foreign policy, Impeachment = political questions.
cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::political question doctrine}} makes some issues {{c2::non-justiciable}}—like {{c3::Guarantee Clause}}, {{c4::foreign policy conduct}}, and {{c5::impeachment procedures}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 006. Supreme Court Jurisdiction and Review
cards.front: Supreme Court Jurisdiction and Review
cards.backPlain: The Supreme Court’s jurisdiction and review powers break down into four key areas: 1. Original jurisdiction - Under Article III, the Supreme Court has original jurisdiction over suits between states and cases involving foreign ambassadors and other foreign ministers. - These cases must be brought in federal court, and suits between states must be filed in the Supreme Court itself. - Congress cannot expand the Court's original jurisdiction beyond what Article III provides. 2. Methods of Supreme Court review - Discretionary review: Most cases reach the Supreme Court by writ of certiorari, which the Court may grant or deny in its discretion. - Mandatory review: The Court must hear direct appeals from three-judge district court panels deciding injunctive relief, bypassing the courts of appeal. 3. Final judgment and limits on appellate jurisdiction - The Court generally reviews only final judgments of lower federal courts or a state's highest court. - Congress may limit the Court's appellate jurisdiction to certain categories of cases under Article III, but may not expand its original jurisdiction. 4. Adequate and independent state grounds - The Court cannot review a state court decision that rests on an independent and adequate state law ground. - If a state court decision is based on both federal and state law, the Supreme Court will review only if the judgment cannot stand on the state law ground alone.
cards.frontPrompt: How is the Supreme Court’s jurisdiction and review authority structured, including original jurisdiction, methods of review, the final judgment rule, and the adequate-and-independent state grounds limitation?
cards.cloze: The Supreme Court’s jurisdiction and review powers break down into four key areas: 1. {{c1::Original jurisdiction}} (suits between states; foreign ambassadors and ministers; cannot be expanded by Congress). 2. {{c2::Methods of review}} (primarily discretionary {{c3::certiorari}}, with limited {{c4::mandatory}} appeals from {{c5::three-judge district court panels}} on {{c6::injunctive relief}}). 3. {{c7::Final judgment}} and {{c8::limits on appellate jurisdiction}} (review of {{c9::final judgments}} only; Congress may {{c10::limit}} but not expand jurisdiction within Article III). 4. {{c11::Adequate and independent state grounds}} (no review if the state law ground is {{c12::independent}} of federal law and {{c13::adequate}} to support the judgment).
cards.easyContent: The Supreme Court’s jurisdiction covers (1) limited original cases (states and foreign ministers), (2) mostly discretionary review by certiorari plus narrow mandatory appeals, (3) only final judgments from lower courts within Article III limits, and (4) no review of state judgments resting on adequate and independent state law grounds.
cards.mediumContent: The Supreme Court has limited original jurisdiction over suits between states and cases involving foreign ambassadors and ministers, which Congress cannot expand. Most cases reach the Court by discretionary writ of certiorari, but it must hear certain mandatory appeals from three-judge district court panels deciding injunctive relief. The Court generally reviews only final judgments from lower federal courts or a state's highest court, and Congress may limit but not expand the Court’s appellate jurisdiction within Article III. The Court cannot review state court decisions that rest on an independent and adequate state law ground.
cards.hardContent: The Supreme Court’s jurisdiction and review authority is structured into four parts: (1) Original jurisdiction: Under Article III, the Court has original jurisdiction over suits between states and cases involving foreign ambassadors and other foreign ministers. These cases must be brought in federal court, and suits between states must be filed in the Supreme Court itself. Congress cannot expand the Court’s original jurisdiction. (2) Methods of review: Most cases reach the Court by discretionary writ of certiorari, which the Court may grant or deny. By contrast, the Court must take mandatory appeals from three-judge federal district court panels deciding injunctive relief, bypassing the courts of appeal. (3) Final judgment and appellate limits: The Court generally reviews only final judgments from lower federal courts or a state’s highest court. Congress may limit the Court’s appellate jurisdiction to certain categories of cases, consistent with Article III, but may not enlarge its original jurisdiction. (4) Adequate and independent state grounds: The Court cannot review state court decisions that rest on an independent and adequate state law ground. If a state court decision is based on both federal and state law, the Court will review only if the judgment cannot stand on the state law ground alone.
cards.mnemonic: O-FAM: Original, Final judgment, Appeals, state-law Motive (independent & adequate).
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into four children: (1) original jurisdiction and limits, (2) methods of review (certiorari vs mandatory appeals), (3) final judgment rule and congressional limits on appellate jurisdiction, (4) adequate and independent state grounds.
cards.clozeLite: SCOTUS has {{c1::limited original jurisdiction}} Congress {{c2::cannot expand}}, mostly {{c3::discretionary certiorari}}, reviews {{c4::final judgments only}}, and cannot review {{c5::adequate and independent state grounds}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 007. The 11th Amendment and Sovereign Immunity
cards.front: The 11th Amendment and Sovereign Immunity – Overview
cards.backPlain: The 11th Amendment and related sovereign immunity doctrine generally bar suits against state governments, but there are important exceptions. 1. Baseline rule - Federal courts cannot hear suits brought by private parties or foreign governments against a state government. - Sovereign immunity also generally prohibits suits against states in their own courts. 2. Major workarounds - Suits directly against states in federal court are allowed only in narrow circumstances (e.g., waiver, valid Section 5 abrogation, federal government suits, bankruptcy). - Even when states themselves are immune, plaintiffs can often sue state officers in federal court for prospective injunctive relief or for damages from the officer’s personal assets. Use the subcards to learn: (1) the basic immunity rule, (2) the main exceptions that permit suits against states in federal court, and (3) when state officers may be sued in federal court instead of the state itself.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the overall structure of 11th Amendment and sovereign immunity doctrine, including the baseline rule, main exceptions, and the role of suits against state officers?
cards.cloze: The {{c1::11th Amendment}} and related doctrine of {{c2::sovereign immunity}} generally bar suits against {{c3::state governments}} in {{c4::federal court}} and often in {{c5::state court}} as well, subject to narrow {{c6::exceptions}} and the possibility of suing {{c7::state officers}} for {{c8::injunctive relief}} or {{c9::personal-capacity damages}}.
cards.easyContent: The 11th Amendment and sovereign immunity generally bar suits against states, but there are narrow exceptions and a major workaround: suing state officers for prospective relief or personal-capacity damages.
cards.mediumContent: The 11th Amendment and sovereign immunity create a default rule that states cannot be sued by private parties or foreign governments in federal court, and are generally immune in their own courts as well. This immunity can be overcome only in limited situations, such as valid waiver, congressional abrogation under Section 5 of the 14th Amendment, federal government suits, and bankruptcy proceedings. Even when the state itself remains immune, plaintiffs can often sue state officers in federal court for prospective injunctive relief to stop ongoing violations of federal law or for damages from the officer’s personal assets.
cards.hardContent: 11th Amendment and sovereign immunity doctrine has three key pieces: (1) a baseline rule that bars most suits against state governments in federal court (and generally protects states in their own courts); (2) narrow exceptions where states can be sued directly in federal court, such as waiver/consent, valid Section 5 of the 14th Amendment abrogation, federal government enforcement actions, and bankruptcy proceedings; and (3) the Ex parte Young-style workaround that allows suits in federal court against state officers, rather than the state itself, for prospective injunctive relief to stop ongoing violations of federal law and for personal-capacity damages that do not come from the state treasury.
cards.mnemonic: W-Fed-B-5: Waiver, Federal suits, Bankruptcy, valid Section 5 abrogation.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into three children: (1) basic 11th Amendment/sovereign immunity baseline rule, (2) exceptions allowing suits against states in federal court, and (3) suits against state officers for injunctive and personal-capacity damages.
cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::11th Amendment and sovereign immunity}} bar most {{c2::suits against states}}, with {{c3::narrow exceptions}} and the {{c4::Ex parte Young}} {{c5::officer-suit workaround}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 008. Legislative Powers Overview
cards.front: Legislative Powers Overview
cards.backPlain: Congress’s legislative powers under Article I include key enumerated powers, like taxing and spending, regulating commerce, establishing uniform rules of naturalization and bankruptcy, and raising and supporting the military. The executive branch is obligated to execute the laws Congress passes, but Congress itself is the primary lawmaking body. Two important constitutional clauses shape how Congress exercises its powers and how members of Congress are protected: 1. Speech or Debate Clause: Members of Congress are immune from civil and criminal liability for legislative acts and for activities and documents essential to their legislative duties. 2. Necessary and Proper Clause: Congress may adopt any means not otherwise unconstitutional that are useful or convenient to carry into execution its express powers, thereby creating implied powers. However, this Clause is not an independent source of power and must be tied to another federal power.
cards.frontPrompt: What are Congress’s core Article I powers, and what key clauses affect how Congress may exercise those powers and how legislators are protected?
cards.cloze: Congress’s legislative powers under {{c1::Article I}} include key {{c2::enumerated powers}}, like {{c3::taxing and spending}}, {{c4::regulating commerce}}, establishing uniform rules of {{c5::naturalization}} and {{c6::bankruptcy}}, and raising and supporting the {{c7::military}}. Two important constitutional clauses shape how Congress exercises its powers and how members of Congress are protected: 1. {{c8::Speech or Debate Clause}}: Members of Congress are immune from civil and criminal liability for {{c9::legislative acts}} and for activities and documents {{c10::essential to their legislative duties}}. 2. {{c11::Necessary and Proper Clause}}: Congress may adopt any means not otherwise unconstitutional that are useful or convenient to {{c12::carry into execution its express powers}}, thereby creating {{c13::implied powers}}. However, this Clause is {{c14::not an independent source of power}} and must be tied to another federal power.
cards.easyContent: Congress’s Article I powers include taxing and spending, regulating commerce, setting naturalization and bankruptcy rules, and raising and supporting the military. The Speech or Debate Clause protects members of Congress from liability for legislative acts, and the Necessary and Proper Clause lets Congress use implied means to carry out its enumerated powers, though it is not a freestanding power source.
cards.mediumContent: Under Article I, Congress has enumerated powers such as taxing and spending, regulating commerce, establishing uniform rules of naturalization and bankruptcy, and raising and supporting the military. The Speech or Debate Clause gives members of Congress immunity from civil and criminal liability for legislative acts and related activities and documents essential to their legislative duties. The Necessary and Proper Clause authorizes Congress to choose appropriate, not otherwise prohibited means to carry into execution its express powers, thereby creating implied powers, but the Clause is not itself an independent source of legislative power.
cards.hardContent: Article I establishes Congress’s principal enumerated powers, including the powers to tax and spend, regulate interstate and foreign commerce, establish uniform rules for naturalization and bankruptcy, and raise and support the armed forces, while the executive branch is obligated to execute the laws that Congress enacts. Two key clauses structure how these powers operate. First, under the Speech or Debate Clause, members of Congress are immune from civil and criminal liability for legislative acts, and this protection extends to activities and documents that are essential to performing legislative duties. Second, under the Necessary and Proper Clause, Congress may adopt any means not otherwise unconstitutional that are useful or convenient to carrying into execution its express powers, thereby creating implied powers. However, the Clause does not provide an independent basis for federal legislation and must be tied to another enumerated federal power, which is why it is often an incorrect standalone answer on questions about congressional authority.
cards.mnemonic: T-C-N-B-M: Tax, Commerce, Naturalization, Bankruptcy, Military; NP is glue, not power.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into three children: (1) enumerated Article I powers (and execution); (2) Speech or Debate Clause immunity; (3) Necessary and Proper Clause and implied powers.
cards.clozeLite: Congress’s core Article I powers include {{c1::taxing and spending}}, {{c2::regulating commerce}}, {{c3::naturalization and bankruptcy}} rules, and {{c4::raising and supporting the military}}. The {{c5::Necessary and Proper Clause}} creates implied powers but is {{c6::not an independent source of power}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 009. Taxing & Spending Power
cards.front: Taxing & Spending Power
cards.backPlain: Congress’s taxing and spending power is very broad. Congress may tax and spend in any way it deems necessary to provide for the general welfare, and on bar exam questions this is usually the correct basis for federal authority when the law involves taxation, spending, or Congress’s limited police power areas (the military, Indian reservations, federal land, and the District of Columbia). Within this power, Congress may: - Impose taxes that need only reasonably relate to raising revenue (a low threshold), and measures labeled as penalties can be upheld as taxes if they function like taxes; and - Use taxes and spending as regulatory tools, through regulatory taxes (where raising revenue remains the dominant purpose and there is a reasonable relationship to the regulation) and regulatory spending (attaching non-coercive conditions to federal funds to influence behavior).
cards.frontPrompt: What is Congress’s taxing and spending power, and in what broad ways can it be used to regulate behavior (including taxes, penalties, and spending conditions)?
cards.cloze: Congress’s {{c1::taxing and spending power}} is very broad. Congress may {{c2::tax and spend}} in any way it deems necessary to provide for the {{c3::general welfare}}, and on bar exam questions this is usually the correct basis for federal authority when the law involves {{c4::taxation}}, {{c5::spending}}, or Congress’s limited {{c6::police power}} areas (the {{c7::military}}, {{c8::Indian reservations}}, {{c9::federal land}}, and the {{c10::District of Columbia}}). Within this power, Congress may: - Impose {{c11::taxes}} that need only {{c12::reasonably relate to raising revenue}} (a low threshold), and measures labeled as {{c13::penalties}} can be upheld as {{c14::taxes}} if they {{c15::function like taxes}}; and - Use {{c16::taxes and spending as regulatory tools}}, through {{c17::regulatory taxes}} (where {{c18::raising revenue}} remains the {{c19::dominant purpose}} and there is a {{c20::reasonable relationship}} to the regulation) and {{c21::regulatory spending}} (attaching {{c22::non-coercive conditions}} to federal funds to influence behavior).
cards.easyContent: Congress may tax and spend for the general welfare, a broad power usually used to justify federal laws involving taxation, spending, or limited police power areas. Congress can design taxes (including some penalties) to raise revenue and influence behavior, and it can attach non-coercive conditions to federal funds to regulate indirectly.
cards.mediumContent: Congress’s taxing and spending power allows it to tax and spend for the general welfare, and this is often the correct basis for federal authority when the statute involves taxation, spending, or Congress’s limited police power domains (military, Indian reservations, federal land, and D.C.). Taxes need only reasonably relate to raising revenue, and measures labeled as penalties can still be upheld as taxes if they operate like taxes. Congress can use this power to regulate behavior by enacting regulatory taxes—so long as raising revenue is the dominant purpose and there is some reasonable relationship to the regulation—and by attaching non-coercive conditions to the receipt of federal funds.
cards.hardContent: Congress may tax and spend to provide for the general welfare, a power interpreted very broadly. On exam questions, this is usually the correct source of federal authority when a law concerns taxation, spending, or one of Congress’s limited police power areas: the military, Indian reservations, federal property, or the District of Columbia. The only substantive requirement for a tax is that it bear a reasonable relationship to raising revenue, a minimal standard; a charge styled as a penalty may still be sustained under the taxing power if it functions like a tax (as with the Affordable Care Act individual mandate). Congress may also design taxes that both raise revenue and influence private or state behavior, as long as revenue-raising remains the dominant purpose and there is some reasonable connection between the tax and the regulated activity. Likewise, Congress may use its spending power to influence or regulate behavior by placing conditions on federal funds, provided those conditions are not unduly or overly coercive on the states.
cards.mnemonic: G-RAMID: General welfare; Revenue; Areas: Military, Indians, federal land, D.C.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into: (1) basic taxing and spending for the general welfare and bar exam context, (2) taxes, revenue requirement, and penalties treated as taxes, and (3) regulatory taxes and regulatory spending/conditional funding.
cards.clozeLite: Congress may {{c1::tax and spend for the general welfare}} and may {{c2::use regulatory taxes}} or {{c3::attach non-coercive conditions to federal funds}} to influence behavior.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 010. Police Power
cards.front: Police Power
cards.backPlain: 1. No general federal police power 1.1 Congress has no general police power to legislate for the health, safety, welfare, or morals of the public. 2. Limited federal "police" power areas 2.1 Congress effectively has a police power only for legislation concerning: 2.1.1 The military. 2.1.2 Indian reservations. 2.1.3 Federal land and territories. 2.1.4 The District of Columbia.
cards.frontPrompt: Does Congress have a general police power, and in what limited areas does it effectively exercise a police power?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::No general federal police power}} 1.1 Congress has no general police power to legislate for the {{c2::health, safety, welfare, or morals}} of the public. 2. Limited federal "police" power areas 2.1 Congress effectively has a police power only for legislation concerning: 2.1.1 The {{c3::military}}. 2.1.2 {{c4::Indian reservations}}. 2.1.3 {{c5::federal land and territories}}. 2.1.4 The {{c6::District of Columbia}}.
cards.easyContent: Congress has no general police power to legislate for public health, safety, welfare, or morals, except in a few special areas: the military, Indian reservations, federal lands and territories, and the District of Columbia.
cards.mediumContent: The federal government lacks a general police power like the states and ordinarily cannot legislate merely for public health, safety, welfare, or morals. Congress effectively has a police power only in specific federal domains: governing the military, Indian reservations, federal property and territories, and the District of Columbia.
cards.hardContent: Unlike state governments, which possess general police powers, Congress does not have a general authority to legislate for the public’s health, safety, welfare, or morals. Its power to enact such regulations must be tied to an enumerated constitutional grant. Functionally, however, Congress exercises something akin to a general police power in four limited areas under its specific constitutional authority: governing the military, regulating Indian reservations, managing and legislating for federal land and territories, and governing the District of Columbia.
cards.mnemonic: MILD: Military, Indian reservations, Land (federal), D.C.
cards.clozeLite: Congress lacks a {{c1::general police power}} and has effective police power only over {{c2::military}}, {{c3::Indian reservations}}, {{c4::federal lands/territories}}, and {{c5::D.C.}}

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 011. Power to Regulate Commerce
cards.front: Power to Regulate Commerce – Overview
cards.backPlain: The Commerce Clause gives Congress broad authority to regulate interstate and intrastate commerce. 1. Interstate commerce 1.1 Congress may regulate the channels and instrumentalities of interstate commerce, and persons and things in interstate commerce. 1.2 Congress may also regulate economic activities that, in the aggregate, have a substantial effect on interstate commerce. 2. Intrastate commerce 2.1 Congress’s power to regulate intrastate activity depends on whether the activity is economic or non‑economic. 2.2 For intrastate economic activity, Congress needs only a rational basis to conclude that, in the aggregate, it substantially affects interstate commerce. 2.3 For intrastate non‑economic activity, Congress must show a direct, substantial economic effect on interstate commerce. 3. Dormant Commerce Clause 3.1 Even when Congress has not acted, the Dormant Commerce Clause limits state laws that burden interstate commerce by interfering with Congress’s commerce power.
cards.frontPrompt: Summarize Congress’s power to regulate commerce under the Commerce Clause, including interstate vs. intrastate activity and the role of the Dormant Commerce Clause.
cards.cloze: The {{c1::Commerce Clause}} gives Congress broad authority to regulate {{c2::interstate and intrastate commerce}}. 1. {{c3::Interstate commerce}}: Congress may regulate the {{c4::channels and instrumentalities of interstate commerce}} and {{c5::persons and things in interstate commerce}}, as well as {{c6::economic activities that, in the aggregate, substantially affect interstate commerce}}. 2. {{c7::Intrastate commerce}}: Congress’s power depends on whether the activity is {{c8::economic}} or {{c9::non‑economic}}. 3. {{c10::Dormant Commerce Clause}}: limits {{c11::state laws that burden interstate commerce}} by interfering with {{c12::Congress’s commerce power}}.
cards.easyContent: Congress may regulate interstate commerce broadly (channels, instrumentalities, and substantial economic effects) and may reach intrastate activity under different standards for economic vs. non‑economic conduct. The Dormant Commerce Clause limits burdensome state laws even when Congress has not acted.
cards.mediumContent: Under the Commerce Clause, Congress can regulate the channels and instrumentalities of interstate commerce, persons and things in interstate commerce, and economic activities that substantially affect interstate commerce. For intrastate activity, the standard is more lenient for economic activity than for non‑economic activity. Separately, the Dormant Commerce Clause restricts state laws that unduly burden interstate commerce.
cards.hardContent: Congress’s commerce power encompasses regulation of interstate commerce (including channels, instrumentalities, persons and things, and aggregate substantial economic effects) and intrastate commerce under different standards for economic vs. non‑economic activity. In parallel, the Dormant Commerce Clause operates as an implied limit on state laws that burden interstate commerce by interfering with Congress’s commerce power.
cards.mnemonic: CIS: Channels, Instrumentalities, Substantial economic effects; Dormant limits States.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into (1) interstate commerce categories, (2) intrastate economic vs. non‑economic standards, and (3) overview of the Dormant Commerce Clause.
cards.clozeLite: Congress may regulate {{c1::channels and instrumentalities of interstate commerce}}, and {{c2::economic activities that substantially affect interstate commerce}}; {{c3::Dormant Commerce Clause}} limits burdensome state laws.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Tenth Amendment Limitations on Congressional Power
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 012. Tenth Amendment Limitations on Congressional Power
cards.front: Tenth Amendment Limitations on Congressional Power
cards.backPlain: The Tenth Amendment reserves to the states all powers not granted to the federal government and not prohibited to the states. This limits Congress’s ability to regulate or tax states as states and prohibits Congress from commandeering state legislative or executive processes by requiring states to enact laws or administer federal law. However, Congress may regulate states through generally applicable laws that apply to both public and private actors, and may restrict state activities that violate civil liberties and civil rights (including through its Fourteenth Amendment enforcement power). Congress may also influence state policy through conditional grants of federal funds, so long as the conditions meet specific requirements (clear, related, and not unduly coercive).
cards.frontPrompt: How does the Tenth Amendment limit Congress’s ability to regulate or tax state governments, and in what general ways can Congress still influence state action (including through generally applicable laws, civil rights enforcement, and conditional grants)?
cards.cloze: Under the {{c1::Tenth Amendment}}, powers not granted to the {{c2::federal government}} nor prohibited to the {{c3::states}} are {{c4::reserved to the states}}. This limits Congress’s ability to {{c5::regulate or tax states as states}} and bars {{c6::commandeering}} of state legislative or executive processes by requiring states to enact laws or administer federal law. However, Congress may regulate states through {{c7::generally applicable laws}} that cover both public and private actors, may restrict state activities that violate {{c8::civil liberties and civil rights}} (including via the {{c9::Fourteenth Amendment}}), and may influence state policy through {{c10::conditional grants of federal funds}} that satisfy specific requirements.
cards.easyContent: The Tenth Amendment reserves powers not given to the federal government, or denied to the states, to the states. Congress therefore cannot directly commandeer state governments, but it can regulate them through generally applicable laws, enforce civil rights against them, and influence them through properly structured conditional grants.
cards.mediumContent: The Tenth Amendment provides that powers not granted to the federal government nor prohibited to the states are reserved to the states. Congress cannot regulate or tax states as states in a way that commandeers state legislative or executive processes by forcing them to enact laws or administer federal programs. However, Congress may (1) regulate states through generally applicable laws that also apply to private actors, (2) restrict state actions that violate civil liberties and civil rights, including under the Fourteenth Amendment, and (3) influence state policy through conditional grants of federal funds that meet constitutional requirements.
cards.hardContent: Under the Tenth Amendment, powers not granted to the federal government nor prohibited to the states are reserved to the states, constraining Congress’s ability to regulate or tax states as states. Congress may not commandeer state governments by requiring state legislatures to enact laws or state executives to administer federal programs. Nonetheless, Congress can regulate states through generally applicable laws that cover both public and private actors (e.g., minimum wage laws that also bind state and local governments). Congress may also prohibit and remedy state violations of civil liberties and civil rights, including using its Fourteenth Amendment enforcement power. Additionally, Congress may influence state legislative or regulatory choices by attaching conditions to federal grants to states, so long as those conditions are clear, related to the federal program, and not unduly coercive.
cards.mnemonic: Tenth tools: G-R-A-N-T—Generally applicable laws, Rights enforcement, And coNditional funding Tricks.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into: (1) general Tenth Amendment anti‑commandeering/dual application and civil rights limits, and (2) requirements for valid conditional spending grants to states.
cards.clozeLite: Under the {{c1::Tenth Amendment}}, Congress cannot {{c2::commandeer state governments}}, but may use {{c3::generally applicable laws}}, {{c4::civil-rights enforcement}}, and {{c5::conditional grants}} to influence states.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 013. Congressional Delegation of Powers
cards.front: Congressional Delegation of Powers – Overview
cards.backPlain: Congress may broadly delegate rulemaking authority to executive officers and administrative agencies by statute, and validly promulgated agency rules can have the force and effect of law. Delegation doctrine imposes only limited constraints: Congress must supply intelligible standards to guide the exercise of delegated authority and may not reserve executive or judicial enforcement powers to itself or its officers. While challenges based on excessive delegation almost always fail, related separation‑of‑powers mechanisms—such as legislative vetoes and presidential line‑item vetoes—have been held unconstitutional because they bypass bicameralism and presentment or improperly reallocate legislative power.
cards.frontPrompt: How broadly may Congress delegate powers to agencies, what are the main limits on that delegation, and how do legislative and line‑item vetoes relate to delegation and separation of powers?
cards.cloze: Congress may {{c1::broadly delegate rulemaking authority}} to executive officers and administrative agencies by statute, and validly promulgated agency rules can have the {{c2::force and effect of law}}. Delegation is limited mainly by the requirement that Congress provide {{c3::intelligible standards}} and that it not {{c4::reserve executive or judicial enforcement powers to itself or its officers}}. Although excessive‑delegation challenges rarely succeed, {{c5::legislative vetoes and presidential line‑item vetoes}} have been held unconstitutional because they {{c6::bypass bicameralism and presentment or improperly reallocate legislative power}}.
cards.easyContent: Congress can broadly delegate rulemaking power to agencies if it provides intelligible standards and does not keep enforcement power for itself. Excessive‑delegation challenges rarely succeed, but legislative and line‑item vetoes are unconstitutional ways of controlling or reallocating delegated power.
cards.mediumContent: Congress may delegate legislative power to executive officers and agencies via enabling statutes, and agency rules can carry the force of law. Delegation requires intelligible standards and prohibits Congress from retaining executive or judicial enforcement authority in itself or its officers. Although courts seldom invalidate statutes for excessive delegation, they have struck down related mechanisms—legislative vetoes and presidential line‑item vetoes—as violating bicameralism and presentment or improperly transferring legislative authority.
cards.hardContent: Congress’s delegation power is broad: through enabling statutes it may authorize executive officers and administrative agencies to adopt rules with the force and effect of law. The main limits are that (1) Congress must articulate intelligible standards to channel the exercise of delegated authority, and (2) Congress may not delegate executive or judicial enforcement functions to itself or its own officers, such as by creating bodies under its control that prosecute or enforce federal law. Because the nondelegation doctrine is applied leniently, courts rarely strike down statutes for excessive delegation, so bar‑exam answers that rest solely on “too much delegation” are usually wrong. However, closely related devices such as legislative vetoes and presidential line‑item vetoes have been held unconstitutional because they circumvent the constitutional lawmaking process—bicameralism and presentment—or amount to an improper reallocation of legislative power to another branch.
cards.mnemonic: BIG: Broad power, Intelligible standards, no Government self-enforcement.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into: (1) scope and limits of congressional delegation to agencies, and (2) unconstitutionality of legislative vetoes and presidential line‑item vetoes.
cards.clozeLite: Congress may {{c1::broadly delegate}} lawmaking to agencies if it provides {{c2::intelligible standards}} and {{c3::does not retain enforcement power}} in itself.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 014. Appointment and Removal Powers
cards.front: Appointment and Removal Powers – Overview
cards.backPlain: 1. Appointment of federal officers - The President appoints ambassadors, federal judges, and other principal officers with the advice and consent of the Senate. - Congress cannot give itself appointment power, but may vest appointment of inferior officers in the President alone, the courts, or heads of departments. Inferior officers are generally subordinates who work under, and are removable by, principal officers. 2. Removal of federal officers - The President may remove high‑level executive officers and, subject to statutory limits (e.g., good cause), other executive appointees. - Congress has no general removal power; it removes executive officers and Article III judges only through impeachment. 3. Impeachment - The House impeaches the President, Vice President, federal judges, and other federal officers by majority vote for treason, bribery, or other high crimes and misdemeanors. - The Senate tries impeachments and may remove the officer upon conviction by the constitutionally required supermajority vote.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the basic rules governing appointment and removal of federal officers, and how does impeachment fit into that structure?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Appointment of federal officers}} - The {{c2::President}} appoints {{c3::ambassadors, federal judges, and other principal officers}} with the {{c4::advice and consent of the Senate}}. - {{c5::Congress}} cannot give itself appointment power, but may vest appointment of {{c6::inferior officers}} in the {{c7::President alone}}, the {{c8::courts}}, or {{c9::heads of departments}}. 2. {{c10::Removal of federal officers}} - The {{c11::President}} may remove {{c12::high‑level executive officers}} and, subject to statutory {{c13::good‑cause or similar limits}}, other executive appointees. - {{c14::Congress}} has no general removal power; it removes executive officers and {{c15::Article III judges}} only through {{c16::impeachment}}. 3. {{c17::Impeachment}} - The {{c18::House}} impeaches by {{c19::majority vote}} for {{c20::treason, bribery, or other high crimes and misdemeanors}}. - The {{c21::Senate}} tries impeachments and may remove upon conviction by the constitutionally required {{c22::supermajority vote}}.
cards.easyContent: The President, with Senate consent, appoints principal officers, while Congress may allow the President, courts, or department heads to appoint inferior officers. The President generally removes executive officers (subject to some statutory limits). Congress can remove executive officers and Article III judges only through impeachment in the House and conviction in the Senate.
cards.mediumContent: The President appoints ambassadors, federal judges, and other principal officers with Senate advice and consent. Congress cannot appoint officers itself but may vest appointment of inferior officers—subordinates who work under and are removable by principal officers—in the President alone, the courts, or department heads. The President may remove high‑level executive officers and, subject to good‑cause or similar statutory limits, other executive appointees. Congress has no general removal power; executive officers and Article III judges can be removed only through impeachment by majority vote in the House and conviction by the constitutionally required supermajority in the Senate.
cards.hardContent: Under the Appointments Clause, the President appoints ambassadors, federal judges, and other principal (high‑level) officers with the advice and consent of the Senate. Congress may not reserve appointment powers for itself, but it may vest the appointment of inferior officers—subordinates who work under presidentially appointed officers and are removable by them—in the President alone, in the courts, or in heads of departments. The President has the power to remove high‑level executive officers and, subject to congressionally imposed good‑cause or similar limits, other executive appointees. Congress has no general removal authority over officers; instead, it can remove executive officers and Article III judges only through impeachment: the House impeaches by majority vote for treason, bribery, or other high crimes and misdemeanors, and the Senate conducts the trial and may remove the officer upon conviction by the constitutionally required supermajority vote.
cards.mnemonic: P + S for Principals; P/C/H for Inferiors; President removes, Congress impeaches.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into three children: (1) appointment of principal vs. inferior officers, (2) presidential and congressional removal powers, and (3) impeachment standards and procedure.
cards.clozeLite: Under the {{c1::Appointments Clause}}, {{c2::principal officers}} need {{c3::President + Senate}} approval, while {{c4::inferior officers}} may be appointed by {{c5::President, courts, or department heads}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Immunity, Executive Privilege, and Pardon Power
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 015. Immunity, Executive Privilege, and Pardon Power
cards.front: Immunity, Executive Privilege, and Pardon Power
cards.backPlain: 1. Presidential immunity 1.1 The President has absolute immunity from civil suits arising from official actions taken while in office. 1.2 The President has no immunity for actions occurring prior to taking office or for purely private conduct. 2. Executive privilege 2.1 Executive privilege protects against disclosure of presidential papers and conversations. 2.2 Important governmental interests in criminal cases can override the privilege (e.g., in the Watergate tapes case, presidential documents and phone logs were disclosed for evidentiary purposes, which overrode the privilege). 3. Pardon power 3.1 The President has the power to pardon those accused or convicted of federal crimes (not state crimes). 3.2 Exception: The President cannot pardon someone for offenses that led to impeachment or undo the legal consequences of impeachment. 3.3 The President may also commute federal criminal sentences. 3.4 Congress cannot limit the President’s constitutional pardon power.
cards.frontPrompt: What civil immunity and executive privilege does the President have, and what are the scope and limits of the President’s federal pardon power?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Presidential immunity}} 1.1 The President has {{c2::absolute immunity}} from {{c3::civil suits arising from official actions taken while in office}}. 1.2 The President has {{c4::no immunity}} for actions occurring {{c5::prior to taking office}} or for {{c6::purely private conduct}}. 2. {{c7::Executive privilege}} 2.1 Executive privilege protects against disclosure of {{c8::presidential papers and conversations}}. 2.2 Important governmental interests in {{c9::criminal cases}} can override the privilege (e.g., in the {{c10::Watergate}} tapes case, presidential documents and phone logs were disclosed for evidentiary purposes, which overrode the privilege). 3. {{c11::Pardon power}} 3.1 The President has the power to pardon those accused or convicted of {{c12::federal crimes}} (not state crimes). 3.2 Exception: The President cannot pardon someone for offenses that led to {{c13::impeachment}} or undo the legal consequences of impeachment. 3.3 The President may also {{c14::commute federal criminal sentences}}. 3.4 {{c15::Congress cannot limit}} the President’s constitutional pardon power.
cards.easyContent: The President is absolutely immune from civil suits for official acts, may assert executive privilege over presidential communications subject to override in criminal cases, and has broad power to pardon or commute federal, but not state, offenses, except for offenses leading to impeachment.
cards.mediumContent: The President enjoys absolute civil immunity for official acts taken while in office but has no immunity for pre‑office or purely private conduct. Executive privilege protects presidential papers and communications from disclosure, but it yields when outweighed by an important governmental interest in a criminal case. The President may grant pardons and commutations for federal crimes, but not state crimes, and cannot use the pardon power to negate impeachment or its consequences. Congress cannot curtail this constitutional pardon power.
cards.hardContent: The President is absolutely immune from civil liability for official acts undertaken while in office, though this immunity does not extend to conduct occurring before taking office or to purely private acts. The President may invoke executive privilege to resist disclosure of presidential papers and conversations, reflecting the need for confidential executive deliberations, but this privilege is qualified: in criminal proceedings, important governmental interests in obtaining evidence can override it, as in the Watergate tapes case. The President also possesses broad authority under the Pardon Clause to pardon or commute federal criminal offenses at any stage, whether before or after conviction. This power does not extend to state crimes and cannot be used to forgive offenses that gave rise to impeachment or to reverse the legal consequences of impeachment. Congress may not limit or condition the President’s constitutionally granted pardon power.
cards.mnemonic: Presidential PIP: Privilege, Immunity, Pardons (federal only, not impeachment).
cards.clozeLite: The President has {{c1::absolute civil immunity for official acts in office}}, a {{c2::qualified executive privilege over presidential communications}}, and {{c3::broad power to pardon federal (not state) crimes, except impeachment offenses}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 016. Treaties and Executive Agreements
cards.front: Treaties and Executive Agreements
cards.backPlain: Article II gives the President major foreign affairs powers, including making treaties, appointing ambassadors, and serving as Commander in Chief. This topic covers three related areas: 1. Treaties: how they are made, and how they rank versus state law, federal statutes, and the Constitution. 2. Executive agreements: how they are made, their scope, and their legal effect relative to other law. 3. General foreign affairs authority: the President’s primacy in representing the United States in foreign affairs, and limits on other branches directing foreign representatives.
cards.frontPrompt: How does Article II allocate foreign-affairs authority to the President, and what are the main categories of international agreements and their legal effect?
cards.cloze: Article II gives the {{c1::President}} major {{c2::foreign affairs}} powers, including making treaties, appointing ambassadors, and serving as {{c3::Commander in Chief}}. This area covers {{c4::treaties}}, {{c5::executive agreements}}, and the President’s general {{c6::foreign affairs authority}}.
cards.easyContent: Article II gives the President primary authority over U.S. foreign affairs, including making treaties and executive agreements. Treaties and executive agreements are distinct tools with different approval requirements and different ranks in relation to state law, federal statutes, and the Constitution.
cards.mediumContent: Under Article II, the President has primary responsibility for U.S. foreign relations, including negotiating treaties and executive agreements and representing the United States abroad. Treaties require Senate ratification and have a defined hierarchy relative to state law, federal statutes, and the Constitution. Executive agreements require no congressional approval but have more limited status in conflicts with other law. Other branches generally may not direct U.S. foreign representatives.
cards.hardContent: Article II vests the President with core foreign-affairs powers: negotiating treaties, appointing ambassadors, acting as Commander in Chief, and representing the United States in foreign relations. Within this framework, U.S. law recognizes two main types of binding international agreements—treaties and executive agreements—which differ in how they are made and in their rank relative to state law, federal statutes, and the Constitution. In addition, the President, not Congress or the courts, has primary authority to represent the nation in foreign affairs, and other branches generally may not control or direct U.S. foreign representatives such as ambassadors.
cards.mnemonic: T-E-C: Treaties need Two-thirds; Executive agreements need none.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into three children: (1) treaties and conflicts hierarchy; (2) executive agreements and their legal effect; (3) general allocation of foreign-affairs power to the President.
cards.clozeLite: Under {{c1::Article II}}, the {{c2::President has primary foreign-relations authority}}, including {{c3::negotiating treaties}} and {{c4::executive agreements}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 017. Supremacy Clause & Preemption
cards.front: Supremacy Clause & Preemption
cards.backPlain: Under the Supremacy Clause, federal laws trump conflicting state and local laws. 1. Express preemption 1.1 If a federal law expressly provides that it is the exclusive authority in a given area, it preempts state and local laws in that area. 1.2 Express preemption provisions are narrowly construed. 2. Implied preemption 2.1 If a federal law is silent on preemption, it may still implicitly preempt state law in three situations: 2.1.1 Mutual exclusivity: Federal and state laws are mutually exclusive, so complying with both is impossible. States may set stricter requirements if compliance with both federal and state laws is possible. 2.1.2 Obstacle preemption: State law impedes a federal objective. 2.1.3 Field preemption: Congress evidences a clear intent to legislate exclusively and/or to preempt state law. Examples include immigration and bankruptcy law. 2.2 If a state law does not fall into any of the above three situations, it is likely valid under the Supremacy Clause. 3. State constitutions 3.1 State constitutions may provide broader rights and protections than the federal Constitution. 3.2 State constitutions may not provide lesser protections that conflict with the scope of federal constitutional rights and protections.
cards.frontPrompt: How does the Supremacy Clause operate, and what are the rules for express and implied preemption of state law by federal law, including the role of state constitutions?
cards.cloze: Under the {{c1::Supremacy Clause}}, {{c2::federal laws}} trump conflicting {{c3::state and local laws}}. 1. Express preemption 1.1 If a federal law expressly provides that it is the {{c4::exclusive authority in a given area}}, it preempts state and local laws in that area. 1.2 Express preemption provisions are {{c5::narrowly construed}}. 2. Implied preemption 2.1 If a federal law is silent on preemption, it may still implicitly preempt state law in three situations: 2.1.1 {{c6::Mutual exclusivity}}: Federal and state laws are mutually exclusive, so complying with both is impossible. States may set {{c7::stricter requirements}} if compliance with both federal and state laws is possible. 2.1.2 {{c8::Obstacle preemption}}: State law impedes a federal objective. 2.1.3 {{c9::Field preemption}}: Congress evidences a clear intent to legislate exclusively and/or to preempt state law. Examples include {{c10::immigration}} and {{c11::bankruptcy}} law. 2.2 If a state law does not fall into any of the above three situations, it is likely {{c12::valid under the Supremacy Clause}}. 3. State constitutions 3.1 State constitutions may provide {{c13::broader rights and protections}} than the federal Constitution. 3.2 State constitutions may not provide {{c14::lesser protections that conflict with federal constitutional rights}}.
cards.easyContent: The Supremacy Clause makes valid federal law supreme over conflicting state and local law. Federal law can expressly or implicitly preempt state law, but state constitutions may always give more protection than the federal Constitution, not less.
cards.mediumContent: Under the Supremacy Clause, federal laws override conflicting state and local laws. Congress can expressly preempt state law by stating federal law is exclusive in an area, though such clauses are narrowly read. Even without express language, federal law may impliedly preempt state law where (1) federal and state rules are mutually exclusive, (2) state law impedes a federal objective, or (3) Congress shows clear intent to occupy the field, as in immigration or bankruptcy. State constitutions may grant broader individual rights than the federal Constitution but cannot undercut federal constitutional protections.
cards.hardContent: The Supremacy Clause provides that valid federal law prevails over conflicting state and local law. Preemption may be express, where a federal statute states that it is the exclusive authority in a field, which will displace state and local regulation but is narrowly construed. Even if silent on preemption, a federal law may impliedly preempt state law in three situations: (1) mutual exclusivity, where compliance with both federal and state law is impossible, though states may impose stricter standards if both can be met; (2) obstacle preemption, where state law impedes or frustrates federal objectives; and (3) field preemption, where Congress evidences a clear intent to legislate exclusively and occupy the field, as in immigration and bankruptcy. Where none of these apply, the state law is likely valid under the Supremacy Clause. State constitutions may provide greater rights and protections than the federal Constitution but may not provide lesser protections or conflict with the scope of federal constitutional rights.
cards.mnemonic: M-O-F preemption: Mutual exclusivity, Obstacle, Field.
cards.clozeLite: Under the {{c1::Supremacy Clause}}, {{c2::valid federal law overrides conflicting state and local law}} and {{c3::may expressly or impliedly preempt state law}}.
