cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 018. Dormant Commerce Clause
cards.front: Dormant Commerce Clause – Overview and Structure
cards.backPlain: Dormant Commerce Clause (DCC) limits state and local regulation of interstate commerce when Congress has not acted. States may regulate local aspects of interstate commerce only if the regulation is neither discriminatory nor unduly burdensome. Basic DCC framework 1. Invalid state/local laws: A state or local law regulating interstate commerce is invalid if it: - Discriminates against out-of-state competition; - Unduly burdens interstate commerce; or - Regulates wholly out-of-state activity. Examples include laws protecting local businesses, requiring local operations, or limiting access to in-state products. 2. Exceptions that can save a burdensome or discriminatory law: - Necessary to an important, non-economic state interest with no reasonable, non-discriminatory alternatives. - Market participant doctrine (state acting as buyer/seller, employer, or subsidy provider). - Traditional government function where the state favors its own residents. - Clear congressional approval authorizing the burden on interstate commerce.
cards.frontPrompt: What does the Dormant Commerce Clause prohibit, and what are the main categories of exceptions that can save an otherwise invalid state law?
cards.cloze: The {{c1::Dormant Commerce Clause}} limits state and local regulation of {{c2::interstate commerce}} when Congress has not acted. A state or local law is generally invalid if it {{c3::discriminates against out-of-state competition}}, {{c4::unduly burdens interstate commerce}}, or {{c5::regulates wholly out-of-state activity}}, unless an {{c6::exception}} applies (such as a {{c7::necessary important state interest}}, {{c8::market participant}} status, a {{c9::traditional government function}}, or {{c10::clear congressional approval}}).
cards.easyContent: The Dormant Commerce Clause (DCC) limits state and local laws that affect interstate commerce when Congress is silent. A law is generally invalid if it discriminates against out-of-staters, unduly burdens commerce, or regulates activity outside the state, unless it fits within an exception like a necessary important state interest, the state acting as a market participant, a traditional government function, or clear congressional approval.
cards.mediumContent: Under the Dormant Commerce Clause, when Congress has not regulated, states may regulate only if they do not discriminate against or unduly burden interstate commerce, or regulate wholly out-of-state activity. Discriminatory or burdensome laws may survive if they are necessary to an important, non-economic state interest with no reasonable, non-discriminatory alternatives, if the state is acting as a market participant, if the law involves a traditional government function, or if Congress has unmistakably authorized the burden.
cards.hardContent: The Dormant Commerce Clause restricts state and local regulations affecting interstate commerce in the absence of congressional action. A law is invalid if it (1) discriminates against out-of-state competition, (2) imposes an undue burden on interstate commerce, or (3) regulates wholly out-of-state activity, including measures that protect local businesses, require local operations, or limit access to in-state products. Such a law may nonetheless be upheld if it falls within one of the main exceptions: (1) it is necessary to achieve an important, non-economic state interest and there are no reasonable, non-discriminatory alternatives; (2) the state is acting as a market participant in buying or selling goods, hiring labor, or providing subsidies; (3) the law involves a traditional government function, permitting some preference for residents; or (4) Congress has unmistakably authorized the state to impose the burden on interstate commerce.
cards.mnemonic: D-U-O for violations; N-M-T-C for exceptions.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into: (1) basic Dormant Commerce Clause test and invalid regulations, (2) necessary important state interest exception, and (3) market participant, traditional government function, and congressional approval exceptions.
cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::Dormant Commerce Clause}} limits state laws that {{c2::discriminate against}} or {{c3::unduly burden}} interstate commerce, unless an {{c4::exception}} applies.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Article IV Privileges and Immunities Clause
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 019. Article IV Privileges and Immunities Clause
cards.front: Article IV Privileges and Immunities Clause
cards.backPlain: States may not discriminate against non-state residents with respect to certain fundamental rights. The issue arises where a state law is intentionally protectionist and concerns rights relating to important commercial activities or civil liberties. Look for situations where a state intentionally protects its citizens by discriminating against non-state residents. Note: The Article IV Privileges and Immunities Clause protects only citizens; corporations and aliens are not citizens for these purposes. 1. Analysis 1.1 A discriminatory state law will be invalid if it: 1.1.1 Relates to civil liberties or important commercial activities; and 1.1.2 Is not necessary to achieve an important government interest, such as where the law is intentionally protectionist in nature, there is no substantial justification for the discrimination, or less restrictive means are available. 2. Examples 2.1 Valid: Laws requiring higher fees for non-state residents at public golf courses, or higher fees for hunting licenses for non-state residents. 2.2 Invalid: An income tax on non-residents only, limiting bar admission to state residents, or different fees for commercial fishing licenses charged only to non-residents. 3. Fourteenth Amendment Privileges or Immunities Clause 3.1 The Fourteenth Amendment Privileges or Immunities Clause primarily applies to restrictions on the right to interstate travel. 3.2 It is narrowly construed and is unlikely to be a correct answer choice.
cards.frontPrompt: When does the Article IV Privileges and Immunities Clause bar state discrimination against non-residents, and how does it differ from the Fourteenth Amendment Privileges or Immunities Clause?
cards.cloze: States may not {{c1::discriminate against non-state residents}} with respect to certain fundamental rights. The issue arises where a state law is {{c2::intentionally protectionist}} and concerns rights relating to {{c3::important commercial activities}} or {{c4::civil liberties}}. The Article IV Privileges and Immunities Clause protects only {{c5::citizens}}; {{c6::corporations and aliens}} are not citizens for these purposes. 1. Analysis 1.1 A discriminatory state law will be invalid if it: 1.1.1 Relates to {{c7::civil liberties or important commercial activities}}; and 1.1.2 Is not {{c8::necessary to achieve an important government interest}}, such as where the law is intentionally protectionist, there is no substantial justification, or {{c9::less restrictive means}} are available. 2. Examples 2.1 Valid: Laws requiring higher fees for non-state residents at {{c10::public golf courses}} or higher fees for {{c11::hunting licenses}} for non-state residents. 2.2 Invalid: An {{c12::income tax on non-residents only}}, {{c13::limiting bar admission to state residents}}, or {{c14::different fees for commercial fishing licenses}} charged only to non-residents. 3. Fourteenth Amendment Privileges or Immunities Clause 3.1 The Fourteenth Amendment Privileges or Immunities Clause primarily applies to restrictions on the {{c15::right to interstate travel}}. 3.2 It is {{c16::narrowly construed}} and is unlikely to be a {{c17::correct answer choice}}.
cards.easyContent: The Article IV Privileges and Immunities Clause limits states from discriminating against non-residents with respect to important commercial activities and civil liberties unless the state can show the discrimination is necessary to achieve an important government interest. It protects natural citizens only, not corporations or aliens.
cards.mediumContent: Under Article IV, a state generally may not intentionally discriminate against non-residents in favor of its own citizens regarding civil liberties and important commercial activities like earning a livelihood. A discriminatory law is invalid unless it is necessary to achieve an important government interest and there are no less restrictive means. Reasonable recreational distinctions, like higher fees for non-resident hunting or golf, are usually valid. The Fourteenth Amendment Privileges or Immunities Clause, by contrast, is narrow and mainly protects the right to interstate travel, and is seldom the correct basis for invalidating state action.
cards.hardContent: The Article IV Privileges and Immunities Clause prohibits states from discriminating against non-state residents with respect to fundamental rights involving civil liberties and important commercial activities, particularly where the state is acting in an intentionally protectionist manner. The Clause protects only natural citizens, not corporations or aliens. A discriminatory state law will be invalid if it (1) relates to civil liberties or important commercial activities and (2) is not necessary to achieve an important government interest, such as where there is no substantial justification for the discrimination or less restrictive, non-discriminatory alternatives are available. Examples of valid discrimination include modestly higher fees for non-residents for recreational uses like public golf courses or hunting licenses. Invalid examples include imposing an income tax solely on non-residents, limiting bar admission to state residents, or charging higher commercial fishing license fees only to non-residents. The Fourteenth Amendment Privileges or Immunities Clause is distinct; it is narrowly construed, applies primarily to restrictions on the right to interstate travel, and is rarely the correct doctrinal basis on bar exam questions.
cards.mnemonic: Article IV P&I: Protects outsiders’ Civil and Commercial rights.
cards.clozeLite: Article IV {{c1::Privileges and Immunities Clause}} bars state discrimination against {{c2::non-residents}} in {{c3::civil liberties}} and {{c4::important commercial activities}} unless {{c5::necessary to an important government interest}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 020. State Taxation of Interstate Commerce
cards.front: State Taxation of Interstate Commerce
cards.backPlain: State taxes affecting interstate commerce must have a substantial connection to the state and may not discriminate against or unduly burden interstate commerce. A state may not use its tax system to help in-state businesses or discriminate against interstate commerce. 1. Initial analysis 1.1 Ask whether the tax discriminates against interstate commerce. 1.1.1 If yes: The tax is invalid and violates the Dormant Commerce Clause. 1.1.2 If no: Ask whether the burden placed on interstate commerce outweighs the benefits to the state. 2. Three requirements for a valid, non-discriminatory tax on interstate commerce 2.1 Substantial nexus: The tax must have a substantial nexus to the taxing state, meaning the item or activity taxed is based on significant in-state activity. 2.2 Fair apportionment: The tax must be fairly apportioned; the state may tax only the portion of the activity that is connected to the state. 2.3 Fair relationship: The tax must be fairly related to services or benefits provided by the state, meaning that the tax is fairly related to some government service or benefit. 3. Intergovernmental immunity 3.1 States may not directly tax or regulate federal government property or activities without the consent of Congress. 3.2 Exception: Indirect, non-discriminatory taxes are valid if they do not unreasonably burden the federal government, such as a state income tax on a federal employee working in the state, which is permissible because it is not a direct tax on the federal government itself.
cards.frontPrompt: What limits does the Dormant Commerce Clause place on state taxation of interstate commerce, what are the three requirements for a valid non-discriminatory tax, and how does intergovernmental immunity constrain state taxes on the federal government?

A state may not use its tax system to {{c4::help in-state businesses}} or {{c5::discriminate against interstate commerce}}. 1. Initial analysis 1.1 Ask whether the tax {{c6::discriminates against interstate commerce}}. 1.1.1 If yes: The tax is {{c7::invalid}} and violates the {{c8::Dormant Commerce Clause}}. 1.1.2 If no: Ask whether the {{c9::burden}} placed on interstate commerce outweighs the {{c10::benefits}} to the state. 2. Three requirements for a valid, non-discriminatory tax on interstate commerce 2.1 {{c11::Substantial nexus}}: The tax must have a substantial nexus to the taxing state, meaning the item or activity taxed is based on significant in-state activity. 2.2 {{c12::Fair apportionment}}: The tax must be fairly apportioned; the state may tax only the portion of the activity that is connected to the state. 2.3 {{c13::Fair relationship}}: The tax must be fairly related to services or benefits provided by the state, meaning that the tax is fairly related to some government service or benefit. 3. Intergovernmental immunity 3.1 States may not directly {{c14::tax or regulate federal government property or activities}} without the consent of Congress. 3.2 Exception: {{c15::Indirect, non-discriminatory taxes}} are valid if they do not unreasonably burden the federal government, such as a {{c16::state income tax on a federal employee working in the state}}, which is permissible because it is not a direct tax on the federal government itself.
cards.easyContent: A state tax on interstate commerce cannot discriminate against or unduly burden interstate trade and must have a substantial connection to the state. A valid non-discriminatory tax requires substantial nexus, fair apportionment, and a fair relationship to state-provided benefits, and states generally cannot directly tax the federal government.
cards.mediumContent: Under the Dormant Commerce Clause, a state may not structure its tax system to favor in-state businesses or discriminate against interstate commerce. First, ask whether the tax discriminates against interstate commerce; if it does, it is invalid. If it does not, the tax is valid only if it has a substantial nexus to the state, is fairly apportioned so the state taxes only its fair share of the activity, and is fairly related to services or benefits provided by the state. Separately, intergovernmental immunity bars states from directly taxing or regulating federal property or activities without congressional consent, though indirect, non-discriminatory taxes like state income tax on federal employees are allowed.
cards.hardContent: State taxes that affect interstate commerce are constrained by the Dormant Commerce Clause. They must be based on a substantial connection to the taxing state and may not discriminate against or unduly burden interstate commerce, nor be used to aid in-state businesses over out-of-state competitors. The analysis begins by asking whether the tax discriminates against interstate commerce; if so, it is invalid under the Dormant Commerce Clause. If the tax is facially non-discriminatory, it will be upheld only if three requirements are met: (1) substantial nexus, meaning the taxed item or activity has significant in-state activity; (2) fair apportionment, meaning the state taxes only the portion of the activity fairly attributable to the state; and (3) a fair relationship between the tax and the services or benefits provided by the state. In addition, under intergovernmental immunity, states may not directly tax or regulate federal government property or activities without congressional consent. However, indirect, non-discriminatory taxes that do not unreasonably burden the federal government—such as a state income tax imposed on federal employees working in the state—are permissible.
cards.mnemonic: Valid tax needs NAR: Nexus, Apportionment, Relationship; never tax Uncle Sam directly.
cards.clozeLite: A state tax on {{c1::interstate commerce}} cannot {{c2::discriminate against or unduly burden}} such commerce and must have {{c3::substantial nexus}}, {{c4::fair apportionment}}, and a {{c5::fair relationship to state-provided benefits}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 021. Governmental Action Requirement
cards.front: Governmental Action Requirement
cards.backPlain: The Constitution applies only to governmental action (federal, state, or local). Private conduct generally does not have to comply with the Constitution, subject to the exceptions below. 1. Exceptions (the Constitution will apply to private conduct where): 1.1 Exclusive public function: a private entity performs a task traditionally and exclusively performed by the government (narrow exception). This arises only if a private entity exclusively operates a governmental function (e.g., private prisons, running elections). 1.2 Significant state involvement (entanglement): the government affirmatively authorizes, encourages, or facilitates private conduct. 1.2.1 The state must affirmatively approve or validate the private conduct; merely permitting it is insufficient. 1.2.2 Examples of state action: a court enforces a racially restrictive covenant; the state provides books to private schools that racially discriminate. 1.2.3 Examples of no state action: the government grants a liquor license to a racially discriminatory private club; a private school receiving government funds fires a teacher over speech. 2. Indirect regulation of private conduct: Congress may indirectly regulate private conduct through the Commerce Clause (if the conduct affects interstate commerce) or through the 13th Amendment (which enables Congress to pass legislation enforcing the 13th Amendment’s ban on slavery).
cards.frontPrompt: When does the constitutional governmental action requirement apply to private conduct, and what are the main exceptions?
cards.cloze: The {{c1::Constitution}} applies only to {{c2::governmental action}} (federal, state, or local). Private conduct generally does not have to comply with the Constitution, subject to the exceptions below. 1. Exceptions (the Constitution will apply to private conduct where): 1.1 {{c3::Exclusive public function}}: a private entity performs a task {{c4::traditionally and exclusively performed by the government}} (narrow exception). This arises only if a private entity exclusively operates a governmental function (e.g., private prisons, running elections). 1.2 {{c5::Significant state involvement}} ({{c6::entanglement}}): the government affirmatively authorizes, encourages, or facilitates private conduct. 1.2.1 The state must {{c7::affirmatively approve or validate}} the private conduct; merely permitting it is insufficient. 1.2.2 Examples of state action: a court enforces a {{c8::racially restrictive covenant}}; the state provides books to private schools that {{c9::racially discriminate}}. 1.2.3 Examples of no state action: the government grants a {{c10::liquor license to a racially discriminatory private club}}; a private school receiving government funds fires a teacher over speech. 2. Indirect regulation of private conduct: Congress may indirectly regulate private conduct through the {{c11::Commerce Clause}} (if the conduct affects interstate commerce) or through the {{c12::13th Amendment}} (which enables Congress to pass legislation enforcing the 13th Amendment’s ban on slavery).
cards.easyContent: The Constitution generally binds only government actors, not private parties, except when private entities perform exclusive public functions or are significantly entangled with the state.
cards.mediumContent: The Constitution applies only to governmental action, but will apply to private conduct when a private entity performs a traditionally and exclusively governmental function, or when the government is significantly involved in, authorizes, or facilitates the private conduct. Mere permission is not enough, and courts use examples (e.g., enforcing racially restrictive covenants) to find state action. Congress can also reach private conduct indirectly under the Commerce Clause or by enforcing the 13th Amendment.
cards.hardContent: The Constitution applies only to governmental action at the federal, state, or local level. Private conduct generally is not subject to constitutional limits. Exceptions: (1) Exclusive public function—where a private entity performs a task traditionally and exclusively performed by the government (a narrow category, such as operating prisons or running elections). (2) Significant state involvement (entanglement)—where the government affirmatively authorizes, encourages, or facilitates private conduct; the state must affirmatively approve or validate the conduct, and mere permission is insufficient. Examples of state action include courts enforcing racially restrictive covenants and states supplying books to racially discriminatory private schools. There is no state action where the state merely grants a liquor license to a discriminatory private club or where a private school receiving government funds fires a teacher over speech. Separately, Congress may indirectly regulate private conduct via the Commerce Clause (for activities affecting interstate commerce) and through legislation enforcing the 13th Amendment’s ban on slavery.
cards.mnemonic: GAS: Government, Acts like government, Significant entanglement.
cards.clozeLite: The Constitution applies only to {{c1::governmental action}}, but can reach {{c2::private conduct}} doing {{c3::exclusive public functions}} or with {{c4::significant state involvement}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 022. Bill of Rights
cards.front: Bill of Rights
cards.backPlain: Application to federal and state governments: The Bill of Rights (BoR) applies directly only to the federal government. Certain provisions of the BoR apply to state and local governments through the incorporation doctrine. 1. Incorporation: the Supreme Court has held specific BoR provisions applicable to the states by incorporating them into the 14th Amendment Due Process (DP) Clause. Most BoR provisions are now incorporated. 2. Exceptions: certain provisions of the BoR are not incorporated by the 14th Amendment to the states, including: 2.1 3rd Amendment right not to have soldiers quartered in homes; 2.2 5th Amendment right to grand jury indictment in criminal cases; and 2.3 7th Amendment right to jury trial in civil cases. 3. Reverse incorporation: the 14th Amendment Equal Protection Clause does not apply directly to the federal government, but has been held to apply to the federal government through the 5th Amendment DP Clause.
cards.frontPrompt: How does the Bill of Rights apply to the federal versus state governments, and what are the main incorporation and reverse-incorporation rules?
cards.cloze: Application to federal and state governments: The {{c1::Bill of Rights}} ({{c2::BoR}}) applies directly only to the {{c3::federal government}}. Certain provisions of the BoR apply to state and local governments through the {{c4::incorporation doctrine}}. 1. Incorporation: the Supreme Court has held specific BoR provisions applicable to the states by incorporating them into the {{c5::14th Amendment Due Process (DP) Clause}}. Most BoR provisions are now incorporated. 2. Exceptions: certain provisions of the BoR are not incorporated by the 14th Amendment to the states, including: 2.1 {{c6::3rd Amendment}} right not to have soldiers quartered in homes; 2.2 {{c7::5th Amendment}} right to {{c8::grand jury indictment in criminal cases}}; and 2.3 {{c9::7th Amendment}} right to {{c10::jury trial in civil cases}}. 3. Reverse incorporation: the {{c11::14th Amendment Equal Protection Clause}} does not apply directly to the federal government, but has been held to apply to the federal government through the {{c12::5th Amendment Due Process Clause}}.
cards.easyContent: The Bill of Rights directly limits only the federal government, but most of its protections apply to state and local governments through incorporation into the 14th Amendment Due Process Clause, with a few specific exceptions.
cards.mediumContent: The Bill of Rights applies directly only to the federal government. However, most of its guarantees bind the states through selective incorporation into the 14th Amendment Due Process Clause. Not incorporated are the 3rd Amendment quartering of soldiers, the 5th Amendment right to a grand jury indictment in criminal cases, and the 7th Amendment right to a jury trial in civil cases. Equal protection limits on the federal government come via "reverse incorporation" through the 5th Amendment Due Process Clause.
cards.hardContent: The Bill of Rights applies directly only to the federal government. Through the incorporation doctrine, the Supreme Court has made most BoR provisions applicable to the states by incorporating them into the 14th Amendment Due Process Clause. However, some provisions remain unincorporated, including the 3rd Amendment right not to have soldiers quartered in homes, the 5th Amendment right to grand jury indictment in criminal cases, and the 7th Amendment right to a jury trial in civil cases. Additionally, the 14th Amendment Equal Protection Clause does not by its terms apply to the federal government, but equal protection principles have been applied to the federal government via "reverse incorporation" through the 5th Amendment Due Process Clause.
cards.mnemonic: Most rights go down, but "3-5-7" stay mostly federal only.
cards.clozeLite: Most {{c1::Bill of Rights}} protections bind states via {{c2::selective incorporation}} into the {{c3::14th Amendment Due Process Clause}}, but not {{c4::3rd, 5th grand jury, or 7th civil jury}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Enforcement of Post Civil War Amendments
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 023. Enforcement of Post Civil War Amendments
cards.front: Enforcement of Post Civil War Amendments
cards.backPlain: The 13th, 14th, and 15th Amendments each contain an enabling clause authorizing Congress to adopt appropriate legislation to enforce the rights these Amendments guarantee. 1. 13th Amendment: prohibition on slavery and involuntary servitude. Congress can adopt legislation prohibiting almost any private racial discrimination that constitutes a badge or incident of slavery. For example, Congress can pass a law prohibiting employers from discriminating in hiring on the basis of race. There is no state action requirement: the 13th Amendment applies to private action by its terms. 2. 14th Amendment: prohibits states from depriving any person of life, liberty, or property without due process and equal protection. Congress can adopt legislation to enforce existing rights and guarantees, but may not expand existing, or create new, constitutional rights. 2.1 Congress must point to a history and pattern of state violations of rights; and 2.2 The legislation must be congruent and proportional to remedying the violation. 3. 15th Amendment: prohibits state and federal governments from denying any citizen the right to vote on the basis of race or color. These powers can be limited by other constitutional principles. The 15th Amendment is much less likely to appear on the bar exam.
cards.frontPrompt: What enforcement powers do Congress’s enabling clauses under the 13th, 14th, and 15th Amendments provide, and what limits apply, especially under the 14th Amendment?
cards.cloze: The {{c1::13th, 14th, and 15th Amendments}} each contain an {{c2::enabling clause}} authorizing Congress to adopt appropriate legislation to enforce the rights these Amendments guarantee. 1. {{c3::13th Amendment}}: prohibition on {{c4::slavery and involuntary servitude}}. Congress can adopt legislation prohibiting almost any {{c5::private racial discrimination}} that constitutes a {{c6::badge or incident of slavery}}. For example, Congress can pass a law prohibiting employers from discriminating in hiring on the basis of race. There is {{c7::no state action requirement}}: the 13th Amendment applies to private action by its terms. 2. {{c8::14th Amendment}}: prohibits states from depriving any person of life, liberty, or property without {{c9::due process}} and {{c10::equal protection}}. Congress can adopt legislation to {{c11::enforce existing rights and guarantees}}, but may not {{c12::expand existing or create new constitutional rights}}. 2.1 Congress must {{c13::point to a history and pattern of state violations of rights}}; and 2.2 The legislation must be {{c14::congruent and proportional}} to remedying the violation. 3. {{c15::15th Amendment}}: prohibits state and federal governments from denying any citizen the {{c16::right to vote on the basis of race or color}}. These powers can be limited by other constitutional principles. The 15th Amendment is much less likely to appear on the bar exam.
cards.easyContent: The 13th, 14th, and 15th Amendments each have enforcement clauses giving Congress power to pass laws enforcing their guarantees, but only the 13th reaches private conduct directly, while the 14th and 15th are primarily aimed at state action with limits on how far Congress can go.
cards.mediumContent: Congress’s enforcement power under the 13th Amendment allows it to ban slavery and involuntary servitude and to prohibit private racial discrimination that is a badge or incident of slavery, with no state action requirement. Under the 14th Amendment, Congress may pass laws to enforce existing due process and equal protection rights, but it cannot create new rights; any such law must address a history and pattern of state violations and be congruent and proportional to the harm. The 15th Amendment empowers Congress to prevent state and federal denial of the vote based on race or color, subject to other constitutional limits.
cards.hardContent: The 13th, 14th, and 15th Amendments each contain enabling clauses authorizing Congress to enact appropriate enforcement legislation. Under the 13th Amendment, which bans slavery and involuntary servitude, Congress may prohibit virtually any private racial discrimination that constitutes a badge or incident of slavery, and the Amendment operates directly on private actors with no state action requirement. The 14th Amendment prohibits states from depriving any person of life, liberty, or property without due process or equal protection; Congress may enforce these existing guarantees but may not expand or create new constitutional rights. Legislation under Section 5 of the 14th Amendment must respond to a documented history and pattern of state violations and must be congruent and proportional to preventing or remedying those violations. The 15th Amendment forbids state and federal governments from denying the right to vote on account of race or color and authorizes Congress to protect that right, though such legislation remains subject to other constitutional limits. The 15th Amendment’s enforcement issues are less commonly tested.
cards.mnemonic: "13 hits private badges; 14 needs congruent, proportional state-fixing; 15 guards race voting."
cards.clozeLite: Under the {{c1::13th Amendment}}, Congress can reach {{c2::private racial discrimination}}. Under the {{c3::14th}}, laws must be {{c4::congruent and proportional}} to {{c5::state}} violations.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 024. Levels of Scrutiny
cards.front: Levels of Scrutiny
cards.backPlain: Courts use three tests to analyze the constitutionality of government acts under substantive due process and equal protection. 1. Rational basis: a law will be upheld if it is rationally related to a legitimate government purpose. 1.1 Any conceivable legitimate purpose suffices, regardless of the actual purpose of the law. 1.2 A law will almost always be upheld under rational basis review unless it is completely irrational or arbitrary. 1.3 Burden of proof: the challenger bears the burden of proof. 2. Intermediate scrutiny: a law will be upheld if it is substantially related to an important government purpose. 2.1 The government’s goal must be important. 2.2 Courts look at the actual reason the law was enacted. 2.3 Burden of proof: the government bears the burden of proof. 3. Strict scrutiny: a law will be upheld if it is necessary to achieve a compelling government interest. 3.1 The government must show there are no less restrictive or burdensome means of achieving its goal. 3.2 Courts look at the actual reason the law was enacted. 3.3 Burden of proof: the government bears the burden of proof.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the three constitutional levels of scrutiny (rational basis, intermediate scrutiny, and strict scrutiny), and what does each require?
cards.cloze: Courts use {{c1::three tests}} to analyze the constitutionality of government acts under {{c2::substantive due process}} and {{c3::equal protection}}. 1. {{c4::Rational basis}}: a law will be upheld if it is {{c5::rationally related}} to a {{c6::legitimate government purpose}}. 1.1 Any {{c7::conceivable}} legitimate purpose suffices, regardless of the actual purpose of the law. 1.2 A law will almost always be upheld under rational basis review unless it is completely {{c8::irrational or arbitrary}}. 1.3 Burden of proof: the {{c9::challenger}} bears the burden of proof. 2. {{c10::Intermediate scrutiny}}: a law will be upheld if it is {{c11::substantially related}} to an {{c12::important government purpose}}. 2.1 The government’s goal must be {{c13::important}}. 2.2 Courts look at the {{c14::actual reason}} the law was enacted. 2.3 Burden of proof: the {{c15::government}} bears the burden of proof. 3. {{c16::Strict scrutiny}}: a law will be upheld if it is {{c17::necessary}} to achieve a {{c18::compelling government interest}}. 3.1 The government must show there are {{c19::no less restrictive or burdensome means}} of achieving its goal. 3.2 Courts look at the {{c20::actual reason}} the law was enacted. 3.3 Burden of proof: the {{c21::government}} bears the burden of proof.
cards.easyContent: Courts review constitutional challenges using three levels of scrutiny: rational basis (rationally related to a legitimate purpose), intermediate scrutiny (substantially related to an important purpose), and strict scrutiny (necessary to a compelling interest).
cards.mediumContent: Under rational basis review, a law is upheld if it is rationally related to any conceivable legitimate government purpose; the challenger bears the burden and the law is usually upheld. Under intermediate scrutiny, the law must be substantially related to an important government purpose, courts look at the actual purpose, and the government bears the burden. Under strict scrutiny, the law must be necessary to achieve a compelling government interest, using no less restrictive means, with the government again bearing the burden and courts examining the real purpose.
cards.hardContent: Courts apply three levels of scrutiny to government action under substantive due process and equal protection. Rational basis: a law will be upheld if it is rationally related to a legitimate government purpose; any conceivable legitimate objective suffices, the law is struck down only if completely irrational or arbitrary, and the challenger bears the burden of proof. Intermediate scrutiny: a law is upheld if it is substantially related to an important government purpose; the government’s goal must be important, courts evaluate the government’s actual purpose, and the burden of proof is on the government. Strict scrutiny: a law survives only if it is necessary to achieve a compelling government interest; the government must show there are no less restrictive or burdensome means of achieving its objective, courts look to the actual purpose, and the government bears the burden of proof.
cards.mnemonic: RIL: Rational–Legitimate, Intermediate–Important, Strict–Life-or-death compelling.
cards.clozeLite: Under {{c1::rational basis}}, the law is upheld if {{c2::rationally related to any conceivable legitimate purpose}}. {{c3::Intermediate scrutiny}} requires a law be {{c4::substantially related to an important purpose}}. {{c5::Strict scrutiny}} requires a law be {{c6::necessary to achieve a compelling interest with no less restrictive means}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 025. Procedural Due Process
cards.front: Procedural Due Process
cards.backPlain: A fair process (e.g., notice, hearings) is required for the government to take or deprive a person's life, liberty, or property. Due process rights arise only if the government acts to deprive an individual, not when the government acts generally. 1. Analysis: 1.1 Has there been a deprivation of life, liberty, or property? 1.1.1 Liberty deprivation exists when there is a loss of significant freedom of action or a freedom provided by the Constitution or statute (e.g., institutionalization, government restriction of fundamental rights). 1.1.2 Property deprivation exists when there is a legitimate claim or entitlement to a benefit under law that goes unfulfilled (e.g., public school attendance, welfare). 1.2 What procedures are required? (determined by balancing): 1.2.1 Importance of the individual interest involved; 1.2.2 Value of additional or substitute procedural safeguards to that interest; against 1.2.3 The government’s interest (i.e., fiscal or administrative efficiency). Usually, fair procedures, an unbiased decision-maker, and notice of the government’s action will be required. 2. Examples where procedural due process requirements arise include: terminating welfare or social security benefits; separating a child from parents; punitive damages awards; and determining enemy combatant status for citizens captured in foreign countries.
cards.frontPrompt: How do you analyze a procedural due process claim, including what counts as a deprivation of life, liberty, or property and how you determine what procedures are required?

Due process rights arise only if the government {{c3::acts to deprive an individual}}, not when the government acts generally. 1. Analysis: 1.1 Has there been a deprivation of life, liberty, or property? 1.1.1 {{c4::Liberty deprivation}} exists when there is a loss of {{c5::significant freedom of action}} or a freedom provided by the {{c6::Constitution or statute}} (e.g., institutionalization, government restriction of fundamental rights). 1.1.2 {{c7::Property deprivation}} exists when there is a {{c8::legitimate claim or entitlement}} to a benefit under law that goes unfulfilled (e.g., public school attendance, welfare). 1.2 What procedures are required? (determined by balancing): 1.2.1 {{c9::Importance of the individual interest}} involved; 1.2.2 {{c10::Value of additional or substitute procedural safeguards}} to that interest; against 1.2.3 The {{c11::government’s interest}} (i.e., fiscal or administrative efficiency). Usually, fair procedures, an {{c12::unbiased decision-maker}}, and {{c13::notice}} of the government’s action will be required. 2. Examples where procedural due process requirements arise include: {{c14::terminating welfare or social security benefits}}; {{c15::separating a child from parents}}; {{c16::punitive damages awards}}; and determining {{c17::enemy combatant status}} for citizens captured in foreign countries.
cards.easyContent: Procedural due process requires fair procedures, like notice and a hearing before an unbiased decision-maker, when the government seeks to deprive an individual of life, liberty, or property.
cards.mediumContent: To analyze procedural due process, first ask whether there is a deprivation of life, liberty, or property—liberty means a significant loss of freedom or a statutory or constitutional freedom; property means a legitimate claim or entitlement, such as public education or welfare benefits. If there is a deprivation, determine what procedures are required by balancing the importance of the individual interest, the value of additional safeguards, and the government’s fiscal and administrative interests. Common contexts include cutting off benefits, removing children from parents, punitive damages, and enemy combatant determinations.
cards.hardContent: Procedural due process requires that the government provide fair procedures—typically notice and an opportunity to be heard before an unbiased decision-maker—when it seeks to deprive a person of life, liberty, or property. The doctrine applies only when the government acts to deprive an individual, not through generally applicable laws alone. First, ask whether there is a deprivation: a liberty deprivation arises from a loss of significant freedom of action or a freedom guaranteed by the Constitution or statute (e.g., institutionalization, restrictions on fundamental rights); a property deprivation arises when an individual has a legitimate claim or entitlement to a government benefit under law (such as public school attendance or welfare) that goes unfulfilled. Second, determine the required procedures using a balancing test weighing: (1) the importance of the individual interest; (2) the value of additional or substitute procedural safeguards; and (3) the government’s interest in fiscal and administrative efficiency. Procedural due process protections frequently arise in contexts such as terminating welfare or social security benefits, separating a child from parents, awarding punitive damages, and determining enemy combatant status for citizens captured abroad.
cards.mnemonic: D + B: find Deprivation, then Balance interests and procedures.
cards.clozeLite: Procedural due process applies when the {{c1::government}} seeks to deprive {{c2::life, liberty, or property}}; if so, required procedures are set by a {{c3::balancing test}} of {{c4::individual interest}}, {{c5::value of safeguards}}, and {{c6::government burdens}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 026. Substantive Due Process
cards.front: Substantive Due Process
cards.backPlain: Substantive due process involves determining whether the government has adequate reasons for depriving a person of life, liberty, or property. It encompasses both fundamental and non-fundamental rights. 1. Applicable levels of scrutiny 1.1. If a non-fundamental right is burdened, the court applies rational basis review. 1.2. If a fundamental right is burdened, the court applies strict scrutiny. 2. Substantive due process vs. Equal Protection Clause (EP) 2.1. Similarities: Under both substantive due process and equal protection, a court reviews the substance of the law, not the procedures used to enact or enforce it. 2.2. Differences: Substantive due process usually involves laws affecting the rights of all persons to engage in some conduct or activity. Equal protection usually involves laws treating certain people or classes of people differently than others, often based on some trait.
cards.frontPrompt: What does substantive due process protect, what levels of scrutiny apply, and how does it differ from equal protection analysis?
cards.cloze: {{c1::Substantive due process}} involves determining whether the government has adequate reasons for depriving a person of {{c2::life, liberty, or property}}. It encompasses both {{c3::fundamental}} and {{c4::non-fundamental}} rights. 1. Applicable levels of scrutiny 1.1. If a {{c5::non-fundamental right}} is burdened, the court applies {{c6::rational basis}} review. 1.2. If a {{c7::fundamental right}} is burdened, the court applies {{c8::strict scrutiny}}. 2. Substantive due process vs. Equal Protection Clause (EP) 2.1. Similarities: Under both {{c1::substantive due process}} and {{c9::equal protection}}, a court reviews the {{c10::substance of the law, not the procedures}} used to enact or enforce it. 2.2. Differences: {{c1::Substantive due process}} usually involves laws affecting the rights of {{c11::all persons}} to engage in some conduct or activity. {{c9::Equal protection}} usually involves laws {{c12::treating certain people or classes of people differently}} than others, often based on some trait.
cards.easyContent: Substantive due process asks whether the government has sufficient justification to deprive life, liberty, or property, using strict scrutiny for fundamental rights and rational basis for non-fundamental rights.
cards.mediumContent: Substantive due process examines whether the government has adequate reasons for depriving life, liberty, or property. If a fundamental right is burdened, strict scrutiny applies; if a non-fundamental right is burdened, rational basis applies. While both substantive due process and equal protection review the substance of laws, SDP generally concerns laws affecting everyone’s ability to engage in conduct, whereas EP concerns laws that treat certain groups differently.
cards.hardContent: Substantive due process involves determining whether the government has adequate reasons for depriving a person of life, liberty, or property and applies to both fundamental and non-fundamental rights. If a non-fundamental right is burdened, the court applies rational basis review; if a fundamental right is burdened, the court applies strict scrutiny. Under both substantive due process and the Equal Protection Clause, courts review the substance of the law rather than the procedures used to enact or enforce it. Substantive due process usually involves laws affecting the rights of all persons to engage in certain conduct or activities, whereas equal protection usually involves laws that treat certain people or classes of people differently than others, often based on some trait.
cards.mnemonic: SDP = Substance for all; EP = Equality among groups.
cards.clozeLite: Substantive due process asks if the {{c1::government has adequate reasons}} to {{c2::deprive life, liberty, or property}} and uses {{c3::strict scrutiny for fundamental rights}} but {{c4::rational basis for non-fundamental rights}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Economic Rights and the Contract Clause
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 027. Economic Rights and the Contract Clause
cards.front: Economic Rights and the Contract Clause – Overview
cards.backPlain: 1. Economic rights – overview 1.1. Laws affecting economic rights (economic liberties) are generally reviewed under the rational basis test. 1.2. The Constitution provides only minimal protection for economic liberties; the government almost always wins under rational basis for economic regulation. 1.3. A higher level of protection for economic interests may arise under specific provisions such as the Takings Clause or the Contract Clause. 2. Contract Clause – overview 2.1. The Contract Clause limits state and local interference with existing contracts. 2.2. It applies only to state or local—not federal—impairment of existing contractual obligations, including government obligations. 2.3. Different levels of scrutiny apply to state interference with private contracts versus interference with the state’s own (government) contracts.
cards.frontPrompt: How does the Constitution generally protect economic rights, and what is the basic role of the Contract Clause with respect to state or local interference with existing contracts?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Economic rights}} – overview 1.1. Laws affecting economic rights (economic liberties) are generally reviewed under the {{c2::rational basis}} test. 1.2. The Constitution provides only {{c3::minimal protection}} for economic liberties; the government almost always wins under {{c2::rational basis}} review of economic regulation. 1.3. A higher level of protection for economic interests may arise under specific provisions such as the {{c4::Takings Clause}} or the {{c5::Contract Clause}}. 2. {{c5::Contract Clause}} – overview 2.1. The Contract Clause limits {{c6::state and local}} interference with {{c7::existing contracts}}. 2.2. It applies only to {{c6::state or local}}—not {{c8::federal}}—impairment of existing contractual obligations, including government obligations. 2.3. Different levels of scrutiny apply to state interference with {{c9::private}} contracts versus interference with {{c10::government}} contracts.
cards.easyContent: Economic rights generally get only rational basis review, so economic regulations usually stand unless a specific protection like the Takings Clause or Contract Clause is triggered. The Contract Clause limits state and local—not federal—impairment of existing private and government contracts, with different scrutiny for each.
cards.mediumContent: Economic liberties receive minimal constitutional protection and are typically reviewed under rational basis; economic regulations almost always survive unless a more specific protection like the Takings Clause or Contract Clause applies. The Contract Clause restricts only state and local interference with existing contractual obligations, including the government’s own contracts. Different levels of scrutiny apply to interference with private contracts versus interference with government contracts.
cards.hardContent: Economic rights (economic liberties) are generally reviewed under the rational basis test, under which the Constitution affords only minimal protection and the government almost always prevails in defending economic regulation. Higher protection for economic interests may arise under specific provisions like the Takings Clause or the Contract Clause. The Contract Clause limits only state and local—not federal—impairment of existing contractual obligations, including obligations under government contracts, and it uses different levels of scrutiny depending on whether the state is impairing private contracts or its own (government) contracts.
cards.mnemonic: Rational until TAKES or CONTRACTS kick in.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into (1) overview of economic rights and Contract Clause; (2) economic rights and rational basis; (3) Contract Clause basics; (4) private contract impairment test; (5) government contract impairment test.
cards.clozeLite: Economic liberties usually get {{c1::rational basis}}; more protection may come from {{c2::Takings Clause}} or {{c3::Contract Clause}}, which limits {{c4::state and local}} interference with {{c5::existing contracts}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Ex Post Facto & Bills of Attainder
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 028. Ex Post Facto & Bills of Attainder
cards.front: Ex Post Facto & Bills of Attainder
cards.backPlain: The Constitution prohibits state and federal governments from passing retroactive laws, which generally involve either ex post facto laws or bills of attainder. 1. Ex Post Facto Clause 1.1. The Ex Post Facto Clause prohibits ex post facto laws. 1.2. Test: A law is an ex post facto law if it either: 1.2.1. criminally punishes conduct that was lawful when done; 1.2.2. increases punishment for a crime after it has been committed; or 1.2.3. reduces the burden required to convict a person for a crime after it has been committed. 1.3. The Ex Post Facto Clause does not apply to civil liability; retroactive civil legislation need only satisfy rational basis review. 2. Bill of attainder 2.1. A bill of attainder is a legislative act that punishes specific individuals or identifiable group members without a judicial trial. 2.2. Bills of attainder are prohibited under the Constitution.
cards.frontPrompt: What types of retroactive criminal laws are forbidden by the Ex Post Facto Clause, and what is a prohibited bill of attainder?
cards.cloze: The Constitution prohibits state and federal governments from passing {{c1::retroactive laws}}, which generally involve either {{c2::ex post facto laws}} or {{c3::bills of attainder}}. 1. {{c2::Ex Post Facto Clause}} 1.1. The Ex Post Facto Clause prohibits {{c2::ex post facto laws}}. 1.2. Test: A law is an ex post facto law if it either: 1.2.1. {{c4::criminally punishes conduct that was lawful when done}}; 1.2.2. {{c5::increases punishment}} for a crime after it has been committed; or 1.2.3. {{c6::reduces the burden required to convict}} a person for a crime after it has been committed. 1.3. The Ex Post Facto Clause does not apply to {{c7::civil liability}}; retroactive civil legislation need only satisfy {{c8::rational basis}} review. 2. {{c3::Bill of attainder}} 2.1. A bill of attainder is a {{c9::legislative act}} that {{c10::punishes specific individuals or identifiable groups without a judicial trial}}. 2.2. {{c3::Bills of attainder}} are {{c11::prohibited under the Constitution}}.
cards.easyContent: The Ex Post Facto Clause forbids retroactive criminal laws that newly punish past lawful conduct, increase punishment, or lower the burden of conviction, and it does not apply to civil laws. Bills of attainder are legislative punishments of named individuals or groups without a trial and are unconstitutional.
cards.mediumContent: The Constitution bars state and federal ex post facto laws and bills of attainder. A criminal law is ex post facto if it makes past lawful conduct criminal, increases the punishment for a past crime, or lowers the burden of proof for conviction after the crime was committed. The Ex Post Facto Clause does not cover civil liability, where retroactive laws need only satisfy rational basis review. A bill of attainder is a legislative act that inflicts punishment on specific persons or identifiable groups without a judicial trial, and such bills are prohibited.
cards.hardContent: The Constitution prohibits both state and federal governments from enacting retroactive laws in two main forms: ex post facto laws and bills of attainder. The Ex Post Facto Clause forbids criminal laws that retroactively punish conduct that was lawful when performed, increase the punishment for a crime after it has been committed, or reduce the burden required to convict someone after the crime was committed. The Clause does not apply to civil liability; retroactive civil legislation is reviewed under rational basis. A bill of attainder is a legislative act that targets specific individuals or identifiable groups for punishment without a judicial trial, and such bills of attainder are unconstitutional.
cards.mnemonic: Ex Post Facto: New Crime, More Time, Easier Time; Bill as Judge punishes without trial.
cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::Ex Post Facto Clause}} forbids {{c2::retroactive criminal laws}} that {{c3::create new crimes}}, {{c4::increase punishment}}, or {{c5::lower the burden of proof}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 029. Takings Clause & Eminent Domain
cards.front: Takings Clause & Eminent Domain – Overview
cards.backPlain: The 5th Amendment Takings Clause prohibits the government from taking private property for public use without providing just compensation to the owner and/or occupant. The Clause applies to government action that significantly damages property or its use. Courts generally use a three-part framework: 1. Has there been a taking (possessory or regulatory, including severe economic impact on use or value)? 2. Is the taking for public use (broadly defined as rationally related to a legitimate public purpose)? 3. Has just compensation been paid (measured by the owner’s loss, usually fair market value at the time of the taking)?
cards.frontPrompt: What are the basic requirements of the 5th Amendment Takings Clause, and what are the three main questions to analyze a taking?
cards.cloze: The {{c1::5th Amendment Takings Clause}} prohibits the government from taking {{c2::private property}} for {{c3::public use}} without providing {{c4::just compensation}}. Courts ask three main questions: (1) {{c5::Has there been a taking (possessory or regulatory)?}} (2) {{c6::Is the taking for public use (broadly defined)?}} (3) {{c7::Has just compensation (owner’s loss, usually FMV) been paid?}}
cards.easyContent: The Takings Clause bars the government from taking private property for public use without just compensation. Analyze by asking: (1) is there a taking; (2) is it for public use; and (3) has just compensation been paid.
cards.mediumContent: Under the 5th Amendment Takings Clause, the government may not take private property for public use without just compensation. The analysis proceeds in three steps: first, determine whether there has been a taking (physical or regulatory). Second, determine whether the taking is for public use, which is broadly defined as any taking rationally related to a legitimate public purpose. Third, determine whether the government has paid just compensation, measured by the owner’s loss, usually the fair market value at the time of the taking.
cards.hardContent: The 5th Amendment Takings Clause applies when government action significantly damages private property or its use. The analysis has three components: (1) whether there has been a taking, including physical occupation or regulations that go so far as to effectively appropriate the property; (2) whether the taking is for public use, which is satisfied by any rational relation to a legitimate public purpose; and (3) whether the government has provided just compensation, generally the owner’s loss measured by fair market value at the time of the taking.
cards.mnemonic: TPJ: Taking, Public use, Just compensation — analyze in that order.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into four children: (1) definition and types of takings; (2) regulatory takings standards (total vs. near-total loss and factors); (3) public use requirement; and (4) just compensation measurement.
cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::5th Amendment Takings Clause}} bars taking {{c2::private property}} for {{c3::public use}} without {{c4::just compensation}}; ask if {{c5::taking, public use, and compensation}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Fundamental Rights and the Right to Privacy
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 030. Fundamental Rights and the Right to Privacy
cards.front: Fundamental Rights and the Right to Privacy – Overview
cards.backPlain: Fundamental rights are protected under both 5th Amendment substantive due process and 14th Amendment equal protection. Substantive due process applies if a right is denied to all; equal protection applies if a right is denied to some but not others. Government actions that do not implicate a fundamental right receive only rational basis review. Many core fundamental rights are grouped under an inferred right to privacy, including rights related to marriage, procreation, and family life, as well as certain autonomy interests (e.g., abortion, private consensual sexual conduct, and refusing medical treatment). In addition, the rights to vote and to travel are fundamental and are usually analyzed under the Equal Protection Clause.
cards.frontPrompt: How are fundamental rights generally protected under substantive due process and equal protection, and what are the major categories of fundamental rights (privacy, voting, and travel)?
cards.cloze: Fundamental rights are protected under both {{c1::5th Amendment substantive due process}} and {{c2::14th Amendment equal protection}}. {{c1::Substantive due process}} applies if a right is denied to {{c3::all}}; {{c2::equal protection}} applies if a right is denied to {{c4::some but not others}}. Government actions that do not implicate a fundamental right receive only {{c5::rational basis}} review. Major categories of fundamental rights include: (1) an inferred {{c6::right to privacy}} covering marriage, procreation, and family-related rights; (2) certain autonomy interests such as {{c7::abortion}}, {{c8::private consensual homosexual activity}}, and {{c9::refusal of medical treatment}}; and (3) the fundamental rights to {{c10::vote}} and to {{c11::travel}}, often analyzed under the {{c2::Equal Protection Clause}}.
cards.easyContent: Fundamental rights are protected through substantive due process (when denied to everyone) and equal protection (when denied only to some), and non-fundamental rights get only rational basis review. Major fundamental rights include privacy-related rights (marriage, procreation, family, childrearing, contraception and related autonomy interests) plus the rights to vote and to travel.
cards.mediumContent: Fundamental rights are enforced under 5th Amendment substantive due process and 14th Amendment equal protection. Substantive due process is used when a right is denied to everyone; equal protection is used when a right is denied to some but not others. Government action that does not implicate a fundamental right is reviewed under rational basis. Key fundamental rights fall into three broad categories: (1) privacy rights that generally receive strict scrutiny (marriage, procreation, family integrity, custody and upbringing of children, and use of contraceptives); (2) other autonomy rights with separate or evolving standards of review (abortion, private consensual homosexual activity, and refusal of medical treatment); and (3) the rights to vote and to travel, which are fundamental and usually analyzed under equal protection.
cards.hardContent: Fundamental rights are protected by both 5th Amendment substantive due process and 14th Amendment equal protection. Substantive due process applies when a right is denied to all persons, whereas equal protection applies when the right is denied only to certain people or groups. Government action that does not implicate a fundamental right receives only rational basis review. Within this framework, core fundamental rights are grouped into: (1) privacy rights that usually receive strict scrutiny, including the rights to marry, to procreate, to maintain family integrity, to custody of one’s children, to keep the family together, to control children’s upbringing, and to use contraceptives; (2) privacy-related autonomy rights with separate or uncertain standards of review, including the right to abortion, the right to engage in private, consensual homosexual activity, and the right to refuse medical treatment; and (3) the separate but related fundamental rights to vote and to travel, which are often analyzed under the Equal Protection Clause.
cards.mnemonic: Fundamental rights: Privacy, Power to vote, Pack up and travel.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into: (1) SDP vs. EP framework; (2) strict-scrutiny privacy rights (marriage, procreation, family/children, contraception); (3) abortion and other privacy-related rights with separate standards; (4) fundamental rights to vote and to travel.
cards.clozeLite: Fundamental rights are enforced under {{c1::5th Amendment substantive due process}} and {{c2::14th Amendment equal protection}} and generally get {{c3::strict scrutiny}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 031. Right to Abortion (old analysis)
cards.front: Right to Abortion (old analysis)
cards.backPlain: Under the old substantive due process framework, abortion was treated as part of the fundamental right to privacy. Analysis turned on fetal viability: before viability the state could not ban abortion and could regulate only if it did not impose an undue burden; after viability the state could ban abortion but had to allow abortions when medically necessary to protect the mother's health. Additional rules addressed what counted as an undue burden, special requirements for minors (including judicial bypass), and the absence of any constitutional duty for the government to fund or provide abortions.
cards.frontPrompt: Under the (old) substantive due process framework, what was the nature of the abortion right, how did the viability framework work, and what other main regulatory limits applied (e.g., undue burden, minors, and funding)?
cards.cloze: Under the old framework, abortion was treated as a {{c1::substantive due process}} {{c2::privacy}} right. The core analysis turned on {{c3::fetal viability}}: {{c4::before viability}} the state could not {{c5::ban abortion}} and could regulate only if there was no {{c6::undue burden}}; {{c7::after viability}} the state could {{c8::prohibit abortion}} but had to allow abortions when {{c9::medically necessary to protect the mother's health}}. Additional rules governed {{c10::minors (judicial bypass)}} and the lack of any {{c11::constitutional duty to fund or provide abortions}}.
cards.easyContent: Under the old framework, abortion was a substantive due process privacy right analyzed under a viability framework. Before viability, bans were forbidden and regulations could not impose an undue burden; after viability, bans were allowed with a health exception. There were also special rules for minors (judicial bypass) and no duty for the government to fund or provide abortions.
cards.mediumContent: Under the old analysis, abortion was protected as part of the substantive due process right to privacy. The key was viability: before viability, states could not ban abortions and could regulate only if there was no undue burden; after viability, states could ban abortions but had to allow abortions when medically necessary to protect the mother’s health. Courts also developed specific undue burden examples and special rules for parental involvement with minors (judicial bypass), and held that the government had no duty to fund or provide abortions.
cards.hardContent: Under the pre-Dobbs substantive due process framework, abortion was a fundamental privacy right. Courts applied a viability framework: (1) Before viability, the state could not prohibit abortion and could regulate only if it did not impose an undue burden on a woman’s right to obtain an abortion. (2) After viability, the state could prohibit abortion but had to permit abortions when medically necessary to protect the mother’s health. The doctrine also identified specific examples of what did or did not constitute an undue burden, required particular protections in parental notice/consent laws for minors (i.e., a judicial bypass procedure), and made clear that the government had no constitutional duty to subsidize or provide abortions.
cards.mnemonic: V-U-B: Viability, Undue burden, Bans with health exception.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into four children: (1) nature of abortion right and viability framework, (2) pre- vs post-viability rules and undue burden examples, (3) parental involvement and judicial bypass, and (4) government funding limits.
cards.clozeLite: Under the old framework, abortion was {{c1::protected as a substantive due process privacy right}} under a {{c2::viability}} and {{c3::undue burden}} framework, with {{c4::post-viability health exception}} and {{c5::judicial bypass for minors}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 032. Equal Protection Application & Analysis
cards.front: Equal Protection Application & Analysis
cards.backPlain: 1. Application (how Equal Protection applies to federal, state, and local governments): 1.1 The 14th Amendment Equal Protection Clause applies directly to state and local governments. 1.2 Equal Protection applies to the federal government by incorporation through the 5th Amendment Due Process Clause (the Equal Protection Clause does not apply directly to the federal government). 1.3 The same Equal Protection analysis and levels of scrutiny apply whether Equal Protection is applied through the 5th or 14th Amendment. 2. Analysis (if you see anything that could implicate Equal Protection, ask): 2.1 Is there a discriminatory classification? To receive heightened scrutiny, a discriminatory classification must be proved. 2.2 What level of scrutiny applies given the classification? 2.2.1 Suspect classifications receive strict scrutiny. 2.2.2 Quasi-suspect classifications receive intermediate scrutiny. 2.2.3 All other alleged classifications receive rational basis review. 2.3 Does the classification satisfy the appropriate level of scrutiny?
cards.frontPrompt: How does the Equal Protection guarantee apply to state/local versus federal governments, and what are the basic analytical steps (including levels of scrutiny) in an Equal Protection analysis?
cards.cloze: 1. Application (how {{c1::Equal Protection}} applies to federal, state, and local governments): 1.1 The {{c2::14th Amendment Equal Protection Clause}} applies directly to {{c3::state and local governments}}. 1.2 Equal Protection applies to the {{c4::federal government}} by incorporation through the {{c5::5th Amendment Due Process Clause}} (the Equal Protection Clause does not apply directly to the federal government). 1.3 The same Equal Protection {{c6::analysis and levels of scrutiny}} apply whether Equal Protection is applied through the 5th or 14th Amendment. 2. Analysis (if you see anything that could implicate Equal Protection, ask): 2.1 Is there a {{c7::discriminatory classification}}? To receive {{c8::heightened scrutiny}}, a discriminatory classification must be proved. 2.2 What {{c9::level of scrutiny}} applies given the classification? 2.2.1 {{c10::Suspect classifications}} receive {{c11::strict scrutiny}}. 2.2.2 {{c12::Quasi-suspect classifications}} receive {{c13::intermediate scrutiny}}. 2.2.3 All other alleged classifications receive {{c14::rational basis}} review. 2.3 Does the classification satisfy the appropriate level of scrutiny?
cards.easyContent: Equal Protection binds state and local governments directly through the 14th Amendment and binds the federal government through the 5th Amendment Due Process Clause, and the same Equal Protection analysis and levels of scrutiny apply to both.
cards.mediumContent: Equal Protection applies directly to state and local governments via the 14th Amendment and to the federal government via the 5th Amendment Due Process Clause, but the same Equal Protection analysis and scrutiny levels apply either way. In any Equal Protection problem, ask: (1) is there a discriminatory classification; (2) what level of scrutiny applies (strict for suspect classes, intermediate for quasi-suspect, rational basis for others); and (3) does the law satisfy that level of scrutiny.
cards.hardContent: Equal Protection applies to different governments in two ways. The 14th Amendment Equal Protection Clause applies directly to state and local governments. Equal Protection applies to the federal government by incorporation through the 5th Amendment Due Process Clause; the Equal Protection Clause itself does not directly bind the federal government. Nonetheless, the same Equal Protection analysis and levels of scrutiny apply whether the guarantee is applied through the 5th or 14th Amendment. In any Equal Protection analysis, first ask whether there is a discriminatory classification; heightened scrutiny applies only if a discriminatory classification is proved. Second, determine the applicable level of scrutiny: suspect classifications get strict scrutiny, quasi-suspect classifications get intermediate scrutiny, and all other alleged classifications get rational basis review. Third, analyze whether the classification satisfies the applicable level of scrutiny.
cards.mnemonic: 14 → States, 5 → Feds; then: Classify, Choose Scrutiny, Check If Satisfied
cards.clozeLite: EP binds {{c1::states via the 14th Amendment}} and {{c2::the federal government via the 5th Amendment Due Process Clause}}, using {{c3::the same scrutiny levels}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 033. Proving Discriminatory Classifications
cards.front: Proving Discriminatory Classifications
cards.backPlain: Classifications must be discriminatory to be reviewed under heightened scrutiny (intermediate or strict scrutiny). There are three ways to prove a discriminatory classification: 1. Law discriminates on its face: By its terms, the law treats classes of people differently. 2. Facially neutral law applied in a discriminatory manner: The law does not create a classification by its terms, but does so as applied (for example, only men are arrested under an otherwise valid law). 3. Discriminatory motive or purpose behind the law and/or its application: 3.1 Test: The plaintiff must show both: 3.1.1 Disparate impact: the law has a discriminatory impact (it creates a classification in practice), and 3.1.2 Discriminatory purpose: the law was enacted or maintained for reasons involving discrimination. Demonstrating discriminatory impact alone is not enough; there must be some evidence of the government's discriminatory motive. 4. Challenger bears burden: The burden is on the party challenging the classification to show that it is discriminatory.
cards.frontPrompt: In Equal Protection cases, what are the three ways to prove a discriminatory classification sufficient to trigger heightened scrutiny, and what must a challenger show when alleging discriminatory purpose?
cards.cloze: Classifications must be {{c1::discriminatory}} to be reviewed under {{c2::heightened scrutiny}} ({{c3::intermediate}} or {{c4::strict}} scrutiny). There are three ways to prove a discriminatory classification: 1. {{c5::Law discriminates on its face}}: By its terms, the law treats classes of people differently. 2. {{c6::Facially neutral law applied in a discriminatory manner}}: The law does not create a classification by its terms, but does so as applied (for example, only men are arrested under an otherwise valid law). 3. {{c7::Discriminatory motive or purpose}} behind the law and/or its application: 3.1 Test: The plaintiff must show both: 3.1.1 {{c8::Disparate impact}}: the law has a discriminatory impact (it creates a classification in practice), and 3.1.2 {{c9::Discriminatory purpose}}: the law was enacted or maintained for reasons involving discrimination. Demonstrating discriminatory impact alone is not enough; there must be some evidence of the government's discriminatory motive. 4. {{c10::Challenger bears burden}}: The burden is on the party challenging the classification to show that it is discriminatory.
cards.easyContent: To get heightened scrutiny, there must be a discriminatory classification, which can be shown by a law that discriminates on its face, a facially neutral law applied in a discriminatory way, or a law adopted/maintained for a discriminatory purpose.
cards.mediumContent: Equal Protection heightened scrutiny requires a discriminatory classification. This can be shown in three ways: (1) the law discriminates on its face; (2) a facially neutral law is applied in a discriminatory manner; or (3) there is discriminatory motive or purpose. For discriminatory purpose, the plaintiff must prove both disparate impact in practice and that the law was enacted or maintained for discriminatory reasons; impact alone is not enough. The challenger bears the burden of proof.
cards.hardContent: For intermediate or strict scrutiny to apply in Equal Protection, the classification must be discriminatory. There are three ways to prove a discriminatory classification. First, a law can discriminate on its face, meaning that by its terms it treats different classes of people differently. Second, a facially neutral law can be applied in a discriminatory manner, so that although the text is neutral, in practice it only burdens a protected group (for example, only men are arrested under an otherwise valid law). Third, discriminatory motive or purpose can underlie the law or its administration. In that situation, the plaintiff must show both a disparate impact (that the law has a discriminatory impact in practice) and a discriminatory purpose (that it was enacted or maintained for reasons involving discrimination). Disparate impact alone is insufficient without some evidence of governmental discriminatory motive. In all cases, the challenger bears the burden of showing that the classification is discriminatory.
cards.mnemonic: "Face, Application, Aim": face, applied, or purpose; purpose needs impact + intent.
cards.clozeLite: Heightened scrutiny needs a {{c1::discriminatory classification}} shown by {{c2::facial discrimination}}, {{c3::discriminatory application}}, or {{c4::discriminatory purpose plus disparate impact}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 034. Equal Protection Standards of Review
cards.front: Equal Protection Standards of Review
cards.backPlain: The following lists classifications and the standard of review they receive: 1. Rational basis: 1.1 Alienage, but only if the classification: 1.1.1 Relates to self-government, and 1.1.2 Relates to the democratic process, or 1.1.3 Is a congressional action concerning immigration. 1.2 All other classifications not qualifying for strict or intermediate scrutiny receive rational basis review (for example, age, disability, wealth, and economic regulations). 2. Intermediate scrutiny (quasi-suspect classifications): 2.1 Gender. 2.2 Non-marital children (illegitimacy). 3. Strict scrutiny (suspect classifications and certain fundamental rights): 3.1 Race. 3.2 National origin. 3.3 Alienage (except when subject only to rational basis as noted above). 3.4 Right to travel. 3.5 Right to vote.
cards.frontPrompt: Under Equal Protection, which classifications receive rational basis, intermediate scrutiny, and strict scrutiny, and what are the main alienage and fundamental rights wrinkles?
cards.cloze: The following lists classifications and the {{c1::standard of review}} they receive: 1. {{c2::Rational basis}}: 1.1 {{c3::Alienage}}, but only if the classification: 1.1.1 Relates to {{c4::self-government}}, and 1.1.2 Relates to the {{c5::democratic process}}, or 1.1.3 Is a {{c6::congressional action concerning immigration}}. 1.2 All other classifications not qualifying for strict or intermediate scrutiny receive rational basis review (for example, {{c7::age}}, {{c8::disability}}, {{c9::wealth}}, and {{c10::economic regulations}}). 2. {{c11::Intermediate scrutiny}} ({{c12::quasi-suspect classifications}}): 2.1 {{c13::Gender}}. 2.2 {{c14::Non-marital children}} (illegitimacy). 3. {{c15::Strict scrutiny}} ({{c16::suspect classifications}} and certain {{c17::fundamental rights}}): 3.1 {{c18::Race}}. 3.2 {{c19::National origin}}. 3.3 {{c20::Alienage}} (except when subject only to rational basis as noted above). 3.4 {{c21::Right to travel}}. 3.5 {{c22::Right to vote}}.
cards.easyContent: Equal Protection uses three main levels of scrutiny: rational basis for most classifications, intermediate scrutiny for gender and non-marital children, and strict scrutiny for race, national origin, most alienage classifications, and fundamental rights like voting and travel.
cards.mediumContent: Under Equal Protection, rational basis applies to most classifications, including age, disability, wealth, and economic regulations, and to certain alienage classifications that relate to self-government and the democratic process or involve congressional regulation of immigration. Intermediate scrutiny (quasi-suspect) applies to gender and non-marital children. Strict scrutiny (suspect and key fundamental rights) applies to race, national origin, and most alienage classifications, as well as rights such as the right to travel and the right to vote.
cards.hardContent: Equal Protection analysis uses three levels of scrutiny tied to different classifications. Rational basis review applies to all classifications that do not qualify for strict or intermediate scrutiny, including age, disability, wealth, and economic regulations. It also applies to certain alienage classifications—those that relate to self-government and the democratic process (the "political function" exception) and to congressional actions concerning immigration. Intermediate scrutiny applies to quasi-suspect classifications, primarily gender and non-marital children (illegitimacy). Strict scrutiny applies to suspect classifications and certain fundamental rights.
