cards.clozeLite: Article III gives {{c1::original jurisdiction}} only for {{c2::suits between states}} and {{c3::cases involving foreign ambassadors/ministers}}, and {{c4::Congress cannot expand}} it.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Supreme Court Methods of Review: Certiorari and Mandatory Appeals
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 006-2. Supreme Court Methods of Review: Certiorari and Mandatory Appeals
cards.front: Supreme Court Methods of Review: Certiorari and Mandatory Appeals
cards.backPlain: 2. Methods of Supreme Court review 2.1 Discretionary review by certiorari - Most cases reach the Supreme Court by writ of certiorari. - A party petitions for certiorari, and the Court has complete discretion to grant or deny review. 2.2 Mandatory review from three-judge district courts - In certain cases, federal law requires that a three-judge federal district court panel hear requests for injunctive relief. - Appeals from these three-judge panels go directly and mandatorily to the Supreme Court. - These mandatory appeals bypass the intermediate federal courts of appeals.
cards.frontPrompt: By what main methods does a case reach the Supreme Court, and which kinds of cases must the Court review rather than exercising certiorari discretion?
cards.cloze: 2. Methods of Supreme Court review 2.1 {{c1::Discretionary review}} by {{c2::writ of certiorari}} - Most cases reach the Supreme Court through a {{c3::certiorari}} petition. - The Court has {{c4::complete discretion}} to grant or deny review. 2.2 {{c5::Mandatory review}} from three-judge district courts - Certain cases are heard in the first instance by a {{c6::three-judge federal district court panel}} deciding {{c7::injunctive relief}}. - Appeals from these panels go {{c8::directly}} and {{c9::mandatorily}} to the Supreme Court. - These appeals {{c10::bypass the federal courts of appeals}}.
cards.easyContent: Most Supreme Court cases arrive by discretionary writ of certiorari, which the Court can grant or deny, but it must directly hear certain mandatory appeals from three-judge federal district court panels deciding injunctive relief, skipping the courts of appeals.
cards.mediumContent: The primary route to the Supreme Court is via discretionary writ of certiorari: parties petition, and the Court decides whether to grant review. However, federal statutes require some cases—especially those heard by three-judge federal district court panels granting or denying injunctive relief—to be appealed directly and mandatorily to the Supreme Court, without passing through the courts of appeals.
cards.hardContent: Cases reach the Supreme Court mainly through discretionary review by writ of certiorari. A party files a certiorari petition, and the Court decides, in its complete discretion, whether to grant review. In contrast, certain statutes require that three-judge federal district court panels hear requests for injunctive relief in the first instance. Appeals from these three-judge panels go directly and mandatorily to the Supreme Court, bypassing the intermediate courts of appeals, so the Court has no discretion to refuse those appeals.
cards.mnemonic: Cert is Choice; Three-Judge Injunctions are Forced.
cards.clozeLite: Cases reach SCOTUS mainly by {{c1::discretionary writ of certiorari}}, but {{c2::appeals from three-judge federal district court panels}} on {{c3::injunctive relief}} go {{c4::directly and mandatorily}} to {{c5::the Supreme Court}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Supreme Court Final Judgment Rule and Limits on Appellate Jurisdiction
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 006-3. Supreme Court Final Judgment Rule and Limits on Appellate Jurisdiction
cards.front: Supreme Court Final Judgment Rule and Limits on Appellate Jurisdiction
cards.backPlain: 3. Final judgment requirement and appellate jurisdiction limits 3.1 Final judgment rule - The Supreme Court generally will hear a case on review only if there has been a final judgment. - The final judgment must come from either: • A lower federal court; or • A state's highest court that can decide the case. 3.2 Limits on appellate jurisdiction - Under Article III, the Supreme Court has appellate jurisdiction over other cases within the federal judicial power, subject to "such Exceptions and under such Regulations as the Congress shall make." - Congress may limit or make exceptions to the Court's appellate jurisdiction by statute. - However, Congress may not use this power to expand the Court's original jurisdiction or otherwise violate core Article III requirements.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the Supreme Court’s final judgment rule, and how can Congress limit the Court’s appellate jurisdiction under Article III?
cards.cloze: 3. Final judgment requirement and appellate jurisdiction limits 3.1 {{c1::Final judgment rule}} - The Supreme Court generally reviews a case only after a {{c2::final judgment}}. - The judgment must be from either: • A {{c3::lower federal court}}; or • A {{c4::state's highest court}} that can decide the case. 3.2 Limits on appellate jurisdiction - Under {{c5::Article III}}, the Supreme Court has {{c6::appellate jurisdiction}} subject to "{{c7::such Exceptions and under such Regulations as the Congress shall make}}." - Congress may {{c8::limit or make exceptions}} to the Court's appellate jurisdiction by statute. - Congress may not use this power to {{c9::expand original jurisdiction}} or otherwise {{c10::contradict Article III}} requirements.
cards.easyContent: The Supreme Court usually reviews only final judgments from lower federal courts or a state’s highest court, and while Congress can make exceptions and regulations to limit the Court’s appellate jurisdiction, it cannot expand the Court’s original jurisdiction or violate Article III.
cards.mediumContent: Under the final judgment rule, the Supreme Court typically will not review a case until there has been a final judgment by a lower federal court or by the state’s highest court competent to decide the matter. Article III grants the Court appellate jurisdiction over other cases within the federal judicial power, but subjects that jurisdiction to exceptions and regulations Congress may make. Congress can therefore limit or create exceptions to the Court’s appellate jurisdiction by statute, but it cannot use this power to enlarge original jurisdiction or otherwise override constitutional limits.
cards.hardContent: The Supreme Court adheres to a final judgment rule: it generally hears cases only after a final judgment has been entered by a lower federal court or by the highest state court that can render a decision in the case. This discourages piecemeal review. Article III provides that the Supreme Court has appellate jurisdiction over other cases within the federal judicial power, "with such Exceptions, and under such Regulations as the Congress shall make." Using this power, Congress may limit or make exceptions to the Court’s appellate jurisdiction by statute. However, Congress cannot use such legislation to expand the Court’s original jurisdiction or contravene constitutional structure and Article III boundaries.
cards.mnemonic: Final First: only final rulings, Congress trims appeals.
cards.clozeLite: Under the {{c1::final judgment rule}}, the Supreme Court reviews only {{c2::final judgments}} and Congress may make {{c3::exceptions and regulations}} to its {{c4::appellate jurisdiction}} under {{c5::Article III}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Adequate and Independent State Grounds Limiting Supreme Court Review
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 006-4. Adequate and Independent State Grounds Limiting Supreme Court Review
cards.front: Adequate and Independent State Grounds Limiting Supreme Court Review
cards.backPlain: 4. State court decisions and adequate and independent state grounds 4.1 Bar on review when state law is adequate and independent - The Supreme Court cannot review a state court judgment that rests on an independent and adequate state law ground. - "Adequate" means the state law ground fully supports the judgment by itself. - "Independent" means the state law ground is not based on, or intertwined with, federal law. 4.2 Mixed state and federal grounds - If a state court decision is based on both federal and state law, the Supreme Court will not review if the judgment can stand on the state law ground alone. - The Court will grant review only if it appears that the state law ground is not adequate or not independent—for example, where it is unclear whether the judgment necessarily depends on the federal law issue.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the adequate and independent state grounds doctrine, and how does it limit the Supreme Court’s ability to review state court decisions?
cards.cloze: 4. State court decisions and {{c1::adequate and independent state grounds}} 4.1 Bar on review when state law is adequate and independent - The Supreme Court cannot review a state court judgment that rests on an {{c2::independent}} and {{c3::adequate}} state law ground. - "Adequate" means the state law ground {{c4::fully supports the judgment}} by itself. - "Independent" means the state law ground is {{c5::not based on or intertwined with federal law}}. 4.2 Mixed state and federal grounds - If a state court decision is based on both federal and state law, the Supreme Court will not review if the judgment {{c6::can stand on the state law ground alone}}. - The Court will review only if it appears that the state law ground is {{c7::not adequate}} or {{c8::not independent}}, such that the judgment may necessarily depend on {{c9::federal law}}.
cards.easyContent: The Supreme Court cannot review a state court judgment if an adequate and independent state law ground fully supports the result; only when the judgment cannot stand on state law alone, or the state ground is not clearly independent, will the Court review the federal issue.
cards.mediumContent: Under the adequate-and-independent state grounds doctrine, the Supreme Court lacks jurisdiction to review a state court judgment resting on a state law ground that is both adequate by itself to support the judgment and independent of federal law. When a state court decision appears to rest on both state and federal grounds, the Supreme Court will decline review if the judgment can stand on the state ground alone, and will review only where the state ground is not truly adequate or independent or where it is unclear whether the judgment depends on federal law.
cards.hardContent: The adequate and independent state grounds doctrine limits the Supreme Court’s capacity to review state court decisions. The Court has no authority to review a state judgment that rests on a state law ground that is both adequate—fully sufficient to support the judgment on its own—and independent—derived from state law that is not based on, or intertwined with, federal law. Where a state court opinion relies on both state and federal grounds, the Supreme Court will dismiss for want of jurisdiction if the judgment can stand on the state law ground alone. The Court will take review only where the state ground is not adequate or independent, or where ambiguity in the state court’s reasoning creates a substantial possibility that the judgment necessarily turned on a federal issue.
cards.mnemonic: A+I state ground means: Adequate, Independent = no Supreme Court review.
cards.clozeLite: SCOTUS lacks jurisdiction if a {{c1::state law ground}} is both {{c2::adequate}} and {{c3::independent}} of {{c4::federal law}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 007-1. 11th Amendment & Sovereign Immunity – Baseline Rule
cards.front: 11th Amendment & Sovereign Immunity – Baseline Rule
cards.backPlain: 1. General baseline rule 1.1 The 11th Amendment and the related doctrine of sovereign immunity bar suits against state governments in federal court. 1.2 Under the 11th Amendment, federal courts cannot hear claims from a private party or foreign government against a state government. 1.3 Sovereign immunity also generally bars suits against states in state court. Scope - Applies to suits where the state is the defendant and would be liable from the state treasury. - Applies to suits by citizens of that state, citizens of other states, and foreign citizens or governments, unless an exception applies.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the baseline rule under the 11th Amendment and sovereign immunity regarding suits against state governments in federal and state court?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::General baseline rule}} 1.1 The {{c2::11th Amendment}} and the related doctrine of {{c3::sovereign immunity}} bar suits against {{c4::state governments}} in {{c5::federal court}}. 1.2 Under the 11th Amendment, federal courts cannot hear claims from a {{c6::private party}} or {{c7::foreign government}} against a state government. 1.3 Sovereign immunity also generally bars suits against states in {{c8::state court}}. Scope - Applies to suits where the {{c9::state is the defendant}} and would be liable from the {{c10::state treasury}}. - Applies to suits by {{c11::citizens of that state}}, {{c12::citizens of other states}}, and {{c13::foreign citizens or governments}}, unless an exception applies.
cards.easyContent: By default, the 11th Amendment and sovereign immunity bar private and foreign suits against states in federal court, and generally protect states from being sued in their own courts.
cards.mediumContent: The 11th Amendment and sovereign immunity establish a baseline rule that states cannot be sued in federal court by private parties or foreign governments, and are generally immune from suit in their own state courts as well. This protection applies when the state is the defendant and any judgment would be paid from the state treasury, regardless of the plaintiff’s citizenship, unless an exception or valid workaround applies.
cards.hardContent: Under the baseline 11th Amendment rule, federal courts lack jurisdiction over suits brought by private parties or foreign governments against state governments. Parallel sovereign immunity principles generally prevent states from being sued in their own courts absent consent or valid abrogation. The doctrine protects the state as an entity and its treasury from liability and applies regardless of whether the plaintiff is a citizen of the same state, a citizen of another state, or a foreign citizen or government, unless a specific exception or workaround (such as waiver, abrogation, or suit against a state officer) applies.
cards.mnemonic: Baseline is “NO STATE AS DEFENDANT” in most courts.
cards.clozeLite: Baseline: {{c1::states cannot be sued in federal court}} by {{c2::private parties or foreign governments}}, and are {{c3::generally immune in their own courts}} absent {{c4::exception or valid workaround}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: 11th Amendment – Exceptions Allowing Suits Against States
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 007-2. 11th Amendment – Exceptions Allowing Suits Against States
cards.front: 11th Amendment – Exceptions Allowing Suits Against States
cards.backPlain: 2. Exceptions: suits against state governments allowed in federal court 2.1 Waiver or consent - A state may waive sovereign immunity or consent to be sued in federal court, but the waiver must be explicit and unequivocal. 2.2 Valid Section 5 abrogation - Congress may authorize private suits against states under Section 5 of the 14th Amendment, but only if: • Congress clearly expresses its intent to abrogate state immunity; and • The legislation is a valid exercise of Section 5 power (i.e., it enforces the 14th Amendment and is congruent and proportional to the constitutional violation). 2.3 Federal government suits - The United States federal government may sue a state in federal court; 11th Amendment sovereign immunity does not bar these suits. 2.4 Bankruptcy proceedings - The 11th Amendment does not bar certain federal bankruptcy proceedings involving states, based on the Bankruptcy Clause and Supreme Court precedent.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the main exceptions that allow suits against state governments in federal court despite the 11th Amendment and sovereign immunity?
cards.cloze: 2. {{c1::Exceptions}}: suits against state governments allowed in federal court 2.1 {{c2::Waiver or consent}} – a state may {{c3::explicitly and unequivocally waive}} sovereign immunity or consent to be sued. 2.2 {{c4::Valid Section 5 abrogation}} – Congress may authorize private suits against states when it: • {{c5::clearly expresses}} an intent to abrogate immunity; and • Acts under a {{c6::valid exercise of Section 5}} power (congruent and proportional enforcement of the 14th Amendment). 2.3 {{c7::Federal government suits}} – the {{c8::United States}} may sue a state in federal court; 11th Amendment immunity does not apply. 2.4 {{c9::Bankruptcy proceedings}} – certain {{c10::federal bankruptcy}} proceedings involving states are not barred by the 11th Amendment.
cards.easyContent: States can be sued in federal court if they clearly waive immunity, if Congress validly abrogates immunity under Section 5 of the 14th Amendment, if the federal government sues them, or in certain bankruptcy proceedings.
cards.mediumContent: Although the 11th Amendment and sovereign immunity bar most private suits against states in federal court, there are four key exceptions. First, a state can explicitly and unequivocally waive its immunity or consent to suit. Second, Congress can validly abrogate state immunity when it clearly expresses that intent and acts under its enforcement power in Section 5 of the 14th Amendment with congruent and proportional legislation. Third, the United States federal government may sue a state in federal court without being blocked by 11th Amendment immunity. Fourth, the 11th Amendment does not bar certain federal bankruptcy proceedings involving state creditors or debtors.
cards.hardContent: The principal ways around state sovereign immunity in federal court are limited and carefully policed. A state may waive its immunity or consent to be sued, but courts require a clear, unequivocal expression of that waiver—mere participation in a federal regulatory scheme is not enough. Congress may abrogate state sovereign immunity only when it (1) unmistakably states its intent to permit suits against states, and (2) acts pursuant to a valid grant of constitutional authority, almost always Section 5 of the 14th Amendment, with remedies that are congruent and proportional to identified constitutional violations. The 11th Amendment does not shield states from suits brought by the federal government itself, so the United States may sue a state in federal court. Finally, under the Bankruptcy Clause and Supreme Court precedent, the 11th Amendment does not bar certain core bankruptcy proceedings even when they affect states, providing another narrow exception to state immunity.
cards.mnemonic: W-Fed-B-5: Waiver, Federal suits, Bankruptcy, Section 5 abrogation.
cards.clozeLite: Four exceptions: {{c1::state waiver}}, {{c2::valid §5 14A abrogation}}, {{c3::U.S. sues the state}}, and {{c4::certain bankruptcy proceedings}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 007-3. 11th Amendment – Suits Against State Officers
cards.front: 11th Amendment – Suits Against State Officers
cards.backPlain: 3. Suits against state officers (in federal court) 3.1 Injunctive relief - Suits seeking injunctive relief for violation of the Constitution or federal law may be brought against state officers. - This is the Ex parte Young doctrine: a plaintiff can sue a state officer in his or her official capacity for prospective relief to stop an ongoing violation of federal law. - The suit is treated as not being against the state itself, so 11th Amendment immunity does not apply. 3.2 Personal-capacity damages - Suits seeking money damages to be paid by the state officer personally (not from the state treasury) may be brought against state officers. - These are personal-capacity suits; any judgment is collected from the officer’s personal assets, not the state. Limits - Retrospective relief requiring payment from the state treasury is barred when the state is the real party in interest. - Suits nominally against officers but effectively against the state (e.g., to impose liability on the state treasury) remain barred by sovereign immunity.
cards.frontPrompt: When may a plaintiff sue state officers in federal court despite the 11th Amendment, and what kinds of relief are allowed?
cards.cloze: 3. Suits against {{c1::state officers}} (in federal court) 3.1 {{c2::Injunctive relief}} - Suits seeking injunctive relief for violations of the {{c3::Constitution}} or {{c4::federal law}} may be brought against state officers. - Under the {{c5::Ex parte Young}} doctrine, a plaintiff can sue a state officer in his or her {{c6::official capacity}} for {{c7::prospective relief}} to stop an ongoing violation of federal law. - The suit is treated as not being against the {{c8::state itself}}, so 11th Amendment immunity does not apply. 3.2 {{c9::Personal-capacity damages}} - Suits seeking {{c10::money damages}} to be paid by the state officer {{c11::personally}} (not from the state treasury) may be brought. - These are {{c12::personal-capacity}} suits; any judgment is collected from the officer’s {{c13::personal assets}}, not the state. Limits - {{c14::Retrospective relief}} requiring payment from the {{c15::state treasury}} is barred when the {{c16::state is the real party in interest}}. - Suits nominally against officers but effectively against the {{c17::state}} (e.g., to impose liability on the state treasury) remain barred by sovereign immunity.
cards.easyContent: Even when a state is immune, a plaintiff can sue state officers in federal court: (1) for prospective injunctive relief under Ex parte Young to stop ongoing violations of federal law, and (2) for money damages from the officer personally, not the state treasury.
cards.mediumContent: The 11th Amendment does not bar federal suits against state officers in two important situations. First, under Ex parte Young, a plaintiff may sue a state officer in official capacity for prospective injunctive relief to stop ongoing violations of the Constitution or federal law; these suits are treated as not being against the state itself. Second, a plaintiff may sue a state officer in personal capacity for money damages, so long as any judgment is payable from the officer’s personal assets rather than the state treasury. However, sovereign immunity still bars suits that, in substance, seek retrospective relief or payment from the state treasury, even if framed nominally against officers.
cards.hardContent: To work around state sovereign immunity, plaintiffs often sue state officers rather than the state itself. Ex parte Young allows official-capacity suits for prospective injunctive or declaratory relief aimed at halting ongoing violations of federal law, on the theory that an officer acting unconstitutionally is stripped of his lawful authority. Because the relief is forward-looking and does not compel payment from the state treasury for past harms, these suits are not treated as barred suits against the state. Separately, plaintiffs may bring personal-capacity suits for damages against state officers, with any judgment satisfied from the officer’s own assets, not the state’s. The 11th Amendment still bars suits that, despite being framed against an officer, are in substance against the state—as where the requested remedy would impose liability on the state treasury or grant retrospective monetary relief for past violations against the state.
cards.mnemonic: Young injunctions, personal pockets: sue officers, not the state.
cards.clozeLite: 11th Amendment allows suits vs {{c1::state officers}} for {{c2::Ex parte Young prospective injunctive relief}} and {{c3::personal-capacity damages from officer’s assets}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Legislative Powers – Core Article I Enumerated Powers
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 008-1. Legislative Powers – Core Article I Enumerated Powers
cards.front: Legislative Powers – Core Article I Enumerated Powers
cards.backPlain: 1. Article I as the main source of congressional power 1.1 Article I of the Constitution provides most of Congress’s powers. 2. Core enumerated powers to remember 2.1 Taxing and spending power. 2.2 Commerce power. 2.3 Power to establish uniform rules of naturalization and bankruptcy. 2.4 Power to raise and support the military (armed forces). 3. Relationship to execution of the laws 3.1 Congress enacts laws pursuant to its Article I powers. 3.2 The executive branch is then obligated to execute the laws passed by Congress, but this is not itself a separate congressional power.
cards.frontPrompt: What are Congress’s core Article I enumerated powers that frequently appear on the bar exam, and how do they relate to the execution of federal laws?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Article I}} as the main source of congressional power 1.1 Article I of the Constitution provides most of Congress’s powers. 2. Core {{c2::enumerated powers}} to remember 2.1 {{c3::Taxing and spending}} power. 2.2 {{c4::Commerce}} power. 2.3 Power to establish uniform rules of {{c5::naturalization}} and {{c6::bankruptcy}}. 2.4 Power to {{c7::raise and support the military}} (armed forces). 3. Relationship to execution of the laws 3.1 Congress {{c8::enacts laws}} pursuant to its Article I powers. 3.2 The {{c9::executive branch}} is obligated to {{c10::execute the laws}} passed by Congress, but this is not itself a separate congressional power.
cards.easyContent: Article I is the main source of Congress’s power. Core enumerated powers to know cold are the powers to tax and spend, regulate commerce, set uniform naturalization and bankruptcy rules, and raise and support the military. Congress uses these powers to pass laws, and the executive branch then carries them out.
cards.mediumContent: Article I grants Congress most of its powers. High‑yield enumerated powers include: (1) the taxing and spending power; (2) the commerce power; (3) the power to establish uniform rules of naturalization and bankruptcy; and (4) the power to raise and support the armed forces. Congress uses these powers to enact laws, while the executive branch has the distinct duty to execute those laws.
cards.hardContent: Article I of the Constitution is the primary source of congressional authority. Among the most frequently tested enumerated powers are: (1) the power to tax and spend for the general welfare; (2) the power to regulate interstate and foreign commerce; (3) the power to establish uniform rules of naturalization and bankruptcy; and (4) the power to raise and support the military, including the armed forces. Congress exercises these powers by enacting statutes, and the executive branch is constitutionally obligated to execute and enforce those statutes, underscoring the separation between lawmaking (legislative) and law‑executing (executive) functions.
cards.mnemonic: T-C-N-B-M: Tax, Commerce, Naturalization, Bankruptcy, Military.
cards.clozeLite: Core {{c1::Article I powers}}: {{c2::tax and spend}}, {{c3::regulate commerce}}, {{c4::naturalization and bankruptcy}}, {{c5::raise and support the military}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Legislative Powers – Speech or Debate Clause Immunity
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 008-2. Legislative Powers – Speech or Debate Clause Immunity
cards.front: Legislative Powers – Speech or Debate Clause Immunity
cards.backPlain: 1. Speech or Debate Clause: basic rule 1.1 The Speech or Debate Clause protects members of Congress from liability for legislative conduct. 2. Scope of immunity 2.1 Members of Congress have criminal and civil immunity for legislative acts. 2.2 The immunity extends to activities and documents that are essential to the performance of legislative duties. 3. Key idea 3.1 The Clause is designed to protect the independence and integrity of the legislative process, not personal or political acts unrelated to legislation.
cards.frontPrompt: What does the Speech or Debate Clause protect, and how broad is the immunity it provides to members of Congress?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Speech or Debate Clause}}: basic rule 1.1 The Speech or Debate Clause protects members of Congress from liability for {{c2::legislative conduct}}. 2. Scope of immunity 2.1 Members of Congress have {{c3::criminal and civil immunity}} for {{c4::legislative acts}}. 2.2 The immunity extends to {{c5::activities and documents}} that are {{c6::essential to the performance of legislative duties}}. 3. Key idea 3.1 The Clause is designed to protect the {{c7::independence and integrity of the legislative process}}, not {{c8::personal or political acts}} unrelated to legislation.
cards.easyContent: The Speech or Debate Clause gives members of Congress immunity from civil and criminal liability for legislative acts and for activities and documents essential to those duties. It protects the legislative process, not personal or political conduct.
cards.mediumContent: Under the Speech or Debate Clause, members of Congress are immune from both criminal and civil liability for their legislative acts. This protection extends to activities and documents that are essential to performing legislative duties. The purpose is to safeguard the independence and integrity of the legislative process, not to shield purely personal, political, or non‑legislative acts.
cards.hardContent: The Speech or Debate Clause provides broad functional immunity to members of Congress for actions within the legislative sphere. Legislators are protected from civil and criminal liability for legislative acts, and this immunity encompasses activities and documents that are integral or essential to their legislative duties, such as voting, speaking on the floor, and preparing committee reports. The Clause is meant to preserve the independence and integrity of the legislative process by preventing intimidation or harassment through lawsuits or prosecutions, but it does not immunize purely personal conduct, political campaigning, or other acts not fairly characterized as part of the legislative function.
cards.mnemonic: Speech or Debate shields speech and debate—legislative acts, not personal politics.
cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::Speech or Debate Clause}} gives members of Congress {{c2::immunity from civil and criminal liability}} for {{c3::legislative acts and essential legislative activities}}, but {{c4::not for purely personal or political conduct}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Legislative Powers – Necessary and Proper Clause & Implied Powers
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 008-3. Legislative Powers – Necessary and Proper Clause & Implied Powers
cards.front: Legislative Powers – Necessary and Proper Clause & Implied Powers
cards.backPlain: 1. Function of the Necessary and Proper Clause 1.1 The Necessary and Proper Clause enables Congress to take actions that are not themselves enumerated to implement its express powers. 1.2 It authorizes any means that are useful or convenient, so long as they are not otherwise unconstitutional. 2. Implied powers 2.1 The Clause is the textual basis for Congress’s implied powers. 2.2 These implied powers exist to carry into execution Congress’s other enumerated powers (e.g., commerce, taxing and spending, military). 3. Not an independent source of power 3.1 The Necessary and Proper Clause is not an independent or standalone source of congressional power. 3.2 Any law justified under the Clause must be tied to another valid federal power. 3.3 On the MBE, the Necessary and Proper Clause by itself is usually an incorrect answer choice for the source of Congress’s power to act.
cards.frontPrompt: What does the Necessary and Proper Clause authorize Congress to do, what are implied powers, and why is the Clause not a standalone source of congressional power?
cards.cloze: 1. Function of the {{c1::Necessary and Proper Clause}} 1.1 The Necessary and Proper Clause enables Congress to take actions that are not themselves enumerated to {{c2::implement its express powers}}. 1.2 It authorizes any means that are {{c3::useful or convenient}}, so long as they are {{c4::not otherwise unconstitutional}}. 2. Implied powers 2.1 The Clause is the textual basis for Congress’s {{c5::implied powers}}. 2.2 These implied powers exist to {{c6::carry into execution Congress’s other enumerated powers}} (e.g., commerce, taxing and spending, military). 3. Not an independent source of power 3.1 The Necessary and Proper Clause is {{c7::not an independent or standalone source}} of congressional power. 3.2 Any law justified under the Clause must be {{c8::tied to another valid federal power}}. 3.3 On the MBE, the Necessary and Proper Clause by itself is usually an {{c9::incorrect answer choice}} for the source of Congress’s power to act.
cards.easyContent: The Necessary and Proper Clause lets Congress use implied means—actions not themselves listed in the Constitution—to carry out its enumerated powers, as long as those means are not unconstitutional. The Clause creates implied powers but is not itself a freestanding source of power, so it usually isn’t the correct standalone basis for a federal law on the MBE.
cards.mediumContent: The Necessary and Proper Clause authorizes Congress to adopt measures that are useful or convenient for implementing its express Article I powers, provided those measures are not otherwise unconstitutional. It is the textual basis for Congress’s implied powers: powers that exist solely to carry into execution other enumerated powers such as the commerce, taxing and spending, or military powers. However, the Clause does not supply an independent grant of substantive power; any statute relying on it must be linked to another valid federal power, which is why the Clause alone is often an incorrect answer on MBE questions about the source of congressional authority.
cards.hardContent: The Necessary and Proper Clause permits Congress to select any means that are rationally related to and useful or convenient for carrying into execution its enumerated powers, so long as those means are not otherwise prohibited by the Constitution. This Clause is the basis for Congress’s implied powers: it allows Congress to legislate beyond the literal text of the enumerated powers when doing so facilitates the effective exercise of those powers, such as by creating federal agencies or criminalizing interference with federal programs. Critically, the Clause is not an independent source of legislative authority; it operates only in conjunction with other valid federal powers. Thus, on bar exam questions asking for the source of Congress’s power, the Necessary and Proper Clause, standing alone, is usually an incorrect answer choice.
cards.mnemonic: NP is the glue: needs a power to stick to.
cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::Necessary and Proper Clause}} is the basis for Congress’s {{c2::implied powers}} but {{c3::is not an independent grant}} of {{c4::substantive power}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Taxing & Spending Power – Basic Scope and Exam Context
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 009-1. Taxing & Spending Power – Basic Scope and Exam Context
cards.front: Taxing & Spending Power – Basic Scope and Exam Context
cards.backPlain: 1. Basic scope of the taxing and spending power 1.1 Congress may tax and spend in any way it deems necessary to provide for the general welfare. 1.2 This "general welfare" standard is interpreted very broadly. 2. Typical bar exam context 2.1 On bar exam questions, Congress’s taxing and spending power is usually the correct basis for federal authority when the statute concerns: 2.1.1 Taxation; 2.1.2 Spending; or 2.1.3 One of Congress’s limited police power areas: - The military; - Indian reservations; - Federal land or property; or - The District of Columbia.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the basic scope of Congress’s taxing and spending power, and in what types of situations is it usually the correct basis for federal authority on the bar exam?
cards.cloze: 1. Basic scope of the taxing and spending power 1.1 Congress may {{c1::tax and spend}} in any way it deems necessary to provide for the {{c2::general welfare}}. 1.2 This "{{c3::general welfare}}" standard is interpreted {{c4::very broadly}}. 2. Typical bar exam context 2.1 On bar exam questions, Congress’s taxing and spending power is usually the correct basis for federal authority when the statute concerns: 2.1.1 {{c5::Taxation}}; 2.1.2 {{c6::Spending}}; or 2.1.3 One of Congress’s limited {{c7::police power}} areas: - The {{c8::military}}; - {{c9::Indian reservations}}; - {{c10::federal land or property}}; or - The {{c11::District of Columbia}}.
cards.easyContent: Congress may tax and spend for the general welfare, which is read very broadly, and this is usually the right basis for federal authority when a bar exam question involves a federal tax, federal spending, or one of Congress’s limited police power areas like the military, Indian reservations, federal property, or D.C.
cards.mediumContent: Congress’s taxing and spending power authorizes it to tax and spend in any way it deems necessary to provide for the general welfare, and courts interpret this standard very broadly. On bar exam questions, this power is usually the correct constitutional basis for federal action when a statute involves taxation, federal spending, or one of Congress’s limited police power domains—namely the military, Indian reservations, federal land or property, and the District of Columbia.
cards.hardContent: The Constitution grants Congress the power to tax and spend to provide for the general welfare, a grant that the Supreme Court interprets extremely broadly. In practice, this means Congress may structure federal taxes and spending programs in almost any manner so long as the aim is plausibly related to promoting the general welfare of the nation. On the bar exam, this taxing and spending power is typically the correct basis of authority whenever a federal statute deals with taxation, the disbursement of federal funds, or one of the few contexts in which Congress has something like general police power: the military, Indian reservations, federal land and property, and the District of Columbia.
cards.mnemonic: T-S-MIFD: Tax, Spend, Military, Indians, Federal land, D.C.
cards.clozeLite: Congress may {{c1::tax and spend}} in any way it deems necessary to provide for the {{c2::general welfare}}, a power read {{c3::very broadly}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Taxing & Spending Power – Taxes, Revenue Requirement, and Penalties as Taxes
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 009-2. Taxing & Spending Power – Taxes, Revenue Requirement, and Penalties as Taxes
cards.front: Taxing & Spending Power – Taxes, Revenue Requirement, and Penalties as Taxes
cards.backPlain: 1. Revenue requirement for taxes 1.1 To qualify as a valid tax, a federal charge must reasonably relate to revenue production. 1.2 This reasonable relationship standard is a low threshold. 2. Penalties functioning as taxes 2.1 A measure labeled as a "penalty" rather than a "tax" may still be upheld under the taxing power. 2.2 The key question is whether the measure behaves similarly to a tax, such as: - It is collected by the tax authorities; - It is calculated by reference to income, status, or similar tax-like factors; and - It is not so punitive as to be purely regulatory. 2.3 Example: The Affordable Care Act individual mandate payment was treated as a tax because it functioned like a tax, even though Congress called it a penalty.
cards.frontPrompt: What minimal revenue requirement must a federal tax satisfy, and when can a measure labeled as a penalty be sustained as a valid exercise of the taxing power?
cards.cloze: 1. Revenue requirement for taxes 1.1 To qualify as a valid {{c1::tax}}, a federal charge must {{c2::reasonably relate to revenue production}}. 1.2 This {{c3::reasonable relationship}} standard is a {{c4::low threshold}}. 2. Penalties functioning as taxes 2.1 A measure labeled as a "{{c5::penalty}}" rather than a "{{c6::tax}}" may still be upheld under the {{c7::taxing power}}. 2.2 The key question is whether the measure {{c8::behaves similarly to a tax}}, such as: - It is {{c9::collected by the tax authorities}}; - It is {{c10::calculated by reference to income, status, or similar tax-like factors}}; and - It is {{c11::not so punitive as to be purely regulatory}}. 2.3 Example: The {{c12::Affordable Care Act individual mandate}} payment was treated as a {{c13::tax}} because it {{c14::functioned like a tax}}, even though Congress called it a {{c15::penalty}}.
cards.easyContent: A federal charge is a valid tax if it reasonably relates to raising revenue, which is an easy standard to meet. Even something labeled a penalty can be upheld under the taxing power if it operates like a tax—for example, the ACA individual mandate payment.
cards.mediumContent: Congress’s power to tax is subject to only a minimal requirement: the exaction must reasonably relate to raising revenue. This is a very low bar. Moreover, Congress’s label is not controlling; a charge called a "penalty" can still be sustained as a tax if it behaves like a tax—collected through the tax system, calculated using tax-like factors, and not so punitive as to be purely a regulatory sanction. The Affordable Care Act’s individual mandate payment is the classic example.
cards.hardContent: For an exaction to qualify as a valid exercise of Congress’s taxing power, it must bear a reasonable relationship to revenue production, a standard that is easily satisfied in most cases. Courts will look beyond labels: a so-called "penalty" may be upheld as a tax if its practical operation is tax-like—for instance, if it is assessed and collected by the IRS, calculated based on income or other standard tax criteria, and is not so severe as to be purely punitive. In such circumstances, the measure is treated as a tax authorized by the taxing power, as with the Affordable Care Act individual mandate, which the Court sustained because it functioned in substance as a tax despite being described as a penalty.
cards.mnemonic: R-FIT: Reasonable revenue; Functions like tax; Income-based; not Too punitive.
cards.clozeLite: A federal {{c1::exaction is a valid tax}} if it {{c2::reasonably relates to raising revenue}} and a {{c3::“penalty”}} is valid if it {{c4::functions like a tax rather than a punitive sanction}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Taxing & Spending Power – Regulatory Taxes and Regulatory Spending
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 009-3. Taxing & Spending Power – Regulatory Taxes and Regulatory Spending
cards.front: Taxing & Spending Power – Regulatory Taxes and Regulatory Spending
cards.backPlain: 1. Regulatory taxes 1.1 Congress can use taxes to achieve a regulatory effect. 1.2 A regulatory tax is valid if: 1.2.1 The tax’s dominant intent is to raise revenue; and 1.2.2 There is some reasonable relationship between the tax and the regulation or conduct being influenced. 1.3 The reasonable relationship requirement is a low burden to satisfy. 2. Regulatory spending (conditional funding) 2.1 Congress can use its spending power to regulate indirectly by attaching conditions to the receipt of federal funds. 2.2 These conditions must not be overly or unduly coercive, especially when imposed on the states. 2.3 If the conditions are non-coercive and tied to the federal program, Congress may influence or regulate behavior through conditional funding.
cards.frontPrompt: When may Congress use its taxing and spending power to regulate behavior through regulatory taxes and conditional spending, and what are the key limits on these tools?
cards.cloze: 1. Regulatory taxes 1.1 Congress can use {{c1::taxes}} to achieve a {{c2::regulatory effect}}. 1.2 A regulatory tax is valid if: 1.2.1 The tax’s {{c3::dominant intent}} is to {{c4::raise revenue}}; and 1.2.2 There is some {{c5::reasonable relationship}} between the tax and the {{c6::regulation or conduct}} being influenced. 1.3 The {{c7::reasonable relationship}} requirement is a {{c8::low burden}} to satisfy. 2. Regulatory spending (conditional funding) 2.1 Congress can use its {{c9::spending power}} to regulate indirectly by attaching {{c10::conditions}} to the receipt of {{c11::federal funds}}. 2.2 These conditions must {{c12::not be overly or unduly coercive}}, especially when imposed on the {{c13::states}}. 2.3 If the conditions are {{c14::non-coercive}} and {{c15::tied to the federal program}}, Congress may {{c16::influence or regulate behavior}} through {{c17::conditional funding}}.
cards.easyContent: Congress may use taxes and spending to regulate behavior. A regulatory tax is valid if it mainly raises revenue and is reasonably related to the regulated conduct. Congress may also put non-coercive, program-related conditions on federal funds to influence state or private conduct.
cards.mediumContent: Congress can achieve regulatory goals through its taxing and spending power. A tax intended in part to influence behavior remains valid so long as its dominant purpose is still to raise revenue and there is some reasonable relationship between the tax and the targeted conduct—a low bar. Similarly, Congress may use its spending power to regulate indirectly by attaching conditions to federal funds, provided those conditions are not overly coercive and are related to the federal program.
cards.hardContent: The taxing and spending power allows Congress to shape behavior through both regulatory taxes and conditional spending. A regulatory tax is permissible when, despite its behavioral influence, its primary or dominant objective is revenue generation and there exists at least a modest, reasonable connection between the tax and the activity or conduct being targeted. Courts are deferential on this point, making the requirement relatively easy to satisfy. On the spending side, Congress may condition the receipt of federal funds on compliance with certain requirements, thereby exerting regulatory leverage, but those conditions must not be unduly or overly coercive—particularly vis-à-vis the states—and should be sufficiently related to the federal program. If those limits are respected, Congress can effectively regulate through conditional funding even where it might lack direct regulatory authority.
cards.mnemonic: RRC-NCR: Revenue, Reasonable link; Conditions Non-Coercive, Related.
cards.clozeLite: Congress may {{c1::regulate behavior}} via {{c2::regulatory taxes}} and {{c3::conditional spending}}, if taxes {{c4::primarily raise revenue}} and conditions are {{c5::non-coercive and program-related}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 011-1. Commerce Power – Interstate Commerce Categories
cards.front: Commerce Power – Interstate Commerce Categories
cards.backPlain: Under the Commerce Clause, Congress has broad power to regulate interstate commerce. 1. Channels of interstate commerce 1.1 Congress may regulate the channels of interstate commerce, such as highways, waterways, and air traffic corridors. 2. Instrumentalities, persons, and things 2.1 Congress may regulate the instrumentalities of interstate commerce, such as trucks, planes, and trains. 2.2 Congress may also regulate persons and things in interstate commerce. 3. Economic activities with substantial effects 3.1 Congress may regulate economic activities that, in the aggregate, have a substantial effect on interstate commerce. 3.2 This is a broad power; be wary of arguments that Congress has exceeded its power when regulating interstate economic activity under this category.
cards.frontPrompt: What categories of interstate commerce may Congress regulate under the Commerce Clause?
cards.cloze: Under the {{c1::Commerce Clause}}, Congress has broad power to regulate {{c2::interstate commerce}}. 1. {{c3::Channels of interstate commerce}} (e.g., highways, waterways, air traffic corridors). 2. {{c4::Instrumentalities of interstate commerce}} (e.g., trucks, planes, trains) and {{c5::persons and things in interstate commerce}}. 3. {{c6::Economic activities}} that, in the {{c7::aggregate}}, have a {{c8::substantial effect}} on interstate commerce. This is a {{c9::broad power}} when Congress regulates interstate economic activity.
cards.easyContent: Congress can regulate (1) channels of interstate commerce, (2) instrumentalities of interstate commerce and persons/things in interstate commerce, and (3) economic activities that, in the aggregate, substantially affect interstate commerce.
cards.mediumContent: For interstate commerce, Congress may regulate the channels (e.g., roads, waterways, air routes), the instrumentalities (e.g., trucks, planes, trains), persons and things in interstate commerce, and economic activities that in the aggregate have a substantial effect on interstate commerce. This is a very broad grant of power when interstate economic activity is involved.
cards.hardContent: Congress’s interstate commerce power allows regulation of (1) the channels of interstate commerce, including highways, waterways, and air traffic; (2) the instrumentalities of interstate commerce, such as trucks, planes, and trains, as well as persons and things in interstate commerce; and (3) economic activities that, in the aggregate, have a substantial effect on interstate commerce. Courts are generally deferential when Congress regulates interstate economic activity under the substantial effects category.
cards.mnemonic: For interstate commerce, think ‘CIP’: Channels, Instrumentalities, and economic activities with a substantial effect.
cards.clozeLite: Congress may regulate {{c1::channels of interstate commerce}}, {{c2::instrumentalities and persons/things in interstate commerce}}, and {{c3::economic activities with a substantial aggregate effect}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Commerce Power – Intrastate Economic vs. Non‑Economic Activity
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 011-2. Commerce Power – Intrastate Economic vs. Non‑Economic Activity
cards.front: Commerce Power – Intrastate Economic vs. Non‑Economic Activity
cards.backPlain: Congress’s power to regulate intrastate commerce (activity within a single state) depends on whether the activity is economic or non‑economic. 1. Intrastate economic activity 1.1 Congress may regulate intrastate commercial or economic activities if there is a rational basis to conclude that the activity, in the aggregate, substantially affects interstate commerce. 2. Intrastate non‑economic activity 2.1 Congress may regulate intrastate non‑economic activity only if it has a direct, substantial economic effect on interstate commerce. 2.2 This is a tougher burden to satisfy than for economic activity.
cards.frontPrompt: How does Congress’s power to regulate intrastate commerce differ for economic vs. non‑economic activity under the Commerce Clause?
cards.cloze: Congress’s power to regulate {{c1::intrastate commerce}} depends on whether the activity is {{c2::economic}} or {{c3::non‑economic}}. 1. {{c4::Intrastate economic activity}}: Congress may regulate if there is a {{c5::rational basis}} to conclude that the activity, in the {{c6::aggregate}}, {{c7::substantially affects interstate commerce}}. 2. {{c8::Intrastate non‑economic activity}}: Congress may regulate only if the activity itself has a {{c9::direct, substantial economic effect}} on interstate commerce—a {{c10::tougher burden}} than for economic activity.
cards.easyContent: For intrastate economic activity, Congress needs only a rational basis to think the activity in the aggregate substantially affects interstate commerce. For intrastate non‑economic activity, Congress must show a direct, substantial economic effect on interstate commerce.
cards.mediumContent: Intrastate commercial or economic activity may be regulated when Congress has a rational basis to conclude that, in the aggregate, the activity substantially affects interstate commerce. Intrastate non‑economic activity, by contrast, may be regulated only if the activity has a direct, substantial economic effect on interstate commerce, a significantly stricter standard.
cards.hardContent: When activity occurs wholly within a single state, the Commerce Clause analysis turns on whether the activity is economic. For intrastate commercial or economic activity, Congress may regulate if it could reasonably find that, in the aggregate, such activity substantially affects interstate commerce. For intrastate non‑economic activity, Congress’s power is more limited: it may regulate only where the activity itself has a direct, substantial economic effect on interstate commerce, making this a much tougher standard to meet.
cards.mnemonic: Economic = Easy aggregate; Non‑economic = Needs direct substantial effect.
cards.clozeLite: Intrastate {{c1::economic activity}} is regulated on a {{c2::rational basis}} using {{c3::aggregate substantial effects}}; {{c4::non‑economic activity}} needs a {{c5::direct, substantial economic effect}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 011-3. Dormant Commerce Clause – Overview
cards.front: Dormant Commerce Clause – Overview
cards.backPlain: The Dormant Commerce Clause (also called the negative Commerce Clause) is an implied limit on state power derived from the Commerce Clause. 1. Basic concept 1.1 Even when Congress has not enacted legislation, state laws may not unduly burden interstate commerce. 1.2 The Dormant Commerce Clause limits state laws that burden interstate commerce by interfering with Congress’s commerce power. 2. Relationship to Congress’s power 2.1 The doctrine arises from the grant of power to Congress over interstate commerce and reflects the idea that states may not enact protectionist or unduly burdensome regulations that frustrate a national market. (Details of the specific tests for discrimination vs. incidental burdens are covered in separate cards.)
cards.frontPrompt: What is the Dormant Commerce Clause, and how does it limit state power in relation to Congress’s commerce power?
cards.cloze: The {{c1::Dormant Commerce Clause}} (or {{c2::negative Commerce Clause}}) is an {{c3::implied limit on state power}} derived from the {{c4::Commerce Clause}}. 1. Even when {{c5::Congress has not acted}}, state laws may not {{c6::unduly burden interstate commerce}}. 2. The Dormant Commerce Clause limits {{c7::state laws that burden interstate commerce}} by {{c8::interfering with Congress’s commerce power}}.
cards.easyContent: The Dormant Commerce Clause is an implied limit on state power that prevents states from passing laws that unduly burden interstate commerce, even when Congress has not legislated.
cards.mediumContent: The Dormant Commerce Clause (negative Commerce Clause) arises from the Commerce Clause’s grant of power to Congress. It restricts states from enacting laws that unduly burden or interfere with interstate commerce, even in the absence of federal legislation.
cards.hardContent: The Dormant Commerce Clause, or negative Commerce Clause, is a judge‑made doctrine inferred from the grant of power to Congress over interstate commerce. It operates as an implied limit on state and local laws that burden interstate commerce by interfering with a national economic union, even when Congress has chosen not to regulate. While the specific tests differ for discriminatory versus incidentally burdensome laws, the core idea is that states may not enact protectionist or unduly burdensome regulations that undermine Congress’s commerce power.
cards.mnemonic: Dormant = Congress asleep, but states still blocked from burdening interstate trade.
cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::Dormant Commerce Clause}} is an {{c2::implied limit on state laws}} that {{c3::unduly burden interstate commerce}} even {{c4::without federal legislation}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Tenth Amendment – General Rule, Anti-Commandeering, and Dual Application
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 012-1. Tenth Amendment – General Rule, Anti-Commandeering, and Dual Application
cards.front: Tenth Amendment – General Rule, Anti-Commandeering, and Dual Application
cards.frontPrompt: What does the Tenth Amendment reserve to the states, and how does it limit Congress’s ability to regulate or tax states as states, including the anti-commandeering rule and generally applicable (dual application) laws?
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule (Tenth Amendment) 1.1 Under the Tenth Amendment, all powers not granted to the federal government, nor prohibited to the states, are reserved to the states. 1.2 This limits Congress’s ability to regulate or tax states as states. 2. Anti-commandeering principle 2.1 Congress cannot require states to enact laws or administer federal law; it may not commandeer state legislative or executive processes. 3. Dual application (generally applicable laws) 3.1 Federal regulations that apply to both the public and private sectors are usually valid. 3.2 Example: federal minimum wage laws can apply to state and local governments as well as private employers. 4. Exception – civil rights enforcement 4.1 Congress may restrict state activities that violate civil liberties and civil rights. 4.2 Example: using its Fourteenth Amendment enforcement power to prohibit or remedy state violations of constitutional rights.
cards.cloze: Under the {{c1::Tenth Amendment}}, all powers not granted to the {{c2::federal government}}, nor prohibited to the {{c3::states}}, are {{c4::reserved to the states}}. This limits Congress’s ability to {{c5::regulate or tax states as states}}. Under the {{c6::anti-commandeering}} principle, Congress cannot require states to {{c7::enact laws}} or {{c8::administer federal law}}, and thus may not commandeer state {{c9::legislative}} or {{c10::executive}} processes. However, federal regulations that are {{c11::generally applicable}}—i.e., that apply to both the {{c12::public}} and {{c13::private}} sectors—are usually valid (for example, {{c14::federal minimum wage}} laws can bind state and local governments). Congress may also restrict state activities that violate {{c15::civil liberties and civil rights}}, including through its {{c16::Fourteenth Amendment}} enforcement power.
cards.easyContent: The Tenth Amendment reserves to the states powers not given to the federal government or denied to the states, so Congress cannot directly regulate or tax states as states in a way that forces them to legislate or administer federal programs. But Congress can still regulate states through generally applicable laws that also apply to private actors, and can restrict state conduct that violates civil rights using powers like the Fourteenth Amendment.
cards.mediumContent: Under the Tenth Amendment, powers not granted to the federal government nor prohibited to the states are reserved to the states. This limits Congress’s power to regulate or tax states in their sovereign capacity and gives rise to the anti-commandeering rule: Congress cannot require state legislatures to enact laws or state executives to administer federal regulatory programs. At the same time, federal laws of general applicability—those that apply to both public and private actors, such as federal minimum wage requirements—can constitutionally bind states. Congress may also directly restrict or remedy state conduct that violates civil liberties and civil rights, including via its Fourteenth Amendment enforcement power.
cards.hardContent: The Tenth Amendment’s reservation of powers to the states where authority has neither been delegated to the federal government nor denied to the states constrains Congress’s ability to treat states as mere administrative subdivisions. Congress may not regulate or tax states as states in ways that effectively compel them to govern according to federal instructions, and it may not commandeer state governmental machinery by requiring state legislatures to enact particular laws or state executive officials to administer or enforce federal regulatory schemes. This anti-commandeering doctrine preserves the political accountability of both state and federal governments. Nonetheless, Congress may subject states to federal laws that are generally applicable to both public and private actors—for example, wage-and-hour laws that apply to all employers, including state and local governments. In addition, Congress can affirmatively restrict state conduct that infringes civil liberties and civil rights, such as through its enforcement power under Section 5 of the Fourteenth Amendment.
cards.mnemonic: Tenth core: RAG—Reserved powers, Anti-commandeering, Generally applicable laws allowed.
cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::Tenth Amendment}} reserves {{c2::powers not granted to the federal government nor prohibited to the states}}, creating {{c3::anti-commandeering}} but allowing {{c4::generally applicable federal laws}} to bind states.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Tenth Amendment – Conditional Federal Grants to States
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 012-2. Tenth Amendment – Conditional Federal Grants to States
cards.front: Tenth Amendment – Conditional Federal Grants to States
cards.frontPrompt: How may Congress use conditional grants to influence state regulatory or legislative action, and what are the constitutional requirements for valid conditions on federal grants to states?
cards.backPlain: 1. Use of conditional grants 1.1 Congress can induce, but not compel, state regulatory or legislative action through the use of conditional grants. 1.2 Example: conditioning federal highway funds on a minimum drinking age of 21. 2. Requirements for valid conditions on federal grants 2.1 The condition must be expressly stated so that states know the terms upon which funds are offered. 2.2 The condition must relate to the purpose of the law or program at issue (a relatedness or "germaneness" requirement). 2.3 The condition cannot be unduly coercive; Congress may not effectively leave states with no real choice but to accept the funds and conditions.
cards.cloze: Congress may use {{c1::conditional grants}} of federal funds to {{c2::induce, but not compel}}, state regulatory or legislative action (for example, conditioning {{c3::highway funds}} on a minimum drinking age of {{c4::21}}). For conditions on federal grants to be valid: - The condition must be {{c5::expressly stated}}, so states clearly understand the terms. - The condition must {{c6::relate to the purpose}} of the underlying law or program (a {{c7::germaneness}} requirement). - The condition cannot be {{c8::unduly coercive}}; Congress cannot so heavily penalize refusal that states have no real choice.
cards.easyContent: Congress can encourage, but not force, states to act by attaching conditions to federal funds. Those conditions must be clearly stated, related to the purpose of the program, and not so harsh that states have no real choice but to accept them.
cards.mediumContent: To respect the Tenth Amendment, Congress cannot directly command state legislatures or executives, but it can influence state policy through spending. Congress may attach conditions to federal grants that induce states to adopt certain laws or regulations, such as tying highway funds to a minimum drinking age. These conditions are valid only if (1) they are expressly and clearly stated, (2) they bear a reasonable relationship to the purpose of the federal program or law, and (3) they are not unduly coercive, meaning the financial pressure is not so extreme that states effectively have no voluntary choice.
cards.hardContent: Congress’s spending power allows it to achieve indirectly, through conditional grants, some objectives it could not mandate directly under the Tenth Amendment. Congress may offer federal funds to states subject to conditions designed to encourage states to legislate or regulate in particular ways, such as conditioning highway funds on a uniform drinking age. However, to be constitutional, such conditions must be (1) unambiguously and expressly stated so states can knowingly decide whether to accept the funds, (2) related (germane) to the federal interest in the particular national program or project being funded, and (3) not unduly coercive. If the threatened loss of funds is so substantial that refusal is not a realistic option, the financial inducement crosses the line into unconstitutional coercion.
cards.mnemonic: CER: Clear, End-related, not Restrictive/coercive.
cards.clozeLite: Congress may {{c1::influence state policy}} via {{c2::conditional federal grants}}, if conditions are {{c3::clear}}, {{c4::related to the program}}, and {{c5::not unduly coercive}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 013-1. Congressional Delegation – Scope and Limits
cards.front: Congressional Delegation – Scope and Limits
cards.backPlain: Congress has broad authority to delegate legislative powers to executive officers and administrative agencies via enabling statutes. Administrative agencies established by congressional enabling acts can create rules that have the force and effect of law. 1. Scope of delegation 1.1 Congress may authorize agencies and executive officers to fill in the details of statutory schemes, make policy choices within a statutory framework, and promulgate rules that operate with the force of law. 1.2 Courts generally uphold delegations and rarely invalidate statutes on nondelegation grounds. 2. Limitations on delegation 2.1 Intelligible standard requirement 2.1.1 Congress must provide intelligible standards to define and guide the scope of the legislative authority it delegates (e.g., directing an agency to regulate "in the public interest" has been accepted). 2.2 No self‑delegated enforcement power 2.2.1 Congress may not delegate executive or judicial powers to itself or its own officers. 2.2.2 Congress cannot create commissions under its control that enforce or prosecute violations of law and then retain control over those enforcement decisions, because execution of the laws is an executive function. 2.3 Exam tip 2.3.1 Because the delegation power is broad and courts are highly deferential, be wary of answer choices that rely on excessive delegation as a limitation on congressional authority.
cards.frontPrompt: How broad is Congress’s power to delegate legislative authority to agencies, and what key limits—especially the intelligible standard requirement and the bar on Congress reserving enforcement power to itself—apply to such delegations?
cards.cloze: Congress has {{c1::broad authority to delegate legislative powers}} to executive officers and administrative agencies via enabling statutes, and agency rules can have the {{c2::force and effect of law}}. 1. Scope of delegation 1.1 Congress may authorize agencies to {{c3::fill in statutory details, make policy choices within a framework, and promulgate rules with the force of law}}. 1.2 Courts {{c4::rarely invalidate}} delegations on nondelegation grounds. 2. Limitations on delegation 2.1 Congress must provide {{c5::intelligible standards}} to define and guide the scope of delegated authority. 2.2 Congress may not {{c6::delegate executive or judicial enforcement powers to itself or its own officers}} (e.g., by creating congressional commissions that enforce or prosecute law while under congressional control). 2.3 On exams, because delegation doctrine is {{c7::very broad and deferential}}, answer choices resting on {{c8::“excessive delegation”}} are usually wrong.
cards.easyContent: Congress may broadly delegate rulemaking power to agencies if it provides an intelligible standard and does not keep enforcement power for itself or its officers. Courts almost never strike down statutes for excessive delegation, so those answers are usually wrong on the exam.
cards.mediumContent: Congress can delegate legislative authority to agencies and executive officers through enabling statutes, allowing them to adopt rules with the force of law and to fill in policy details. Delegation is limited mainly by the requirement that Congress give intelligible standards to guide the exercise of that power and that it not reserve executive or judicial enforcement functions to itself or congressional officers. Because courts are highly deferential, nondelegation challenges almost always fail, making “excessive delegation” a weak exam answer.
cards.hardContent: Congress enjoys broad power to delegate legislative authority to executive officers and administrative agencies by statute. Under these enabling acts, agencies may adopt rules and regulations that carry the force and effect of law and may fill in the interstitial details or policy choices left open by Congress. The principal limits are modest: Congress must articulate intelligible standards to define and guide the exercise of delegated discretion, and it may not reserve executive or judicial enforcement powers to itself or its officers, such as by establishing congressional commissions that investigate, prosecute, or otherwise execute the laws while remaining under congressional control. Given the Supreme Court’s highly deferential nondelegation jurisprudence, statutes are almost never struck down as excessive delegations, so bar‑exam answers that rely solely on a theory of “too much delegation” are usually incorrect.
cards.mnemonic: BIG: Broad delegation, Intelligible standard, no Government self-enforcement.
cards.clozeLite: Congress may broadly delegate if it gives an {{c1::intelligible standard}} and {{c2::does not reserve enforcement power to itself}}; {{c3::nondelegation challenges almost always fail}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 013-2. Legislative Vetoes and Line‑Item Vetoes
cards.front: Legislative Vetoes and Line‑Item Vetoes
cards.backPlain: Congress’s broad delegation power does not permit it or the President to use mechanisms that bypass the constitutional lawmaking process. 1. Legislative veto 1.1 Definition 1.1.1 A legislative veto is an attempt by Congress to overturn or block an action taken by an agency pursuant to delegated authority by passing a resolution—often by one house, or sometimes both houses—without going through the full legislative process. 1.2 Unconstitutionality 1.2.1 Legislative vetoes are unconstitutional. 1.2.2 Congress cannot veto a decision by an agency acting pursuant to delegated power through a one‑house or two‑house resolution without presentment to the President. 1.2.3 To change or override agency action taken under a valid delegation, Congress must enact a superseding law that satisfies bicameralism (passage by both houses) and presentment (submission to the President for signature or veto). 2. Presidential line‑item veto 2.1 Definition 2.1.1 A line‑item veto is a purported power of the President to approve a bill generally but cancel or veto specific provisions (such as spending items) after it has been passed by Congress. 2.2 Unconstitutionality 2.2.1 The line‑item veto is unconstitutional. 2.2.2 The President cannot veto only part of a bill; a line‑item veto would be an impermissible delegation of legislative power to the President because it effectively allows unilateral amendment or repeal of parts of duly enacted statutes. 2.2.3 Under the Presentment Clause, the President must either sign or veto a bill in its entirety.
cards.frontPrompt: What are legislative vetoes and presidential line‑item vetoes, and why are both unconstitutional under the requirements of bicameralism and presentment and the separation of legislative and executive powers?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Legislative veto}} 1.1 A legislative veto is an attempt by Congress to {{c2::overturn or block agency action}} taken under delegated authority by passing a {{c3::one‑house or two‑house resolution}} without following the full lawmaking process. 1.2 Legislative vetoes are {{c4::unconstitutional}} because Congress must comply with {{c5::bicameralism and presentment}} to change legal rights or obligations. To override agency action, Congress must enact a {{c6::superseding law passed by both houses and presented to the President}}. 2. {{c7::Presidential line‑item veto}} 2.1 A line‑item veto is the supposed power of the President to {{c8::approve a bill but cancel specific provisions}} (e.g., spending items) after enactment. 2.2 The line‑item veto is {{c9::unconstitutional}}. The President cannot {{c10::veto only part of a bill}}; doing so would be an impermissible {{c11::delegation of legislative power to the President}} because it lets the President {{c12::unilaterally amend or repeal parts of statutes}}. Under the Presentment Clause, the President must {{c13::sign or veto a bill in its entirety}}.
cards.easyContent: A legislative veto is Congress’s attempt to overturn agency action by resolution without passing a new law; it is unconstitutional because it bypasses bicameralism and presentment. A presidential line‑item veto—canceling parts of a bill—is also unconstitutional because the President must sign or veto an entire bill and cannot be given power to rewrite statutes.
cards.mediumContent: Legislative vetoes occur when Congress tries to block or reverse agency actions authorized by delegation through a one‑house or even two‑house resolution that is not presented to the President. They are unconstitutional because Congress must change legal rights through the ordinary lawmaking process, which requires bicameral passage and presentment. The presidential line‑item veto, under which the President purports to cancel specific portions of an enacted bill, is likewise unconstitutional: it violates the Presentment Clause and amounts to an impermissible transfer of legislative power by letting the President effectively amend or repeal parts of statutes, rather than simply signing or vetoing the bill as a whole.
cards.hardContent: Congress cannot control delegated authority or reallocate legislative power through mechanisms that circumvent the Constitution’s lawmaking requirements. A legislative veto arises when Congress attempts to overturn or block agency action taken pursuant to delegated authority by passing a resolution—whether by one house alone or by both houses—that is not enacted as a new statute subject to presentment. The Supreme Court has held such legislative vetoes unconstitutional because any change to legal rights or obligations must satisfy bicameralism (approval by both houses) and presentment (submission to the President for approval or veto). Similarly, the presidential line‑item veto, which would allow the President to approve a bill generally while canceling discrete provisions (such as particular spending items), is unconstitutional. It contravenes the Presentment Clause by empowering the President to unilaterally amend or repeal portions of duly enacted statutes, an impermissible delegation and exercise of legislative power; instead, the President must either sign or veto a bill in its entirety.
cards.mnemonic: Two bad vetoes: Congress skips steps; President slices statutes.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::legislative veto}} is invalid for bypassing {{c2::bicameralism and presentment}}; a {{c3::presidential line‑item veto}} is invalid for letting the President {{c4::amend or repeal parts of bills}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Appointment Powers – Principal vs. Inferior Officers
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 014-1. Appointment Powers – Principal vs. Inferior Officers
cards.front: Appointment Powers – Principal vs. Inferior Officers
cards.backPlain: 1. Appointment of principal officers 1.1 President and Senate 1.1.1 Under the Appointments Clause, the President appoints ambassadors, federal judges, and other principal (high‑level) officers with the advice and consent of the Senate. 2. Appointment of inferior officers 2.1 Congress’s role 2.1.1 Congress cannot give itself appointment powers. 2.1.2 Congress may, by statute, vest the appointment of inferior officers in: - the President alone, - the courts of law, or - the heads of departments or agencies. 2.2 Definition of inferior officers 2.2.1 Inferior officers are typically those who: - work under presidentially appointed principal officers, and - can be removed by those principal officers.
cards.frontPrompt: How are principal and inferior federal officers appointed, and what role can Congress play in the appointment of inferior officers?
cards.cloze: 1. Appointment of {{c1::principal officers}} 1.1 {{c2::President and Senate}} 1.1.1 Under the {{c3::Appointments Clause}}, the {{c4::President}} appoints {{c5::ambassadors, federal judges, and other principal (high‑level) officers}} with the {{c6::advice and consent of the Senate}}. 2. Appointment of {{c7::inferior officers}} 2.1 {{c8::Congress’s role}} 2.1.1 Congress {{c9::cannot give itself appointment powers}}. 2.1.2 Congress may vest the appointment of inferior officers in the {{c10::President alone}}, the {{c11::courts of law}}, or the {{c12::heads of departments or agencies}}. 2.2 Definition of {{c13::inferior officers}} 2.2.1 They are typically those who {{c14::work under presidentially appointed principal officers}} and {{c15::can be removed by those principal officers}}.
cards.easyContent: The President, with Senate consent, appoints principal officers like ambassadors, federal judges, and Cabinet members. Congress cannot appoint officers itself, but it can allow the President, courts, or department heads to appoint inferior officers, who work under and are removable by principal officers.
cards.mediumContent: Principal officers are appointed by the President with the advice and consent of the Senate. Congress may not reserve appointment power for itself, but it may vest the appointment of inferior officers—subordinates who work under and are removable by principal officers—in the President alone, the courts, or heads of departments or agencies.
cards.hardContent: Under the Appointments Clause, the President appoints ambassadors, federal judges, and other principal (high‑level) officers with the advice and consent of the Senate. Congress cannot give itself or its leaders appointment authority, but it may, by statute, vest the appointment of inferior officers in the President alone, the courts of law, or heads of departments or agencies. Inferior officers are generally those who are supervised by, and removable by, presidentially appointed principal officers, distinguishing them from principal officers who require Senate confirmation.
cards.mnemonic: P + S for Principals; P/C/H for Inferiors
cards.clozeLite: Principal officers: {{c1::President with Senate consent}}. Congress may vest {{c2::inferior officer}} appointments in {{c3::President alone}}, {{c4::courts}}, or {{c5::heads of departments}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 014-2. Removal Powers – President and Congress
cards.front: Removal Powers – President and Congress
cards.backPlain: 1. Presidential removal power 1.1 High‑level executive officers 1.1.1 The President may remove high‑level executive officers (e.g., Cabinet members) as part of the executive power. 1.2 Other executive appointees 1.2.1 Congress may, by statute, limit the President’s power to remove certain executive officials, such as independent agency heads, by requiring good cause or similar standards for removal. 2. Congressional removal power 2.1 No general removal authority 2.1.1 Congress has no general power to remove executive officers; it may not reserve removal power for itself. 2.2 Impeachment as Congress’s removal mechanism 2.2.1 Congress may remove executive officers only through the impeachment process, not through ordinary legislation or resolutions. 2.2.2 Article III judges similarly cannot be removed by Congress except through impeachment and conviction.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the President’s power to remove executive officers, and what limits does Congress have on directly removing those officers or Article III judges?
