cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Presidential removal power}} 1.1 {{c2::High‑level executive officers}} 1.1.1 The {{c3::President}} may remove {{c4::high‑level executive officers}} as part of the executive power. 1.2 {{c5::Other executive appointees}} 1.2.1 {{c6::Congress}} may, by statute, {{c7::limit the President’s power to remove certain executive officials}}, for example by requiring {{c8::good cause}} for removal. 2. {{c9::Congressional removal power}} 2.1 {{c10::No general removal authority}} 2.1.1 Congress has {{c11::no general power to remove executive officers}} and may not {{c12::reserve removal power for itself}}. 2.2 {{c13::Impeachment as Congress’s removal mechanism}} 2.2.1 Congress may remove executive officers only through the {{c14::impeachment process}}, not by ordinary legislation or resolutions. 2.2.2 {{c15::Article III judges}} likewise cannot be removed by Congress except through {{c16::impeachment and conviction}}.
cards.easyContent: The President can remove high‑level executive officers, and Congress can limit removal of some officials by requiring good cause. Congress has no general power to remove executive officers or Article III judges directly; it can remove them only through impeachment and conviction.
cards.mediumContent: The President has the power to remove high‑level executive officers and, subject to statutory good‑cause limits, other executive appointees. Congress cannot reserve general removal power for itself; it may only constrain presidential removal by statute and may remove executive officers and Article III judges only through impeachment and conviction.
cards.hardContent: As part of the executive power, the President may remove high‑level executive officers such as Cabinet members. For certain other executive officials—often in independent or quasi‑independent agencies—Congress may impose good‑cause or similar restrictions on removal, so long as they do not unduly interfere with the President’s constitutional functions. Congress itself has no general removal authority over officers; it may not reserve removal power for itself or its committees. Instead, Congress’s only mechanism to remove executive officers or Article III judges is through impeachment and conviction, not by ordinary statutes or resolutions.
cards.mnemonic: President fires; Congress impeaches.
cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::President}} may remove {{c2::high-level executive officers}}, while {{c3::Congress}} may only remove {{c4::executive officers and Article III judges}} through {{c5::impeachment and conviction}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 014-3. Impeachment – Standards and Procedure
cards.front: Impeachment – Standards and Procedure
cards.backPlain: 1. Who may be impeached and for what 1.1 Officers subject to impeachment 1.1.1 The President, Vice President, federal judges (including Article III judges), and other federal civil officers may be impeached. 1.2 Grounds for impeachment 1.2.1 Impeachment lies for treason, bribery, or other high crimes and misdemeanors. 2. Impeachment in the House of Representatives 2.1 Charging decision 2.1.1 The House of Representatives has the sole power of impeachment. 2.1.2 A simple majority vote in the House is required to impeach (to formally charge the officer). 3. Trial and removal in the Senate 3.1 Senate trial 3.1.1 Once impeached, the officer is tried in the Senate. 3.2 Vote required for conviction and removal 3.2.1 Conviction and removal from office require the constitutionally required supermajority vote in the Senate (e.g., two‑thirds of Senators present under the federal Constitution).
cards.frontPrompt: Who can be impeached, on what grounds, and what are the respective roles and voting thresholds of the House and Senate in the impeachment process?
cards.cloze: 1. Who may be impeached and for what 1.1 {{c1::Officers subject to impeachment}} 1.1.1 The {{c2::President}}, {{c3::Vice President}}, {{c4::federal judges (including Article III judges)}}, and other {{c5::federal civil officers}} may be impeached. 1.2 {{c6::Grounds for impeachment}} 1.2.1 {{c7::Treason, bribery, or other high crimes and misdemeanors}}. 2. {{c8::Impeachment in the House of Representatives}} 2.1 {{c9::Charging decision}} 2.1.1 The {{c10::House of Representatives}} has the {{c11::sole power of impeachment}}. 2.1.2 A {{c12::simple majority vote}} in the House is required to {{c13::impeach}}. 3. {{c14::Trial and removal in the Senate}} 3.1 {{c15::Senate trial}} 3.1.1 Once impeached, the officer is {{c16::tried in the Senate}}. 3.2 {{c17::Vote required for conviction and removal}} 3.2.1 Conviction and removal from office require the constitutionally required {{c18::supermajority vote}} in the Senate.
cards.easyContent: The President, Vice President, federal judges, and other federal officers can be impeached for treason, bribery, or other high crimes and misdemeanors. The House impeaches by majority vote, and the Senate then tries the case and can remove the officer only by a supermajority vote.
cards.mediumContent: Impeachment applies to the President, Vice President, federal judges, and other federal civil officers for treason, bribery, or other high crimes and misdemeanors. The House of Representatives has the sole power to impeach by a simple majority vote, after which the Senate conducts a trial. Removal from office requires conviction in the Senate by the constitutionally required supermajority vote.
cards.hardContent: The Constitution authorizes impeachment of the President, Vice President, federal judges (including Article III judges), and other federal civil officers for treason, bribery, or other high crimes and misdemeanors. The House of Representatives has the sole power to impeach and does so by a simple majority vote, which functions like an indictment. After impeachment, the Senate conducts the trial. Conviction and removal from office require the constitutionally required supermajority vote in the Senate (for federal officers, two‑thirds of the Senators present). Without that supermajority, the officer is not removed.
cards.mnemonic: H indicts, S sentences: House simple, Senate super.
cards.clozeLite: {{c1::Impeachment}} applies to {{c2::the President, VP, federal judges, and other civil officers}} for {{c3::treason, bribery, or other high crimes and misdemeanors}}. The {{c4::House impeaches by simple majority}} and the {{c5::Senate convicts and removes by supermajority}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 016-1. Treaties – Formation and Hierarchy
cards.front: Treaties – Formation and Hierarchy
cards.frontPrompt: What is a treaty under U.S. constitutional law, how is it made, and how do treaties rank when they conflict with state law, federal statutes, or the Constitution?
cards.backPlain: 1. Constitutional basis 1.1 Article II gives the President authority to make treaties and appoint ambassadors, as part of the President’s foreign-affairs powers. 2. Definition and formation of treaties 2.1 Definition 2.1.1 Treaties are formal agreements between the United States and foreign countries negotiated by the President. 2.2 Effectiveness 2.2.1 A treaty becomes effective and binding as U.S. law only upon ratification by two-thirds of the Senate. 3. Treaties in conflict with other law 3.1 Conflict with state law 3.1.1 A valid treaty prevails over conflicting state law under the Supremacy Clause. 3.2 Conflict with federal statute 3.2.1 If a treaty and a federal statute conflict, the one that is most recent in time controls. 3.3 Conflict with the Constitution 3.3.1 The Constitution always prevails over a conflicting treaty; a treaty cannot authorize what the Constitution forbids or override constitutional protections.
cards.cloze: 1. Constitutional basis 1.1 Article II gives the {{c1::President}} authority to {{c2::make treaties}} and appoint ambassadors. 2. Definition and formation of treaties 2.1 Definition 2.1.1 Treaties are formal agreements between the {{c3::United States and foreign countries}} negotiated by the President. 2.2 Effectiveness 2.2.1 A treaty becomes effective as U.S. law only upon ratification by {{c4::two-thirds of the Senate}}. 3. Treaties in conflict with other law 3.1 Conflict with state law 3.1.1 A valid treaty {{c5::prevails over conflicting state law}}. 3.2 Conflict with federal statute 3.2.1 Between a treaty and a federal statute, the {{c6::most recent in time prevails}}. 3.3 Conflict with the Constitution 3.3.1 The {{c7::Constitution}} always prevails over a conflicting treaty.
cards.easyContent: A treaty is a formal agreement with a foreign country negotiated by the President and effective only when two-thirds of the Senate ratify it. A valid treaty overrides conflicting state law, conflicts with federal statutes are resolved by the most recent in time, and the Constitution always controls over a conflicting treaty.
cards.mediumContent: Under Article II, the President negotiates treaties with foreign countries. A treaty becomes effective as U.S. law only when two-thirds of the Senate ratifies it. A valid treaty is supreme over conflicting state law. When a treaty and a federal statute conflict, whichever is most recent in time controls. However, the Constitution always prevails: a treaty cannot override or violate the Constitution.
cards.hardContent: Article II empowers the President to make treaties as part of the executive’s foreign-affairs role. A treaty is a formal agreement between the United States and foreign nations negotiated by the President and not effective as domestic law until ratified by two-thirds of the Senate. Once effective, a treaty is the supreme law of the land: it overrides conflicting state laws. When a treaty conflicts with a federal statute, the most recent in time governs the conflict. But a treaty is subordinate to the Constitution; it cannot authorize unconstitutional action, and any conflict is resolved in favor of the Constitution.
cards.mnemonic: T=2/3+S: Treaties beat States, tie Statutes by time, lose to Constitution.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::treaty}} is negotiated by the {{c2::President}} and needs {{c3::two-thirds Senate ratification}}; it {{c4::overrides state law}} but {{c5::cannot override the Constitution}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Executive Agreements – Formation and Legal Effect
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 016-2. Executive Agreements – Formation and Legal Effect
cards.front: Executive Agreements – Formation and Legal Effect
cards.frontPrompt: What is an executive agreement, how is it made, what is its scope, and how does it rank when it conflicts with state law, federal statutes, or the Constitution?
cards.backPlain: 1. Definition and formation 1.1 Executive agreements are international agreements reached between the President and foreign heads of state. 1.2 No Senate or congressional approval is required for an executive agreement. 2. Scope of executive agreements 2.1 Executive agreements can be used for any purpose for which the United States might enter into an international agreement (e.g., trade, military cooperation, claims settlements), so long as they are otherwise constitutional. 3. Executive agreements in conflict with other law 3.1 Conflict with state law 3.1.1 A valid executive agreement prevails over conflicting state laws under the Supremacy Clause. 3.2 Conflict with federal statutes 3.2.1 Executive agreements do not prevail over conflicting federal statutes; a federal statute will control over a conflicting executive agreement. 3.3 Conflict with the Constitution 3.3.1 Executive agreements do not prevail over the Constitution; they cannot authorize conduct that would violate constitutional limitations.
cards.cloze: 1. Definition and formation 1.1 Executive agreements are agreements between the {{c1::President}} and {{c2::foreign heads of state}}. 1.2 They require {{c3::no congressional approval}}. 2. Scope of executive agreements 2.1 Executive agreements can be used for {{c4::any purpose}} for which the U.S. might make an international agreement, if otherwise constitutional. 3. Executive agreements in conflict with other law 3.1 Conflict with state law 3.1.1 A valid executive agreement {{c5::prevails over conflicting state law}}. 3.2 Conflict with federal statutes 3.2.1 Executive agreements {{c6::do not prevail over federal statutes}}; statutes control. 3.3 Conflict with the Constitution 3.3.1 Executive agreements {{c7::do not prevail over the Constitution}} and cannot authorize unconstitutional conduct.
cards.easyContent: An executive agreement is an international agreement between the President and a foreign head of state that needs no congressional approval. It can be used for any purpose, overrides conflicting state law, but cannot override federal statutes or the Constitution.
cards.mediumContent: Executive agreements are international agreements made directly between the President and foreign heads of state. They require no Senate or congressional approval and may cover any subject matter appropriate for international agreements, as long as they are constitutional. As domestic law, a valid executive agreement preempts conflicting state laws. However, it is subordinate to federal statutes and to the Constitution; a contrary statute or constitutional provision controls.
cards.hardContent: Executive agreements are a form of international agreement concluded solely by the President, acting with foreign heads of state, and they require no approval by Congress or the Senate. They are versatile and may address any subject matter on which the United States may engage internationally, so long as they do not contravene constitutional limits. As a matter of domestic supremacy, a valid executive agreement binds the states and displaces conflicting state law. However, unlike treaties, executive agreements do not prevail over conflicting federal statutes, and in all events they are subordinate to the Constitution and cannot authorize unconstitutional actions.
cards.mnemonic: EA: Easy Approval, beats States, but Statutes and Supremacy win.
cards.clozeLite: An {{c1::executive agreement}} is made by the {{c2::President and foreign heads of state}} with {{c3::no Senate or congressional approval}}, {{c4::preempts conflicting state law}} but is {{c5::subordinate to federal statutes and the Constitution}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 016-3. Foreign Affairs – Presidential Primacy
cards.front: Foreign Affairs – Presidential Primacy
cards.frontPrompt: How are foreign-affairs powers generally allocated between Congress and the President, and what limits exist on other branches directing U.S. foreign representatives?
cards.backPlain: 1. General allocation of foreign-affairs powers 1.1 Article II gives the President key foreign-affairs powers, including making treaties, appointing ambassadors, and acting as Commander in Chief. 1.2 The President alone has authority to represent the United States in foreign affairs and to speak as the nation’s representative to other states. 2. Role of Congress 2.1 Congress has important, but distinct, foreign-affairs powers—for example, the power to declare war, raise and support armies, regulate foreign commerce, and fund military and diplomatic activities. 3. Limits on other branches directing foreign representatives 3.1 Because the President is the primary representative of the United States in foreign affairs, other branches generally may not directly control or direct United States foreign representatives (such as ambassadors). 3.2 Be cautious of scenarios in which Congress or the courts attempt to dictate specific instructions to ambassadors or otherwise take over the conduct of diplomacy, as these typically intrude on the President’s exclusive representational role in foreign affairs.
cards.cloze: 1. General allocation of foreign-affairs powers 1.1 Article II gives the {{c1::President}} key foreign-affairs powers, including making treaties, appointing ambassadors, and acting as {{c2::Commander in Chief}}. 1.2 The President alone has authority to {{c3::represent the United States in foreign affairs}}. 2. Role of Congress 2.1 Congress retains foreign-affairs powers such as the power to {{c4::declare war}}, raise and support armies, and regulate foreign commerce. 3. Limits on other branches directing foreign representatives 3.1 Other branches generally may not {{c5::direct U.S. foreign representatives}} such as ambassadors. 3.2 Be cautious of answer choices where {{c6::Congress or the courts attempt to dictate diplomacy}} or specific instructions to ambassadors, as this typically intrudes on the President’s exclusive representational role.
cards.easyContent: The President has primary authority to represent the United States in foreign affairs, including making treaties, appointing ambassadors, and serving as Commander in Chief. Congress still has important foreign-affairs powers like declaring war, but it cannot directly control or direct U.S. foreign representatives such as ambassadors.
cards.mediumContent: Article II makes the President the nation’s chief representative in foreign affairs, with powers such as negotiating treaties, appointing ambassadors, and leading the military as Commander in Chief. Congress retains significant foreign-affairs powers—such as declaring war and regulating foreign commerce—but these do not displace the President’s primary role in conducting diplomacy. Accordingly, other branches generally may not direct U.S. foreign representatives or otherwise take over the conduct of diplomacy.
cards.hardContent: The Constitution allocates foreign-affairs authority primarily to the President under Article II, including the powers to negotiate treaties, appoint and receive ambassadors, and act as Commander in Chief of the armed forces. Congress nonetheless wields important foreign-affairs powers, such as the power to declare war, raise and support armies, regulate foreign commerce, and appropriate funds for military and diplomatic activity. However, the President alone serves as the nation’s representative in dealings with foreign governments, and other branches—whether Congress or the judiciary—may not directly control or instruct U.S. foreign representatives, such as ambassadors, or otherwise supplant the President’s lead role in diplomacy.
cards.mnemonic: One Voice Abroad: Congress funds and declares, President speaks and negotiates.
cards.clozeLite: Article II makes the President the {{c1::chief representative in foreign affairs}}; {{c2::Congress retains war and commerce powers}} but {{c3::cannot direct U.S. foreign representatives}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Dormant Commerce Clause – Basic Test and Invalid Regulations
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 018-1. Dormant Commerce Clause – Basic Test and Invalid Regulations
cards.front: Dormant Commerce Clause – Basic Test
cards.backPlain: Dormant Commerce Clause (DCC) – Basic rule When Congress has not regulated, state and local governments may regulate local aspects of interstate commerce only if their laws are neither discriminatory nor unduly burdensome on interstate commerce. Dormant Commerce Clause invalidity test A state or local law regulating interstate commerce is invalid if it: 1. Discriminates against out-of-state competition; or 2. Unduly burdens interstate commerce (balancing local benefits against burdens on interstate commerce); or 3. Regulates wholly out-of-state activity (extraterritorial regulation). Common examples of invalid laws - Laws protecting local businesses from out-of-state competitors. - Laws requiring local operations (e.g., in-state processing or in-state offices). - Laws limiting access to in-state products (e.g., export bans or hoarding in-state resources) for protectionist reasons.
cards.frontPrompt: When Congress is silent, what makes a state or local law regulating interstate commerce invalid under the Dormant Commerce Clause, and what are common examples of such invalid regulations?
cards.cloze: Under the {{c1::Dormant Commerce Clause}}, when Congress has not acted, state and local governments may regulate only if their laws are neither {{c2::discriminatory}} nor {{c3::unduly burdensome}} on interstate commerce. A state or local law regulating interstate commerce is invalid if it: 1. {{c4::Discriminates against out-of-state competition}}; 2. {{c5::Unduly burdens interstate commerce}}; or 3. {{c6::Regulates wholly out-of-state (extraterritorial) activity}}. Examples of invalid regulations include laws {{c7::protecting local businesses}}, {{c8::requiring local operations}} (such as in-state processing or offices), and laws {{c9::limiting access to in-state products}} for protectionist reasons.
cards.easyContent: When Congress is silent, a state law violates the Dormant Commerce Clause if it discriminates against out-of-staters, places an undue burden on interstate commerce, or tries to regulate activity entirely outside the state. Typical bad laws protect local businesses, require in-state operations, or restrict access to in-state products for protectionist reasons.
cards.mediumContent: The Dormant Commerce Clause applies when Congress has not regulated. A state or local law is invalid if it (1) discriminates against out-of-state competitors, (2) imposes an undue burden on interstate commerce (where the burden on interstate commerce clearly exceeds the local benefits), or (3) regulates conduct wholly outside the state. Common invalid examples are protectionist laws that shield local businesses, impose local-processing or local-office requirements, or limit exports or access to in-state products to favor residents.
cards.hardContent: Under the Dormant Commerce Clause, absent congressional action, states can regulate local aspects of interstate commerce only if their laws do not discriminate against or unduly burden interstate commerce and do not regulate wholly extraterritorial activity. A law is invalid if it discriminates against out-of-state competition on its face, in purpose, or in effect; if the burdens on interstate commerce are clearly excessive in relation to the putative local benefits (Pike balancing); or if the law attempts to control commerce occurring entirely outside the state's borders. Typical invalid regulations include protectionist rules that favor in-state businesses, requirements that certain activities take place in-state (such as in-state processing, warehouses, or offices), and restrictions that limit the export or access to in-state products to give residents an advantage.
cards.mnemonic: DCC red flags are D-U-O: Discrimination, Undue burden, Out-of-state regulation.
cards.clozeLite: A state law violates the {{c1::Dormant Commerce Clause}} if it {{c2::discriminates against out-of-staters}}, {{c3::unduly burdens interstate commerce}}, or {{c4::regulates conduct wholly outside the state}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Dormant Commerce Clause – Necessary Important State Interest Exception
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 018-2. Dormant Commerce Clause – Necessary Important State Interest Exception
cards.front: DCC Exception – Necessary to Important State Interest
cards.backPlain: Necessary important state interest exception (DCC) A state law that discriminates against or burdens interstate commerce may nevertheless be upheld if it satisfies a strict type of necessity test: 1. Important, non-economic state interest - The law furthers an important state interest that is non-economic in nature (e.g., public health, safety, or environmental protection, not mere economic protectionism). 2. No reasonable, non-discriminatory alternatives - There are no reasonable, non-discriminatory (or less burdensome) alternatives that could adequately achieve the state’s important objective. If both conditions are met, a discriminatory or burdensome law may survive Dormant Commerce Clause scrutiny under this exception.
cards.frontPrompt: When can a discriminatory or burdensome state law still be upheld under the Dormant Commerce Clause because it is necessary to an important state interest?
cards.cloze: Under the {{c1::Dormant Commerce Clause}}, a discriminatory or burdensome state law may still be upheld if it is {{c2::necessary}} to an {{c3::important, non-economic state interest}} and there are {{c4::no reasonable, non-discriminatory alternatives}} that would adequately achieve that interest.
cards.easyContent: A discriminatory or burdensome state law can survive Dormant Commerce Clause review if it is truly necessary to achieve an important, non-economic state interest (like health or safety) and there is no reasonable, non-discriminatory alternative.
cards.mediumContent: The "necessary important state interest" exception allows a discriminatory or burdensome law to be upheld only if the law furthers an important, non-economic state objective and there are no reasonable, less discriminatory or less burdensome means to achieve that goal. If a non-discriminatory alternative exists, the law fails.
cards.hardContent: Although the Dormant Commerce Clause is highly suspicious of discriminatory laws, such laws may survive if they are necessary to achieve an important, non-economic state interest—typically involving health, safety, or environmental protection rather than economic protectionism—and the state can show that no reasonable, non-discriminatory (or less burdensome) alternative would adequately serve that interest. This necessity test is demanding: if any workable alternative that burdens interstate commerce less is available, the discriminatory law is invalid.
cards.mnemonic: NINE: Necessary, Important, Non-Economic interest, no alternative.
cards.clozeLite: A discriminatory law survives DCC only if it serves an {{c1::important, non-economic state interest}} and {{c2::no reasonable, less discriminatory alternative}} exists.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Dormant Commerce Clause – Market Participant, Traditional Function, and Congressional Approval
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 018-3. Dormant Commerce Clause – Market Participant, Traditional Function, and Congressional Approval
cards.front: DCC Exceptions – Market Participant, Traditional Function, Congressional Approval
cards.backPlain: Additional Dormant Commerce Clause exceptions A state law that would otherwise violate the Dormant Commerce Clause may be upheld if one of these exceptions applies: 1. Market participant doctrine - When the state is acting as a market participant (not as a regulator), it may favor its own citizens in: • Buying or selling products; • Hiring labor; or • Giving subsidies. - Classic example: tuition discounts at state universities for in-state residents. 2. Traditional government function - The state may discriminate against non-residents when the law involves the performance of a traditional government function (e.g., operation of a state-owned facility or core public services), giving the state somewhat more leeway to prefer its own residents. 3. Congressional approval (authorization) - A state can burden or discriminate in interstate commerce if {{Congress has unmistakably granted permission}}. - Clear congressional authorization overrides the usual Dormant Commerce Clause limits.
cards.frontPrompt: How do the market participant doctrine, traditional government function, and congressional approval operate as exceptions to the Dormant Commerce Clause?
cards.cloze: Under the {{c1::Dormant Commerce Clause}}, some otherwise invalid state laws may be upheld because of specific exceptions: 1. {{c2::Market participant doctrine}} – When the state is acting as a {{c3::market participant}} rather than a regulator, it may {{c4::favor its own citizens}} in buying or selling products, hiring labor, or giving subsidies (e.g., {{c5::in-state tuition discounts}}). 2. {{c6::Traditional government function}} – The state can sometimes {{c7::discriminate against non-residents}} when the law involves a {{c8::traditional government function}}, giving it more leeway to prefer residents. 3. {{c9::Congressional approval}} – A state may burden or discriminate in interstate commerce when {{c10::Congress has unmistakably authorized}} the state to do so, overriding ordinary DCC constraints.
cards.easyContent: Three key Dormant Commerce Clause exceptions are: (1) market participant—when the state is buying, selling, hiring, or subsidizing, it can usually favor its own citizens; (2) traditional government function—states have more room to favor residents when performing core government functions; and (3) congressional approval—clear authorization from Congress allows states to burden or discriminate in interstate commerce.
cards.mediumContent: Beyond the "necessary important state interest" exception, a state law otherwise barred by the DCC can survive if: (1) the state is a market participant, allowing it to favor its own citizens in its proprietary activities like buying, selling, hiring, or subsidizing (such as in-state tuition discounts); (2) the law concerns a traditional government function, where the state has more leeway to prefer residents; or (3) Congress has unmistakably authorized the state to impose the burden or discrimination on interstate commerce, which removes the usual DCC constraint.
cards.hardContent: Several structural exceptions can save a law that would otherwise violate the Dormant Commerce Clause. First, under the market participant doctrine, when a state acts as a participant in the market—such as purchasing or selling goods, hiring labor, or distributing subsidies—it may favor its own residents in those proprietary activities, unlike when it acts as a regulator. Second, where a law involves a traditional government function, the Court gives the state more latitude to discriminate in favor of its residents in performing core public functions. Third, if Congress has unmistakably authorized a particular burden on or discrimination against interstate commerce, that authorization overrides Dormant Commerce Clause limits, because the DCC is only an implied restriction in the absence of congressional action.
cards.mnemonic: MTC: Market participant, Traditional function, Congressional approval.
cards.clozeLite: DCC exceptions include {{c1::market participant (state as buyer/seller/hirer/subsidizer)}}, {{c2::traditional government function}}, and {{c3::unmistakable congressional authorization}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 027-1. Economic Rights – Rational Basis Review
cards.front: Economic Rights – Rational Basis Review
cards.backPlain: Economic rights (economic liberties) receive minimal constitutional protection. 1. Standard of review 1.1. Laws affecting economic rights are reviewed under the rational basis test. 1.2. Under rational basis, a law is upheld if it is rationally related to a legitimate governmental interest. 2. Scope and effect 2.1. The Constitution provides only minimal protection for economic liberties—i.e., laws affecting or amounting to a taking of one’s economic rights. 2.2. Rational basis applies to economic regulations unless the infringement falls under a more specific protection, such as: - The Contract Clause; or - The Takings Clause. 2.3. In practice, the government almost always wins under rational basis review for economic regulation.
cards.frontPrompt: How does the Constitution generally review laws affecting economic rights, and what is the practical level of protection they receive?
cards.cloze: {{c1::Economic rights}} (economic liberties) receive {{c2::minimal constitutional protection}}. 1. Standard of review 1.1. Laws affecting economic rights are reviewed under the {{c3::rational basis}} test. 1.2. Under {{c3::rational basis}}, a law is upheld if it is {{c4::rationally related}} to a {{c5::legitimate governmental interest}}. 2. Scope and effect 2.1. The Constitution provides only {{c2::minimal protection}} for {{c1::economic liberties}}—laws affecting or amounting to a taking of one’s economic rights. 2.2. {{c3::Rational basis}} applies to economic regulations unless the infringement falls under a more specific protection, such as the {{c6::Contract Clause}} or the {{c7::Takings Clause}}. 2.3. In practice, the {{c8::government almost always wins}} under {{c3::rational basis}} review for economic regulation.
cards.easyContent: Laws regulating economic rights almost always get rational basis review, which offers minimal protection, so the government usually wins unless a specific protection like the Contract Clause or Takings Clause applies.
cards.mediumContent: Economic liberties receive minimal constitutional protection: laws affecting them are reviewed under rational basis and are upheld if rationally related to a legitimate government interest. This deferential review applies to economic regulation unless a more specific protection—such as the Contract Clause or Takings Clause—is triggered, and the government almost always prevails.
cards.hardContent: Economic rights (economic liberties) are afforded only minimal protection under the Constitution. Laws regulating economic interests are generally reviewed under the rational basis test, under which a law will be upheld if it is rationally related to a legitimate governmental interest. This deferential standard applies to economic regulations unless a more specific constitutional protection, such as the Contract Clause or the Takings Clause, is implicated. As a result, the government almost always wins rational basis challenges to economic regulation.
cards.mnemonic: ER = RB: Economic Rights get Rational Basis, gov usually wins.
cards.clozeLite: Economic liberties get {{c1::minimal constitutional protection}}: reviewed under {{c2::rational basis}} and upheld if {{c3::rationally related to a legitimate government interest}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 027-2. Contract Clause – Scope and Applicability
cards.front: Contract Clause – Scope and Applicability
cards.backPlain: The Contract Clause limits state interference with existing contracts. 1. Basic prohibition 1.1. States cannot substantially impair existing contractual duties. 2. Who is bound 2.1. The Contract Clause applies only to state or local interference with contracts. 2.2. It does not apply to the federal government. 3. What contracts are covered 3.1. The Clause covers interference with existing contractual obligations, not future contracts. 3.2. It includes both: - Private contracts (between private parties); and - Government contracts (where the state or local government itself is a party). 4. Different scrutiny levels 4.1. Different levels of scrutiny apply depending on whether the state is interfering with: - Private contracts; or - Its own (government) contracts.
cards.frontPrompt: What does the Contract Clause prohibit, to whom does it apply, and what types of contracts does it cover?
cards.cloze: The {{c1::Contract Clause}} limits state interference with existing contracts. 1. Basic prohibition 1.1. States cannot {{c2::substantially impair}} {{c3::existing contractual duties}}. 2. Who is bound 2.1. The Contract Clause applies only to {{c4::state or local}} interference with contracts. 2.2. It does {{c5::not}} apply to the {{c6::federal government}}. 3. What contracts are covered 3.1. The Clause covers interference with {{c3::existing}} contractual obligations, not {{c7::future}} contracts. 3.2. It includes both: - {{c8::Private contracts}} (between private parties); and - {{c9::Government contracts}} (where the state or local government is a party). 4. Different scrutiny levels 4.1. Different levels of scrutiny apply depending on whether the state is interfering with {{c8::private contracts}} or its own {{c9::government contracts}}.
cards.easyContent: The Contract Clause bars states and localities—not the federal government—from substantially impairing existing contractual obligations, including both private and government contracts, with different scrutiny for each.
cards.mediumContent: The Contract Clause prohibits states and local governments from substantially impairing existing contractual duties. It applies only to state and local—not federal—action and covers both private contracts and contracts to which the government itself is a party. The level of scrutiny depends on whether the law impairs private contracts or the state’s own contracts.
cards.hardContent: The Contract Clause functions as a limit on state and local interference with contractual relationships. It forbids states and municipalities from substantially impairing existing contractual obligations; it does not constrain the federal government. The Clause protects obligations under both purely private contracts and contracts involving the state or local government itself. When a law substantially impairs these obligations, the applicable level of scrutiny differs depending on whether the interference is with private contracts or with the government’s own contracts.
cards.mnemonic: State Clamp: Contract Clause clamps state/local, not federal, contracts.
cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::Contract Clause}} bars {{c2::state and local}} (not federal) laws from {{c3::substantially impairing existing}} {{c4::private and government}} contracts.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Contract Clause – State Interference with Private Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 027-3. Contract Clause – State Interference with Private Contracts
cards.front: Contract Clause – Test for Private Contracts
cards.backPlain: When a state or local law interferes with private contracts, the Contract Clause uses an intermediate-type scrutiny. 1. Threshold: substantial impairment 1.1. First ask whether the law substantially impairs a party’s rights under an existing private contract. 1.2. If there is no substantial impairment, the Contract Clause is not violated. 2. Test for substantial impairment of private contracts 2.1. If the law does substantially impair contractual rights, it violates the Contract Clause unless the law: 2.1.1. Serves an important and legitimate public interest; and 2.1.2. Is reasonable and narrowly tailored in promoting that interest. 3. Level of scrutiny 3.1. This is often described as an intermediate-type scrutiny for state interference with private contracts.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the Contract Clause test when a state law substantially impairs existing private contractual rights?
cards.cloze: When a state or local law interferes with {{c1::private contracts}}, the Contract Clause uses an {{c2::intermediate-type scrutiny}}. 1. Threshold: substantial impairment 1.1. First ask whether the law {{c3::substantially impairs}} a party’s rights under an {{c4::existing}} private contract. 1.2. If there is no {{c3::substantial impairment}}, the Contract Clause is not violated. 2. Test for substantial impairment of private contracts 2.1. If the law does substantially impair contractual rights, it violates the Contract Clause unless the law: 2.1.1. Serves an {{c5::important and legitimate public interest}}; and 2.1.2. Is {{c6::reasonable and narrowly tailored}} in promoting that interest. 3. Level of scrutiny 3.1. This standard is often characterized as an {{c2::intermediate-type scrutiny}} for state interference with {{c1::private contracts}}.
cards.easyContent: For private contracts, a state law that substantially impairs existing rights must serve an important and legitimate public interest and be reasonable and narrowly tailored—an intermediate-type scrutiny.
cards.mediumContent: For state interference with private contracts, the Contract Clause first asks whether the law substantially impairs rights under an existing contract. If so, the law is invalid unless it serves an important and legitimate public interest and is reasonable and narrowly tailored to that interest, a form of intermediate-level scrutiny.
cards.hardContent: In the context of private contracts, the Contract Clause analysis begins by determining whether a state or local law substantially impairs rights under an existing contract. If the effect is not a substantial impairment, the Clause is not violated. Where a substantial impairment exists, the law will nonetheless be upheld if it serves an important and legitimate public interest and is reasonable and narrowly tailored in promoting that interest. This framework is often described as an intermediate-type scrutiny for state interference with private contractual obligations.
cards.mnemonic: Private contracts use RBI: Reasonable, important public aim, impairment justified.
cards.clozeLite: For private contracts, a law that {{c1::substantially impairs existing contract rights}} must serve an {{c2::important and legitimate public interest}} and be {{c3::reasonable and narrowly tailored}}—an {{c4::intermediate-level scrutiny}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Contract Clause – State Interference with Government Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 027-4. Contract Clause – State Interference with Government Contracts
cards.front: Contract Clause – Test for Government Contracts
cards.backPlain: When a state or local law interferes with the state’s own contractual obligations (government contracts), the Contract Clause applies a stricter scrutiny. 1. Threshold: substantial impairment 1.1. As with private contracts, first determine whether the law substantially impairs or interferes with existing government contracts. 2. Test for substantial impairment of government contracts 2.1. Laws that substantially impair existing government contracts are subject to stricter scrutiny. 2.2. Such laws must be: 2.2.1. Reasonable; and 2.2.2. Necessary to serve an important public purpose. 3. Level of scrutiny 3.1. This “reasonable and necessary to serve an important public purpose” standard is stricter than the intermediate-type scrutiny applied to private contracts, reflecting heightened concern when the government impairs its own obligations.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the Contract Clause standard when a state or local government substantially impairs its own (government) contractual obligations?
cards.cloze: When a state or local law interferes with the state’s own {{c1::government contracts}}, the Contract Clause applies a {{c2::stricter scrutiny}}. 1. Threshold: substantial impairment 1.1. First determine whether the law {{c3::substantially impairs}} or interferes with existing {{c1::government contracts}}. 2. Test for substantial impairment of government contracts 2.1. Laws that substantially impair existing government contracts are subject to {{c2::stricter scrutiny}}. 2.2. Such laws must be: 2.2.1. {{c4::Reasonable}}; and 2.2.2. {{c5::Necessary}} to serve an {{c6::important public purpose}}. 3. Level of scrutiny 3.1. This “{{c4::reasonable}} and {{c5::necessary}} to serve an {{c6::important public purpose}}” standard is stricter than the {{c7::intermediate-type}} scrutiny used for {{c8::private contracts}}.
cards.easyContent: For government contracts, a state law that substantially impairs existing obligations faces stricter scrutiny: it must be reasonable and necessary to serve an important public purpose.
cards.mediumContent: When a state or locality impairs its own contractual obligations, the Contract Clause imposes a stricter standard than for private contracts. A substantial impairment of existing government contracts is valid only if the law is reasonable and necessary to serve an important public purpose.
cards.hardContent: For government contracts—that is, contracts to which the state or local government itself is a party—the Contract Clause employs a stricter scrutiny than in the private-contract context. The court first asks whether the law substantially impairs or interferes with existing government contracts. If so, the law will be upheld only if it is reasonable and necessary to serve an important public purpose. This elevated standard reflects greater skepticism when the government seeks to modify or escape its own contractual obligations.
cards.mnemonic: Gov’t contracts need RN-IP: Reasonable, Necessary, Important Public purpose.
cards.clozeLite: When a state impairs its own contracts, a substantial impairment is valid only if the law is {{c1::reasonable and necessary}} to serve an {{c2::important public purpose}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 029-1. Takings – Definition & Types (Possessory vs. Regulatory)
cards.front: Takings – Definition & Types (Possessory vs. Regulatory)
cards.frontPrompt: Under the 5th Amendment, what is a “taking,” and what are the main types of takings (possessory vs. regulatory)?
cards.backPlain: The 5th Amendment Takings Clause prohibits the government from taking private property for public use without just compensation. A taking occurs when government action significantly damages private property or its use. Types of takings: 1. Possessory (physical) taking: - The government takes or physically occupies private property. - Includes permanent or significant physical invasions. 2. Regulatory taking (general concept): - Government regulation adversely affects property value or the owner’s ability to use the property. - Whether a regulatory taking has occurred depends on the extent of economic interference with the owner’s rights (elaborated in regulatory takings tests).
cards.cloze: The {{c1::5th Amendment Takings Clause}} prohibits the government from taking private property for public use without just compensation. A taking occurs when {{c2::government action significantly damages private property or its use}}. There are two main types of takings: 1. {{c3::Possessory (physical) taking}} – when the government {{c4::takes or physically occupies private property}}, including permanent or significant physical invasions. 2. {{c5::Regulatory taking}} – when {{c6::government regulation adversely affects property value or the owner’s ability to use the property}}, and whether a taking has occurred depends on the {{c7::extent of economic interference}} with the owner’s rights.
cards.easyContent: A taking under the 5th Amendment is government action that significantly damages private property or its use. It can be a physical occupation (possessory taking) or a regulation that so interferes with value or use that it amounts to a regulatory taking.
cards.mediumContent: The Takings Clause is triggered when the government takes private property. A possessory taking occurs when the government physically takes or occupies property, including permanent or substantial physical invasions. A regulatory taking occurs when regulations so adversely affect the property’s value or the owner’s ability to use it that, functionally, the property has been taken. Whether regulation goes that far depends on the degree of economic interference.
cards.hardContent: Under the 5th Amendment Takings Clause, a taking occurs when government action significantly damages private property or its use. There are two primary forms: • Possessory (physical) takings: where the government directly takes title to or physically occupies private property, including permanent appropriations or substantial physical invasions. • Regulatory takings: where government regulation restricts the use of property or diminishes its value to such an extent that it effectively appropriates the property. In regulatory takings, courts focus on the extent of the economic interference with the owner’s rights to determine whether the regulation has gone “too far.”
cards.mnemonic: Two P’s of takings: Possession or Police Power gone too far.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::possessory taking}} is a {{c2::physical occupation}} of property; a {{c3::regulatory taking}} is regulation that {{c4::so harms use or value}} it functions as a taking.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Regulatory Takings – Total vs. Near-Total Economic Loss
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 029-2. Regulatory Takings – Total vs. Near-Total Economic Loss
cards.front: Regulatory Takings – Total vs. Near-Total Economic Loss
cards.frontPrompt: How does the 5th Amendment treat regulatory takings that deny all or nearly all economic value of property, and what factors are considered?
cards.backPlain: A regulatory taking occurs when government regulation goes so far in restricting property use or value that it effectively takes the property. 1. Total denial of economic value: - A regulation that denies the owner all economic value in the property is a taking and requires just compensation. 2. Near-total denial of economic value: - A regulation that denies nearly all economic value may be a taking, depending on: • The social goals promoted by the regulation; • The diminution in value to the owner; and • The extent of interference with the owner’s reasonable investment-backed expectations.
cards.cloze: A {{c1::regulatory taking}} occurs when government regulation goes so far in restricting property use or value that it effectively takes the property. 1. {{c2::Total denial of economic value}}: - A regulation that denies the owner {{c3::all economic value}} in the property is a taking and requires just compensation. 2. {{c4::Near-total denial of economic value}}: - A regulation that denies {{c5::nearly all economic value}} may be a taking, depending on: • The {{c6::social goals}} promoted by the regulation; • The {{c7::diminution in value}} to the owner; and • The extent of interference with the owner’s {{c8::reasonable investment-backed expectations}}.
cards.easyContent: If a regulation wipes out all economic value, it is a taking requiring compensation. If it wipes out nearly all value, it may be a taking based on factors like the regulation’s social goals, how much value is lost, and how much it interferes with reasonable investment-backed expectations.
cards.mediumContent: For regulatory takings, a regulation that completely eliminates all economic value in property is a per se taking requiring just compensation. Where the regulation leaves only a sliver of value, courts look to factors such as the social purposes of the regulation, the extent of the diminution in value, and how much the regulation interferes with the owner’s reasonable investment-backed expectations to decide if a taking has occurred.
cards.hardContent: Regulatory takings doctrine focuses on how far a regulation goes in restricting property rights. A regulation that denies an owner all economically viable use of the property constitutes a taking per se and requires just compensation. Where a regulation leaves the owner with only minimal economic value, a court applies a multifactor analysis, considering the social goals served by the regulation, the severity of the diminution in value, and the degree to which the regulation frustrates the owner’s reasonable investment-backed expectations. Depending on these factors, a near-total loss can amount to a compensable taking.
cards.mnemonic: ALL vs ALMOST: ALL = automatic taking; ALMOST = Goals, Loss, Expectations.
cards.clozeLite: A regulation that {{c1::eliminates all economic value}} is a {{c2::per se taking}}. A {{c3::near-total loss}} uses factors: {{c4::social purpose}}, {{c5::diminution in value}}, {{c6::investment-backed expectations}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 029-3. Takings – Public Use Requirement
cards.front: Takings – Public Use Requirement
cards.frontPrompt: What is the “public use” requirement under the Takings Clause, and how demanding is this standard?
cards.backPlain: Under the 5th Amendment Takings Clause, the government may take private property only for public use. 1. Broad definition of public use: - A taking is for public use if the government has a reasonable belief that the taking will benefit the public. - This is a low standard. 2. Rational relationship test: - Public use is satisfied so long as the taking is rationally related to some legitimate public purpose. - This includes purposes such as economic redevelopment, eliminating blight, or other public welfare objectives. - The government may even transfer taken property to private developers if the overall use is rationally related to a legitimate public purpose.
cards.cloze: Under the Takings Clause, the government may take private property only for {{c1::public use}}. 1. {{c2::Broad definition}}: - A taking is for public use if the government has a {{c3::reasonable belief}} that the taking will benefit the public, a {{c4::low standard}}. 2. {{c5::Rational relationship test}}: - Public use is satisfied if the taking is {{c6::rationally related}} to a {{c7::legitimate public purpose}}, such as economic redevelopment or eliminating blight. - Property may be transferred to {{c8::private parties}} so long as the overall project satisfies this public purpose standard.
cards.easyContent: Public use is interpreted very broadly. It is enough that the government reasonably believes the taking will benefit the public—i.e., that it is rationally related to a legitimate public purpose, even if the property ends up in private hands.
cards.mediumContent: The Takings Clause requires that any taking be for public use, but courts apply a deferential standard. Public use is met if the government reasonably believes the taking will benefit the public, which is satisfied whenever the taking is rationally related to a legitimate public purpose such as economic development or eliminating blight. The government may condemn property and transfer it to private parties if this public purpose requirement is met.
cards.hardContent: The public use requirement imposes only a minimal constraint on eminent domain. A taking is for public use so long as the government has a reasonable belief that the taking will benefit the public. Courts uphold takings if they are rationally related to any legitimate public purpose, including economic redevelopment, infrastructure projects, or elimination of blight. The fact that the condemned property is ultimately conveyed to private entities does not defeat public use, provided the overall plan serves a legitimate public objective.
cards.mnemonic: Public use is public purpose under rational basis.
cards.clozeLite: Public use is satisfied if a taking is {{c1::rationally related}} to a {{c2::legitimate public purpose}}, even if {{c3::property goes to private hands}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 029-4. Takings – Just Compensation
cards.front: Takings – Just Compensation
cards.frontPrompt: How is just compensation measured under the Takings Clause, and whose perspective controls?
cards.backPlain: If there is a taking for public use, the government must pay just compensation. 1. Measure of just compensation: - Just compensation is measured by the owner’s loss, not the government’s gain. - It is usually the fair market value of the property at the time of the taking. 2. Timing: - The valuation is generally fixed at the time the property is taken or when the restriction becomes effective. 3. Scope: - Compensation is tied to the property interest taken (e.g., full fee, easement, or temporary occupation).
cards.cloze: If there is a taking for public use, the government must pay {{c1::just compensation}}. 1. Measure: - Just compensation is measured in terms of {{c2::loss to the owner}}, not the government’s gain. - It is usually the {{c3::fair market value}} of the property at the {{c4::time of the taking}}. 2. Scope: - The amount of compensation corresponds to the {{c5::property interest taken}} (e.g., fee simple, easement, or temporary occupation).
cards.easyContent: Just compensation is what the owner loses, usually the fair market value of the property at the time of the taking, measured from the owner’s perspective.
cards.mediumContent: Once a taking for public use is established, the government must pay just compensation. This is measured by the owner’s loss—typically the fair market value of the property at the time of the taking. The scope of compensation tracks the interest taken, whether it is a full fee simple, an easement, or a temporary occupation.
cards.hardContent: Just compensation ensures the property owner is made whole for the interest taken. The measure is the owner’s loss, generally the fair market value of the property at the time of the taking or when the restriction becomes effective, not the value of the project to the government. The compensation owed corresponds to the nature and duration of the property interest taken, such as a full fee, partial interest, or temporary occupation.
cards.mnemonic: JC: Just for the owner—FMV loss at taking time.
cards.clozeLite: Just compensation is {{c1::measured by the owner’s loss}}, usually {{c2::fair market value at the time of the taking}}, not {{c3::the project’s value to the government}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Fundamental Rights – SDP vs. Equal Protection Framework
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 030-1. Fundamental Rights – SDP vs. Equal Protection Framework
cards.front: Fundamental Rights – SDP vs. Equal Protection Framework
cards.backPlain: Fundamental rights are protected under both the 5th Amendment (applicable to the federal government) and the 14th Amendment (applicable to the states). 1. Substantive Due Process (SDP) 1.1. Source: - 5th Amendment Due Process Clause (federal). - 14th Amendment Due Process Clause (states). 1.2. When used: - SDP analysis applies when a law or government action {{denies a right to everyone}} or regulates everyone the same way with respect to that right (no classification among groups). 1.3. Standard: - If a fundamental right is burdened, strict scrutiny applies. - If no fundamental right is implicated, the law receives rational basis review. 2. Equal Protection (EP) 2.1. Source: - 14th Amendment Equal Protection Clause (states). - For the federal government, equal protection is applied via the 5th Amendment Due Process Clause. 2.2. When used: - EP analysis applies when a law or government action {{grants or denies a right to some people but not others}}, creating a classification. 2.3. Fundamental rights under EP: - If a classification burdens a fundamental right (e.g., voting or travel), strict scrutiny usually applies. 3. Non-fundamental rights 3.1. When the government action does not implicate a fundamental right, it is reviewed under rational basis, whether framed as SDP or EP. 3.2. Under rational basis, the law will be upheld if it is rationally related to a legitimate government interest.
cards.frontPrompt: How do substantive due process and equal protection differ in the protection of fundamental rights, and when does rational basis apply instead of strict scrutiny?
cards.cloze: Fundamental rights are protected under both the {{c1::5th Amendment}} (federal) and the {{c2::14th Amendment}} (states). 1. {{c3::Substantive Due Process (SDP)}} 1.1. SDP applies when a law or government action {{c4::denies a right to everyone}} or regulates everyone the same way with respect to that right (no classification among groups). 1.2. If a {{c5::fundamental right}} is burdened, {{c6::strict scrutiny}} applies; if not, the law receives {{c7::rational basis}} review. 2. {{c8::Equal Protection (EP)}} 2.1. EP applies when a law or government action {{c9::grants or denies a right to some people but not others}}, creating a classification. 2.2. If a classification burdens a {{c5::fundamental right}} (such as voting or travel), {{c6::strict scrutiny}} usually applies. 3. {{c7::Rational basis}} review 3.1. When no fundamental right is implicated, whether under SDP or EP, the government action is reviewed under {{c7::rational basis}}, and will be upheld if it is {{c10::rationally related}} to a {{c11::legitimate government interest}}.
cards.easyContent: Use substantive due process when the government denies a right to everyone; use equal protection when it denies the right to some but not others. If a fundamental right is burdened, strict scrutiny usually applies; otherwise the law gets rational basis review.
cards.mediumContent: Substantive due process (under the 5th and 14th Amendments) is used when a law burdens a right across the board, without classifications; equal protection (14th Amendment and incorporated via the 5th for the federal government) is used when the law burdens a right for some people but not others. When a fundamental right is burdened—whether framed as SDP or EP—strict scrutiny applies; if no fundamental right is involved, the action is evaluated under rational basis, which asks only whether the law is rationally related to a legitimate government interest.
cards.hardContent: Fundamental rights are protected by both the 5th Amendment (federal) and the 14th Amendment (states). Substantive due process analysis applies when a law or government action burdens a right for everyone similarly—there is no classification among groups. Equal protection analysis applies when the government burdens a right for some people but not others, thereby creating a classification. When a fundamental right (such as privacy, voting, or interstate travel) is burdened, the court typically applies strict scrutiny, requiring that the law be narrowly tailored to achieve a compelling government interest. When no fundamental right is implicated, whether the challenge is framed as substantive due process or equal protection, the applicable test is rational basis, which asks only whether the law is rationally related to a legitimate government interest.
cards.mnemonic: SDP = denied to ALL; EP = denied to SOME; fundamental right = strict scrutiny.
cards.atomizationNotes: Framework card for SDP vs. EP and standards of review for fundamental vs. non-fundamental rights.
cards.clozeLite: Use {{c1::substantive due process}} when a law burdens a right {{c2::across the board}}; use {{c3::equal protection}} when it burdens a right {{c4::for some people but not others}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Right to Privacy – Strict Scrutiny Family and Reproductive Rights
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 030-2. Right to Privacy – Strict Scrutiny Family and Reproductive Rights
cards.front: Right to Privacy – Strict Scrutiny Family and Reproductive Rights
cards.backPlain: The Constitution recognizes an inferred right to privacy, which encompasses several family and reproductive rights that generally receive strict scrutiny when substantially burdened. 1. Inferred right to privacy 1.1. The right to privacy is not expressly stated but inferred from the "penumbras" of various constitutional provisions. 1.2. It protects intimate and family decisions from undue government interference. 2. Privacy rights that typically receive strict scrutiny 2.1. Right to marry. - Government restrictions on the right to marry (e.g., bans on interracial marriage, unjustified impediments to adult marriage) are subject to strict scrutiny. 2.2. Right to procreate. - The decision whether to have children is a fundamental right. 2.3. Rights concerning family and children. 2.3.1. Right to custody of one's children. - Parents have a fundamental right to the care, custody, and control of their children, subject to the state's interest in protecting children from abuse or neglect. 2.3.2. Right to keep family together. - The state generally cannot prevent close family members from living together (e.g., extended family members in a single household), absent a compelling justification. 2.3.3. Right to control children's upbringing. - Parents have a fundamental right to direct the upbringing and education of their children, including choices about schooling and religious upbringing. 2.4. Right to contraceptives. - Decisions about using contraceptives are protected under the right to privacy, and undue burdens are subject to strict scrutiny.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the inferred constitutional right to privacy, and which family and reproductive rights within it generally receive strict scrutiny?
cards.cloze: The Constitution recognizes an {{c1::inferred right to privacy}}, which is not expressly stated but arises from the {{c2::penumbras}} of various constitutional provisions and protects intimate and family decisions from undue government interference. Privacy rights that typically receive {{c3::strict scrutiny}} when substantially burdened include: - The {{c4::right to marry}}. - The {{c5::right to procreate}}. - Rights concerning {{c6::family and children}}, including: - The {{c7::right to custody of one's children}}. - The {{c8::right to keep the family together}} (e.g., extended family living arrangements). - The {{c9::right to control children's upbringing}} (education, religious upbringing). - The {{c10::right to contraceptives}}.
cards.easyContent: An inferred right to privacy protects key family and reproductive decisions, including the rights to marry, procreate, keep the family together, direct children’s upbringing, and use contraceptives. These are generally treated as fundamental rights and receive strict scrutiny when substantially burdened.
cards.mediumContent: The right to privacy is an inferred constitutional right that protects intimate and family decisions. Within this privacy sphere, several rights are treated as fundamental and typically trigger strict scrutiny: the right to marry, the right to procreate, and a cluster of family-related rights (custody of one’s children, keeping the family together, and directing children’s upbringing and education). The decision to use contraceptives is also protected as a fundamental privacy right. Government regulations that substantially burden these rights must satisfy strict scrutiny.
cards.hardContent: The inferred constitutional right to privacy arises from the "penumbras" of several provisions of the Bill of Rights and is applied to the states through the 14th Amendment. This right protects individuals against unwarranted government intrusion into certain intimate and family decisions. Privacy rights that are treated as fundamental and generally trigger strict scrutiny include: (1) the right to marry, which bars unjustified government restrictions on adult marriage; (2) the right to procreate, protecting decisions about whether to have biological children; and (3) several family-related rights, including the right of parents to custody and control of their children (subject to state intervention in cases of abuse or neglect), the right to keep the family together (including extended family cohabitation), and the right to direct children’s upbringing and education (including choices about private or religious schooling). In addition, decisions about whether to use contraceptives fall within the protected zone of privacy and are generally subject to strict scrutiny when significantly burdened by the government.
cards.mnemonic: MPC-FCC: Marriage, Procreation, Custody, Family, Control, Contraceptives.
cards.atomizationNotes: Focuses on the inferred right to privacy and the cluster of family and reproductive rights that typically receive strict scrutiny.
cards.clozeLite: The inferred {{c1::constitutional right to privacy}} protects {{c2::intimate and family decisions}} like {{c3::marriage}}, {{c4::procreation}}, {{c5::family-related rights}} and {{c6::contraceptive use}}, generally triggering strict scrutiny.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Right to Privacy – Abortion, Sexual Autonomy, and Medical Refusal
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 030-3. Right to Privacy – Abortion, Sexual Autonomy, and Medical Refusal
cards.front: Right to Privacy – Abortion, Sexual Autonomy, and Medical Refusal
cards.backPlain: Some privacy-related rights have separate or evolving standards of review and are often tested as distinct doctrines. 1. Right to abortion 1.1. Historically treated as a privacy right with its own framework, distinct from strict scrutiny applied to other privacy rights. 1.2. (On the bar exam, know that abortion is a key privacy-related right with a specialized doctrinal test; the exact current standard may depend on jurisdiction and is typically covered in a separate, detailed card.) 2. Right to engage in private, consensual homosexual activity 2.1. Adults have a protected liberty interest in engaging in private, consensual sexual conduct. 2.2. The Court has invalidated laws criminalizing private consensual homosexual activity as violating liberty and privacy interests. 2.3. The precise level of scrutiny is not clearly labeled, but the right is treated as an important autonomy interest. 3. Right to refuse medical treatment 3.1. Competent adults have a liberty interest in refusing unwanted medical treatment. 3.2. The Court has recognized a right to refuse life-sustaining treatment, subject to important state interests (e.g., preserving life, preventing suicide, protecting third parties). 3.3. The standard of review is not as clearly defined as for other fundamental rights, and states may impose procedural safeguards (e.g., clear and convincing evidence of the patient’s wishes).
cards.frontPrompt: Which privacy-related rights have separate or uncertain standards of review, particularly regarding abortion, consensual homosexual activity, and refusal of medical treatment?
cards.cloze: Some privacy-related rights have {{c1::separate or evolving standards of review}} and are often tested as distinct doctrines. 1. {{c2::Right to abortion}} - Treated as a key privacy-related right with its own specialized doctrinal framework, rather than simply receiving the same strict scrutiny as other privacy rights. 2. {{c3::Right to engage in private, consensual homosexual activity}} - Adults have a protected {{c4::liberty interest}} in engaging in private, consensual sexual conduct. - Laws criminalizing private, consensual homosexual activity have been struck down as violating {{c5::liberty and privacy}} interests, even though the Court did not clearly label a specific level of scrutiny. 3. {{c6::Right to refuse medical treatment}} - Competent adults have a {{c7::liberty interest}} in refusing unwanted medical treatment, including potentially {{c8::life-sustaining}} treatment. - States may assert countervailing interests (e.g., preserving life, preventing suicide, protecting third parties) and may require {{c9::procedural safeguards}} such as clear and convincing evidence of the patient’s wishes.
cards.easyContent: Beyond strict-scrutiny family privacy rights, there are separate privacy-related doctrines: abortion (with its own special framework), private consensual homosexual activity (protected liberty and privacy interest), and the right of competent adults to refuse unwanted, even life-sustaining, medical treatment, subject to some state interests and procedures.
cards.mediumContent: Some privacy-related rights do not simply plug into the standard strict-scrutiny framework. Abortion is a central privacy-related right with its own specialized test on the bar exam. Adults also have a protected liberty and privacy interest in engaging in private, consensual homosexual conduct, and laws criminalizing such conduct have been invalidated even though the Court has not clearly labeled a level of scrutiny. Finally, competent adults have a liberty interest in refusing unwanted medical treatment, including life-sustaining treatment, although the state may require safeguards such as clear and convincing evidence of the patient’s wishes and may invoke interests in preserving life, preventing suicide, and protecting third parties.
cards.hardContent: In addition to strict-scrutiny privacy rights relating to marriage, procreation, and family, some privacy-related interests are governed by specialized or evolving doctrinal frameworks. The right to abortion is treated as a key privacy-related right with its own test, rather than straightforward strict scrutiny; bar examiners often address it separately. The Court has also recognized that adults have a protected liberty interest in engaging in private, consensual homosexual activity. Laws criminalizing private consensual homosexual conduct have been invalidated as violating substantive liberty and privacy interests, even though the Court did not explicitly adopt a particular level of scrutiny. Finally, competent adults have a recognized liberty interest in refusing unwanted medical treatment, including life-sustaining treatment. The state may nevertheless assert interests in preserving life, preventing suicide, and protecting third parties, and may require procedural safeguards—such as clear and convincing evidence that the patient truly wishes to refuse treatment—so this right does not always operate with the same clear strict-scrutiny label used for other privacy rights.
cards.mnemonic: A-SM: Abortion, Sexual autonomy, Medical refusal need special scrutiny.
cards.atomizationNotes: Covers privacy-related rights with separate or uncertain standards: abortion, consensual homosexual activity, and refusal of medical treatment.
cards.clozeLite: Special privacy doctrines: {{c1::abortion}}, {{c2::private consensual homosexual conduct}}, and {{c3::refusal of unwanted medical treatment}} use {{c4::non-standard scrutiny frameworks}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Fundamental Rights – Right to Vote and Right to Travel
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 030-4. Fundamental Rights – Right to Vote and Right to Travel
cards.front: Fundamental Rights – Right to Vote and Right to Travel
cards.backPlain: In addition to privacy rights, the Constitution protects other key fundamental rights, including the rights to vote and to travel, which are usually analyzed under equal protection. 1. Right to vote 1.1. Fundamental nature - The right to vote in elections for federal, state, and local offices is a fundamental right. 1.2. Equal Protection framework - Restrictions on the right to vote or laws that dilute voting power are generally analyzed under the Equal Protection Clause. - Laws that significantly burden the right to vote (e.g., poll taxes, severe residency or registration requirements) are subject to strict scrutiny. 1.3. Typical rules - "One person, one vote" requires roughly equal population in legislative districts. - States may impose reasonable, non-discriminatory regulations on the electoral process, which may receive a more deferential review depending on the burden. 2. Right to travel 2.1. Fundamental nature - The right to travel between states and to move to and become a resident of another state is a fundamental right. 2.2. Equal Protection framework - The right to travel is often protected through the Equal Protection Clause, particularly when new residents are treated less favorably than long-term residents. 2.3. Typical rules - Laws that penalize the right to travel—such as durational residency requirements that limit access to essential benefits for recent arrivals—are subject to close scrutiny. - Reasonable residency requirements for voting or in-state tuition may be permissible if they are not unduly long or punitive.
cards.frontPrompt: How are the fundamental rights to vote and to travel protected, and how are they typically analyzed under the Equal Protection Clause?
cards.cloze: In addition to privacy rights, the Constitution protects other key fundamental rights, including the {{c1::right to vote}} and the {{c2::right to travel}}, which are usually analyzed under the {{c3::Equal Protection Clause}}. 1. {{c1::Right to vote}} - A {{c4::fundamental right}} in elections for federal, state, and local offices. - Restrictions or dilution of voting power are generally reviewed under {{c3::equal protection}}. - Laws that significantly burden voting (e.g., {{c5::poll taxes}} or severe residency/registration requirements) are subject to {{c6::strict scrutiny}}. - The {{c7::“one person, one vote”}} principle requires legislative districts of roughly equal population. 2. {{c2::Right to travel}} - A {{c4::fundamental right}} to move between states and become a resident of another state. - Often protected through {{c3::equal protection}}, especially when {{c8::new residents}} are treated less favorably than {{c9::long-term residents}}. - Laws that penalize travel—such as harsh {{c10::durational residency requirements}} for essential benefits—are subject to {{c6::strict or close scrutiny}}, while reasonable, non-punitive residency requirements (e.g., for voting or in-state tuition) may be upheld.
cards.easyContent: The rights to vote and to travel are fundamental. Burdens on voting (like poll taxes or severe residency rules) and penalties on interstate migration are usually analyzed under equal protection and often trigger strict or close scrutiny, especially when they significantly burden these rights.
cards.mediumContent: Beyond privacy, two other central fundamental rights are the right to vote and the right to travel. The right to vote in federal, state, and local elections is fundamental; significant burdens or dilution of voting power are scrutinized under the Equal Protection Clause, and severe burdens (such as poll taxes or extreme residency requirements) typically trigger strict scrutiny. Related principles include “one person, one vote,” requiring roughly equal population across legislative districts. The right to travel includes the right to move freely between states and to establish residency. It is also treated as fundamental and often protected through equal protection, particularly when states treat new residents worse than long-term residents. Laws that penalize interstate travel via harsh durational residency requirements for essential benefits are closely scrutinized, while more modest residency rules (e.g., for voting qualifications or in-state tuition) may be permissible.
cards.hardContent: Apart from privacy rights, the Constitution protects the fundamental rights to vote and to travel, which are typically litigated under the Equal Protection Clause. The right to vote in federal, state, and local elections is fundamental. Regulations that severely burden the exercise of the franchise—such as poll taxes, highly restrictive registration or residency rules, or malapportioned districts that dilute voting strength—are subjected to strict or close scrutiny. The “one person, one vote” principle requires that legislative districts be drawn with roughly equal populations so that each person’s vote carries approximately equal weight. Lesser, non-discriminatory regulations of the electoral process may receive more deferential review depending on the burden. The right to travel is also fundamental and includes the right to move freely among the states and to establish residency in a new state. This right is frequently enforced via equal protection, especially when new residents are treated less favorably than longer-term residents. Laws that penalize recent arrivals through harsh durational residency requirements for essential public benefits are generally subject to close or strict scrutiny. However, reasonable residency requirements that serve administrative needs—such as short residency periods for voting eligibility or in-state tuition—may be sustained if they do not unduly burden the right to travel.
cards.mnemonic: V-T under EP: Vote and Travel get Equal Protection scrutiny.
cards.atomizationNotes: Covers the fundamental rights to vote and to travel and their typical treatment under the Equal Protection Clause.
cards.clozeLite: The fundamental rights to {{c1::vote}} and to {{c2::travel}} are often enforced via {{c3::Equal Protection}} and major burdens usually trigger {{c4::strict or close scrutiny}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Right to Abortion – Nature of Right and Viability Framework (Old Analysis)
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 031-1. Right to Abortion – Nature of Right and Viability Framework (Old Analysis)
cards.front: Right to Abortion – Nature of Right and Viability Framework (Old Analysis)
cards.frontPrompt: Under the old substantive due process framework, what was the nature of the abortion right, and how did the viability framework structure the analysis?
cards.backPlain: Under the old framework, abortion was treated as a substantive due process right included in the constitutional right to privacy.
