The core analytical structure turned on fetal viability: 1. Viability definition: Viability is the point at which a fetus can survive outside the womb. 2. Viability framework: 2.1 Pre-viability and post-viability are treated differently. 2.2 Before viability, the state’s ability to restrict abortion is more limited. 2.3 After viability, the state has greater power to prohibit abortion, subject to a health exception for the mother.
cards.cloze: Under the old framework, abortion was treated as a {{c1::substantive due process}} right included in the {{c2::right to privacy}}. The analysis turned on {{c3::fetal viability}}. 1. Viability is when a fetus can {{c4::survive outside the womb}}. 2. The law distinguished {{c5::pre-viability}} from {{c6::post-viability}} abortions: before viability the state’s power was more limited, and after viability the state had greater power to {{c7::prohibit abortion (subject to a health exception)}}.
cards.easyContent: Under the old framework, abortion was protected as part of the substantive due process right to privacy. The key dividing line was fetal viability, meaning the fetus could survive outside the womb; pre- and post-viability were treated differently.
cards.mediumContent: Under the old substantive due process analysis, abortion was a fundamental privacy right. Courts used a viability framework: viability is when the fetus can survive outside the womb, and it divided pre-viability from post-viability, with more protection before viability and more state power after viability.
cards.hardContent: Under the pre-Dobbs framework, abortion was protected as a substantive due process right within the broader constitutional right to privacy. The central organizing principle was fetal viability: viability is the point when the fetus can survive outside the womb, and it marks the legal dividing line between two regulatory regimes. Before viability, abortion enjoys stronger protection, and the state’s regulatory authority is correspondingly constrained. After viability, the state’s authority expands and it may prohibit abortion, subject to a requirement (developed in later doctrine) that there be an exception where abortion is necessary to protect the woman’s health.
cards.mnemonic: OLD PRIVACY: Abortion tied to Privacy and Viability line.
cards.clozeLite: Under the old framework, abortion was a {{c1::fundamental}} {{c2::substantive due process}} {{c3::privacy right}}, analyzed using a {{c4::viability framework}} dividing {{c5::pre-}} and {{c6::post-viability}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Right to Abortion – Pre- vs Post-Viability Rules and Undue Burden (Old Analysis)
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 031-2. Right to Abortion – Pre- vs Post-Viability Rules and Undue Burden (Old Analysis)
cards.front: Right to Abortion – Pre- vs Post-Viability Rules and Undue Burden (Old Analysis)
cards.frontPrompt: Under the old viability framework, what were the rules governing abortion pre- and post-viability, and what counted (and did not count) as an undue burden?
cards.backPlain: Under the old substantive due process framework, the state’s power to regulate abortion differed before and after viability. Pre-viability: 1. The state may not prohibit abortion. 2. The state may regulate abortion only if it does not create an undue burden on a woman’s right to obtain an abortion. 3. Undue burden examples: 3.1 Spousal notification requirements have been held to be an undue burden and therefore invalid. 4. Examples held not to be an undue burden: 4.1 24-hour waiting periods. 4.2 Partial-birth abortion bans. 4.3 Parental consent requirements (assuming proper safeguards, e.g., judicial bypass for minors). Post-viability: 5. The state may prohibit abortion. 6. Exception: Even after viability, abortion must be allowed when medically necessary to protect the mother’s health.
cards.cloze: Under the old framework, the state’s power to regulate abortion turned on {{c1::viability}}. Pre-viability: 1. The state may not {{c2::prohibit abortion}}. 2. It may regulate only if it does not create an {{c3::undue burden}} on a woman’s right to obtain an abortion. 3. Example of an undue burden: {{c4::spousal notification}} requirements. 4. Examples that are not an undue burden: {{c5::24-hour waiting periods}}, {{c6::partial-birth abortion bans}}, and {{c7::parental consent}} requirements (with proper safeguards). Post-viability: 5. The state may {{c8::prohibit abortion}}. 6. Exception: abortion must still be allowed when {{c9::medically necessary to protect the mother’s health}}.
cards.easyContent: Before viability, a state could not ban abortion and could regulate only if it did not impose an undue burden; spousal notification was an undue burden, but waiting periods, partial-birth bans, and parental consent (with safeguards) were not. After viability, the state could ban abortions but had to allow them when medically necessary to protect the mother’s health.
cards.mediumContent: Under the old viability framework, pre-viability the state could not prohibit abortions and could only regulate so long as it did not impose an undue burden on a woman’s access. Spousal notification requirements were an undue burden; 24-hour waiting periods, partial-birth abortion bans, and parental consent requirements (with appropriate safeguards) were not. After viability, the state could prohibit abortions, but any such ban still had to allow abortions that are medically necessary to protect the mother’s health.
cards.hardContent: Under the pre-Dobbs viability regime, pre-viability abortions received strong protection: the state could not ban abortion outright and could regulate only if the regulation did not place an undue burden on a woman’s right to obtain an abortion. The Supreme Court held that spousal notification laws constituted an undue burden and were invalid, whereas 24-hour waiting periods, bans on certain procedures such as so-called partial-birth abortions, and parental consent requirements (assuming appropriate protections such as a judicial bypass) did not constitute an undue burden. After viability, the balance shifted: the state could prohibit abortion altogether, but any such prohibition had to contain an exception allowing abortions when they are medically necessary to protect the mother’s health.
cards.mnemonic: Pre: No bans, no burdens; Post: Bans, but health exception.
cards.clozeLite: Under the old {{c1::viability framework}}, pre-viability the state could not {{c2::prohibit abortions}} and could regulate only if it did not impose an {{c3::undue burden}}; {{c4::spousal notification}} was an undue burden, but {{c5::24-hour waiting periods}} and {{c6::parental consent with safeguards}} were not.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Right to Abortion – Parental Involvement and Judicial Bypass (Old Analysis)
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 031-3. Right to Abortion – Parental Involvement and Judicial Bypass (Old Analysis)
cards.front: Right to Abortion – Parental Involvement and Judicial Bypass (Old Analysis)
cards.frontPrompt: Under the old abortion framework, when are parental notice or consent laws for minors valid, and what must a judicial bypass procedure allow a judge to find?
cards.backPlain: Under the old viability/undue burden framework, parental involvement laws for minors were evaluated for whether they imposed an undue burden. Parental notice/consent laws for minors: 1. A parental notice or consent requirement for a minor’s abortion does not create an undue burden if the law provides an alternative judicial bypass procedure. 2. Judicial bypass procedure: 2.1 The minor may go before a judge instead of obtaining parental consent. 2.2 The judge can approve the abortion by finding either: 2.2.1 That the abortion is in the minor’s best interests, or 2.2.2 That the minor is sufficiently mature to decide for herself.
cards.cloze: Parental notice or consent laws for minors do not create an undue burden under the old framework if the law includes an {{c1::alternative judicial bypass procedure}}. Judicial bypass procedure: 1. The minor may {{c2::go before a judge}} instead of obtaining parental consent. 2. The judge can authorize the abortion by finding either: 2.1 That abortion is in the minor’s {{c3::best interests}}, or 2.2 That the minor is {{c4::mature enough to decide for herself}}.
cards.easyContent: Parental notice or consent laws for minors were valid so long as they included a judicial bypass: the minor could ask a judge for approval instead of a parent, and the judge could approve if it was in the minor’s best interests or she was mature enough to decide.
cards.mediumContent: Under the old abortion framework, parental involvement laws for minors did not impose an undue burden if they provided a judicial bypass. A judicial bypass allows the minor to seek court authorization instead of parental consent. The judge can approve the abortion by finding either that it is in the minor’s best interests or that the minor is sufficiently mature to make the decision herself.
cards.hardContent: Within the old viability/undue burden structure, parental notice or consent restrictions on minors’ abortions were constitutional if they did not impose an undue burden. The Supreme Court held that such laws are not an undue burden so long as they provide an adequate judicial bypass mechanism. Under a judicial bypass, the minor may petition a court instead of obtaining parental consent. The judge must be empowered to approve the abortion by finding either (1) that the abortion is in the minor’s best interests or (2) that the minor is sufficiently mature and well informed to decide on her own. With this bypass in place, parental notice or consent requirements were upheld as not creating an undue burden.
cards.mnemonic: Bypass needs B/M: Best interests or Maturity.
cards.clozeLite: Parental involvement laws for minors are valid if they include a {{c1::judicial bypass}} letting a judge find {{c2::best interests}} or {{c3::sufficient maturity}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Right to Abortion – Government Funding and Provision (Old Analysis)
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 031-4. Right to Abortion – Government Funding and Provision (Old Analysis)
cards.front: Right to Abortion – Government Funding and Provision (Old Analysis)
cards.frontPrompt: Under the old abortion framework, what were the rules regarding the government’s duty to fund or provide abortions?
cards.backPlain: Under the old substantive due process abortion framework, the Constitution protected a right to obtain an abortion against certain state restrictions, but did not require the government to affirmatively fund or provide that procedure. Government funding and provision: 1. The government has no constitutional duty to subsidize abortions. 2. The government has no constitutional duty to provide abortions in public hospitals.
cards.cloze: Under the old framework, while abortion was a protected right, the government had no duty to {{c1::subsidize abortions}} and no duty to {{c2::provide abortions in public hospitals}}.
cards.easyContent: The old framework protected access against certain restrictions but did not require the state to pay for or provide abortions. There was no constitutional duty to subsidize abortions or to offer them in public hospitals.
cards.mediumContent: Even though abortion was a substantive due process right under the old framework, that did not mean the government had to fund or provide it. The government had no constitutional obligation to subsidize abortions or to make abortion services available in public hospitals.
cards.hardContent: Under the former substantive due process regime, the constitutional right to abortion was a negative right protecting against certain governmental restrictions, not a guarantee of government aid. Accordingly, the Supreme Court held that there is no constitutional duty for the government to subsidize abortions and no requirement that public hospitals or public facilities provide abortion services. Governments could favor childbirth over abortion in their allocation of public funds and services, so long as they did not impose an undue burden or outright prohibition inconsistent with the viability framework.
cards.mnemonic: Negative right: No Pay or Provide (P&P).
cards.clozeLite: Under the old framework, abortion was a {{c1::negative right}}, so the state had {{c2::no constitutional duty to subsidize}} or {{c3::provide abortions in public hospitals}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Race and National Origin – Strict Scrutiny Rule
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 035-1. Race and National Origin – Strict Scrutiny Rule
cards.front: Race and National Origin – Strict Scrutiny Rule
cards.backPlain: Classifications based on race or national origin are suspect classifications under Equal Protection and are reviewed under strict scrutiny. • Scope: This applies whether the classification burdens minorities or is intended to benefit them (such as affirmative action programs). • Strict scrutiny test: The government must show (1) a compelling governmental interest and (2) that the challenged classification is narrowly tailored to achieve that interest. • Typical contexts: Race and national origin strict scrutiny frequently arises in affirmative action and other race-conscious programs, especially in education and public employment.
cards.frontPrompt: How does Equal Protection treat race and national origin classifications, and what does strict scrutiny require in this context?
cards.cloze: Classifications based on {{c1::race}} or {{c2::national origin}} are {{c3::suspect classifications}} under Equal Protection and are reviewed under {{c4::strict scrutiny}}. The government must show a {{c5::compelling governmental interest}} and that the classification is {{c6::narrowly tailored}} to achieve that interest, even when the law {{c7::benefits minorities}} (e.g., affirmative action programs).
cards.easyContent: Race and national origin are suspect classifications and always get strict scrutiny, even when used to help minorities. The government must show a compelling interest and narrow tailoring.
cards.mediumContent: Any classification based on race or national origin is suspect and subject to strict scrutiny. The government must demonstrate a compelling interest and narrow tailoring, and this is true for both laws that burden minorities and race-conscious programs that benefit them.
cards.hardContent: Under Equal Protection, race and national origin classifications are inherently suspect and are subject to strict scrutiny. This means that any governmental use of race or national origin must serve a compelling governmental interest and be narrowly tailored to achieve that interest. The rule applies regardless of whether the classification burdens a racial minority or is designed to benefit one, as in affirmative action or other race-conscious remedial measures. Courts therefore closely scrutinize the fit between the asserted compelling interest and the specific racial means employed.
cards.mnemonic: RS: Race suspect, strict scrutiny; needs compelling, narrow fit.
cards.clozeLite: Race and {{c1::national origin}} are {{c2::suspect classifications}} and always get {{c3::strict scrutiny}}, requiring a {{c4::compelling interest}} and {{c5::narrow tailoring}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 035-2. Race-Based Affirmative Action – Numerical Quotas
cards.front: Race-Based Affirmative Action – Numerical Quotas
cards.backPlain: Numerical set-asides (quotas) based on race or national origin are highly disfavored and rarely upheld under strict scrutiny. • General rule: Explicit numerical quotas reserving a fixed number or percentage of opportunities for a racial group are suspect. • Validity requirement: To be valid, such quotas require clear proof of persistent and readily identifiable discrimination by the particular governmental unit adopting the quota. • Insufficient justification: General references to past societal discrimination or broad historical wrongs are not enough; the discrimination must be specific and well-documented. • Likely outcome: Because this showing is difficult, race-based numerical set-asides and rigid quotas are unlikely to be upheld.
cards.frontPrompt: When, if ever, are race-based numerical set-asides (quotas) permissible under Equal Protection, and what proof is required?
cards.cloze: {{c1::Numerical set-asides (quotas)}} based on race or national origin are {{c2::highly disfavored}} under strict scrutiny. To be valid, they require {{c3::clear proof of persistent and readily identifiable discrimination}} by the government actor, and {{c4::general past wrongs or societal discrimination}} are {{c5::insufficient}}. As a result, such quotas are {{c6::unlikely to be upheld}}.
cards.easyContent: Race-based numerical quotas are almost never valid. They need clear proof of long-standing, specific government discrimination, not just general societal racism.
cards.mediumContent: Race-based numerical set-asides or quotas are suspect under strict scrutiny. They may only be upheld if the government can show clear proof of persistent, readily identifiable discrimination by that governmental body; generalized references to past societal discrimination are not enough, so quotas are rarely upheld.
cards.hardContent: Affirmative action programs that use explicit numerical set-asides or quotas for particular racial or ethnic groups are subject to strict scrutiny and are strongly disfavored. For such a quota to survive, the government must produce clear, specific evidence of persistent and readily identifiable discrimination by the government entity itself, demonstrating a tight remedial fit between the discrimination found and the quota imposed. Vague or generalized appeals to historical or societal discrimination will not suffice. Because this evidentiary showing is demanding and quotas are considered a blunt instrument, racial numerical set-asides are seldom upheld as constitutional.
cards.mnemonic: Quotas need CPR: Clear, Persistent, Readily identifiable discrimination.
cards.clozeLite: Race-based {{c1::numerical set-asides or quotas}} face {{c2::strict scrutiny}} and are valid only with {{c3::clear proof of persistent, readily identifiable discrimination by that governmental body}}; {{c4::general societal discrimination is insufficient}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 035-3. Race in University Admissions – Diversity
cards.front: Race in University Admissions – Diversity
cards.backPlain: Race or national origin may sometimes be considered in university admissions under strict scrutiny, subject to tight limits. • Compelling interest: Student body diversity can qualify as a compelling governmental interest in higher education. • Use of race: Educational institutions may use race or national origin as one factor in a holistic, individualized admissions process. • Not a defining criterion: Race may not be used as a defining or decisive criterion, such as automatically awarding admission based solely on race or assigning fixed points or separate tracks by race. • Narrow tailoring: Universities must show that no workable race-neutral alternatives would achieve the diversity they seek, and the use of race must be limited in scope and duration.
cards.frontPrompt: Under what conditions may universities consider race or national origin in admissions decisions consistent with Equal Protection?
cards.cloze: In higher education admissions, {{c1::student body diversity}} may be a {{c2::compelling interest}}. Universities may consider {{c3::race or national origin}} as {{c4::one factor}} in a {{c5::holistic, individualized}} admissions process, but may not treat race as a {{c6::defining or decisive criterion}} (e.g., automatic admission based solely on race). They must also show that there are {{c7::no workable race-neutral alternatives}} that would achieve the desired diversity.
cards.easyContent: Universities can sometimes use race as one factor in a holistic admissions process to pursue diversity, but race cannot be decisive, and schools must show no good race-neutral alternative.
cards.mediumContent: Student body diversity in higher education can be a compelling interest, so universities may consider race or national origin as one factor in a holistic admissions policy. However, race cannot be the defining or automatic basis for admission, and the university must show that no workable race-neutral alternatives would achieve comparable diversity.
cards.hardContent: Under strict scrutiny, higher education institutions may pursue student body diversity as a compelling interest. To do so constitutionally, they may consider race or national origin as one factor within a holistic, individualized admissions process that evaluates each applicant on multiple dimensions. The institution may not rely on race as a defining or decisive criterion—such as awarding automatic admission, fixed points, or separate admissions tracks solely on the basis of race. Additionally, narrow tailoring requires that the university demonstrate that no workable race-neutral alternatives can achieve the diversity it seeks, and that the consideration of race is limited, flexible, and subject to periodic review.
cards.mnemonic: HOLD: Holistic, One factor, Limited, Diversity interest.
cards.clozeLite: In higher education, {{c1::student body diversity}} can be a {{c2::compelling interest}}, allowing race as {{c3::one factor in holistic admissions}} if {{c4::no workable race-neutral alternatives}} exist.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 035-4. Public School Integration – Race-Based Assignments
cards.front: Public School Integration – Race-Based Assignments
cards.backPlain: K–12 public school systems face strict limits on assigning students to schools based on race. • General rule: Public schools may not assign students to particular schools on the basis of race simply to achieve integration or racial balancing. • Racial balancing: Racial balancing for its own sake is generally not considered a compelling state interest under strict scrutiny. • Implication: Voluntary integration plans that rely directly on each student’s race to determine school assignment are constitutionally suspect unless tied to remedying specific, identified past discrimination by that school district.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the Equal Protection limits on using race to assign students to K–12 public schools for integration purposes?
cards.cloze: In K–12 public schools, systems may not {{c1::assign students to schools on the basis of race}} simply to achieve integration. {{c2::Racial balancing for its own sake}} is generally {{c3::not a compelling state interest}} under strict scrutiny, making voluntary race-based assignment plans constitutionally suspect.
cards.easyContent: Public schools generally cannot assign students by race just to balance racial numbers; racial balancing alone is not a compelling interest.
cards.mediumContent: Public K–12 school districts cannot assign students to specific schools on the basis of race merely to achieve racial integration or balancing. Under strict scrutiny, racial balancing for its own sake is not a compelling state interest, so race-based assignment plans are usually invalid unless clearly tied to remedying identified past discrimination by that district.
cards.hardContent: Race-based assignments in K–12 public schools are subject to strict scrutiny. Districts may not assign students to schools on the basis of race merely to attain a preferred racial mix or to achieve racial balancing. The Supreme Court has held that racial balancing for its own sake does not constitute a compelling state interest. Accordingly, voluntary integration plans that use each individual student’s race as a controlling factor in school assignment will ordinarily be unconstitutional unless they are narrowly tailored to remedy specific, proven past discrimination by that school system.
cards.mnemonic: K–12: "No BAL"—No Balancing Along Lines of race alone.
cards.clozeLite: K–12 race-based school assignments face {{c1::strict scrutiny}}; {{c2::racial balancing alone}} is not a {{c3::compelling interest}} unless {{c4::remedying that district’s proven past discrimination}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Right to Travel – Equal Protection and Durational Residency
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 038-1. Right to Travel – Equal Protection and Durational Residency
cards.front: Right to Travel – Equal Protection and Durational Residency
cards.frontPrompt: How is the fundamental right to travel analyzed under equal protection, and which durational residency requirements are valid or invalid?
cards.backPlain: Right to Travel under Equal Protection 1. Fundamental right and standard of review - The right to travel is a fundamental right. - When a law burdens interstate movement or penalizes recent arrivals, it is usually analyzed under equal protection. - Standard of review: strict scrutiny. 2. How the issue arises - Typically arises when laws impede movement between states or discriminate against new residents. - A common form is a durational residency requirement: a rule requiring some minimum in-state residency period to qualify for a state benefit or privilege. 3. Durational residency requirements A. Invalid durational residency requirements (fail strict scrutiny): - A 1-year residency requirement to receive welfare benefits. - A 1-year residency requirement to receive subsidized medical care. - A 1-year residency requirement to vote in state elections. B. Valid durational residency requirements (permitted): - A 30-day residency requirement to vote in state elections. - A 1-year residency requirement to obtain a divorce in the state. 4. Framing - Although the right to travel can also be framed as a substantive due process liberty, on the bar exam it is often tested as an equal protection classification problem involving durational residency.
cards.cloze: Right to Travel under Equal Protection 1. Fundamental right and standard of review - The {{c1::right to travel}} is a {{c2::fundamental right}}. - When a law burdens {{c3::interstate movement}} or penalizes recent arrivals, it is usually analyzed under {{c4::equal protection}}. - Standard of review: {{c5::strict scrutiny}}. 2. How the issue arises - Typically arises when laws {{c6::impede movement between states}} or {{c7::discriminate against new residents}}. - A common form is a {{c8::durational residency requirement}}: a rule requiring some minimum in-state residency period to qualify for a state benefit or privilege. 3. Durational residency requirements A. {{c9::Invalid}} durational residency requirements (fail strict scrutiny): - A {{c10::1-year}} residency requirement to receive {{c11::welfare}} benefits. - A {{c12::1-year}} residency requirement to receive {{c13::subsidized medical care}}. - A {{c14::1-year}} residency requirement to {{c15::vote in state elections}}. B. {{c16::Valid}} durational residency requirements (permitted): - A {{c17::30-day}} residency requirement to {{c18::vote in state elections}}. - A {{c19::1-year}} residency requirement to {{c20::obtain a divorce}} in the state. 4. Framing - Although the right to travel can also be framed as a {{c21::substantive due process}} liberty, it is often tested as an {{c22::equal protection classification}} problem involving durational residency.
cards.easyContent: The right to travel is fundamental, so laws that burden interstate movement or penalize new residents are usually reviewed under equal protection with strict scrutiny. One-year residency requirements for welfare, subsidized medical care, or voting are invalid, but a 30-day residency to vote and a 1-year residency to get a divorce are valid.
cards.mediumContent: The right to travel is a fundamental right often analyzed under equal protection when a state law burdens interstate movement or discriminates against new residents. Strict scrutiny applies. These cases commonly involve durational residency requirements for state benefits or privileges. The Court has held that 1-year residency requirements for welfare, subsidized medical care, or voting in state elections are invalid. By contrast, a 30-day residency requirement to vote and a 1-year residency requirement to obtain a divorce are valid durational requirements.
cards.hardContent: The right to travel is a fundamental constitutional right. When the government significantly burdens interstate movement or discriminates against recent arrivals, the issue is typically treated as an equal protection classification problem and triggers strict scrutiny. The most common mechanism is a durational residency requirement, which conditions eligibility for state benefits or privileges on a minimum period of residence. Durational residency rules that effectively penalize new residents for exercising the right to travel—such as 1-year residency requirements for welfare benefits, subsidized medical care, or voting in state elections—are invalid. However, shorter or more narrowly tailored durational rules that serve administrative or jurisdictional interests are allowed, including a 30-day residency requirement to vote in state elections and a 1-year residency requirement to obtain a divorce in the state. While the right to travel can also be framed as a substantive due process liberty, on exams it is commonly tested through this equal protection and durational-residency framework.
cards.mnemonic: Travel timers: 30 vote OK, 1-year divorce OK, 1-year welfare/vote NO.
cards.atomizationNotes: Child card focusing on right to travel and durational residency requirements under equal protection.
cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::right to travel}} is {{c2::fundamental}} and burdens are reviewed under {{c3::equal protection}} with {{c4::strict scrutiny}}; {{c5::1-year welfare or voting}} residency rules are {{c6::invalid}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Right to Vote – Equal Protection, One-Person-One-Vote, and Elections
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 038-2. Right to Vote – Equal Protection, One-Person-One-Vote, and Elections
cards.front: Right to Vote – Equal Protection, One-Person-One-Vote, and Elections
cards.frontPrompt: How is the fundamental right to vote analyzed under equal protection, and what are the key rules on one-person-one-vote, districting, and at-large elections?
cards.backPlain: Right to Vote under Equal Protection 1. Fundamental right and standard of review - The right to vote in general elections is a fundamental right. - When a law denies some citizens the right to vote or significantly burdens voting, it is analyzed under equal protection. - Standard of review: strict scrutiny. 2. Denial or dilution of the vote - Equal protection is triggered when laws deny some citizens the right to vote or dilute their voting power. 3. One-person, one-vote requirement - The one-person, one-vote requirement must be satisfied for all state and local elections. - For elected bodies, voting districts must be substantially similar in population so that votes are weighted equally as nearly as practicable. 4. At-large elections - At-large elections are systems in which all voters in the jurisdiction vote for all office holders, rather than separate district representatives. - At-large election schemes are constitutional if they are not adopted or maintained for a discriminatory purpose (e.g., to dilute minority voting strength). 5. Framing - Although the right to vote can also be understood as a substantive due process liberty, exam questions typically frame denials or dilutions of the vote as equal protection violations requiring strict scrutiny.
cards.cloze: Right to Vote under Equal Protection 1. Fundamental right and standard of review - The {{c1::right to vote}} in general elections is a {{c2::fundamental right}}. - When a law {{c3::denies some citizens the right to vote}} or significantly burdens voting, it is analyzed under {{c4::equal protection}}. - Standard of review: {{c5::strict scrutiny}}. 2. Denial or dilution of the vote - Equal protection is triggered when laws {{c6::deny}} some citizens the right to vote or {{c7::dilute}} their voting power. 3. One-person, one-vote requirement - The {{c8::one-person, one-vote}} requirement must be satisfied for all {{c9::state and local elections}}. - For elected bodies, voting districts must be {{c10::substantially similar in population}} so that votes are weighted equally as nearly as practicable. 4. At-large elections - {{c11::At-large elections}} are systems in which all voters in the jurisdiction vote for {{c12::all office holders}}, rather than separate district representatives. - At-large election schemes are {{c13::constitutional}} if they are not adopted or maintained for a {{c14::discriminatory purpose}} (such as diluting minority voting strength). 5. Framing - Although the right to vote can also be understood as a {{c15::substantive due process}} liberty, exam questions typically frame denials or dilutions of the vote as {{c16::equal protection}} violations requiring {{c17::strict scrutiny}}.
cards.easyContent: The right to vote is fundamental. Laws that deny some citizens the vote or significantly burden it are analyzed under equal protection with strict scrutiny. All state and local elections must meet one-person-one-vote with substantially equal-population districts, and at-large elections are allowed if not adopted or maintained for a discriminatory purpose.
cards.mediumContent: The right to vote in general elections is a fundamental right. When a state law denies some citizens the right to vote or dilutes their voting power, equal protection applies and strict scrutiny is used. One-person, one-vote applies to all state and local elections, requiring substantially equal-population districts so that each vote counts roughly equally. At-large elections, where all voters vote for all officials, are constitutionally permissible provided they are not adopted or maintained for a discriminatory purpose, such as diluting minority voting strength.
cards.hardContent: The right to vote is a fundamental constitutional right. State action denying the vote to some citizens, or significantly burdening or diluting voting power, is analyzed under the Equal Protection Clause and triggers strict scrutiny. The one-person, one-vote principle applies in all state and local elections: for elected bodies, districts must be drawn so that populations are substantially equal, thereby ensuring that each vote is weighted as equally as practicable. Election structures can also raise equal protection concerns. At-large election systems—in which every voter in the jurisdiction votes for all members of an elected body—are not per se unconstitutional; they are valid so long as they are not adopted or maintained for a discriminatory purpose, such as intentionally diluting minority voting strength. While the right to vote can also be treated as a substantive due process liberty, exam questions usually frame these issues as equal protection challenges focused on denial or dilution of the vote.
cards.mnemonic: VOTE: Voting fundamental, One-person, districts Truly Equal.
cards.atomizationNotes: Child card focusing on right to vote, one-person-one-vote, districting, and at-large elections under equal protection.
cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::right to vote}} is {{c2::fundamental}} and burdens are reviewed under {{c3::equal protection}} with {{c4::strict scrutiny}}; {{c5::one-person-one-vote}} requires {{c6::substantially equal-population districts}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Free Speech – Content-Based vs. Content-Neutral Restrictions
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 039-1. Free Speech – Content-Based vs. Content-Neutral Restrictions
cards.front: Free Speech – Content-Based vs. Content-Neutral Restrictions
cards.frontPrompt: For protected speech under the First Amendment, how do you distinguish content-based from content-neutral restrictions, and what level of scrutiny applies to each?
cards.backPlain: For protected speech, the key threshold question is whether the government restriction is content-based or content-neutral. 1. Content-based restrictions: - Definition: The government seeks to restrict speech because of its content—based on the subject matter or the viewpoint expressed. - Level of scrutiny: Strict scrutiny. - Strict scrutiny requires the law to be narrowly tailored to serve a compelling government interest. 2. Content-neutral restrictions: - Definition: The restriction applies to all expression regardless of content or viewpoint, often as a time, place, or manner regulation. - Level of scrutiny: Intermediate scrutiny. - Intermediate scrutiny requires the law to be narrowly tailored to serve an important or significant government interest and leave open ample alternative channels for communication.
cards.cloze: For {{c1::protected speech}}, the threshold question is whether a restriction is {{c2::content-based}} or {{c3::content-neutral}}. 1. {{c4::Content-based restrictions}}: - The government targets speech because of its {{c5::content}}—its {{c6::subject matter}} or {{c7::viewpoint}}. - Reviewed under {{c8::strict scrutiny}}, requiring a {{c9::compelling government interest}} and {{c10::narrow tailoring}}. 2. {{c11::Content-neutral restrictions}}: - Apply to all expression regardless of {{c12::content or viewpoint}}, often as {{c13::time, place, or manner}} regulations. - Reviewed under {{c14::intermediate scrutiny}}, requiring an {{c15::important or significant government interest}}, {{c16::narrow tailoring}}, and {{c17::ample alternative channels}} for communication.
cards.easyContent: For protected speech, content-based restrictions (targeting subject matter or viewpoint) get strict scrutiny; content-neutral time, place, or manner rules get intermediate scrutiny.
cards.mediumContent: When speech is protected, first ask whether the law is content-based—targeting the subject matter or viewpoint of speech—or content-neutral—applied regardless of content, often as a time, place, or manner regulation. Content-based laws are subject to strict scrutiny and must be narrowly tailored to a compelling interest. Content-neutral laws are subject to intermediate scrutiny and must be narrowly tailored to an important interest while leaving open ample alternative channels.
cards.hardContent: In First Amendment analysis of protected speech, the central framework distinguishes content-based from content-neutral restrictions. A regulation is content-based if it targets speech because of its content, including its subject matter or the viewpoint expressed. Such regulations are subject to strict scrutiny, which requires that the government show a compelling interest and that the regulation is narrowly tailored to achieve that interest. A regulation is content-neutral when it applies to all expression without regard to content or viewpoint, often in the form of time, place, or manner restrictions. These are subject to intermediate scrutiny, under which the government must demonstrate an important or significant interest, that the regulation is narrowly tailored (not substantially broader than necessary), and that it leaves open ample alternative channels for communication.
cards.mnemonic: CBCN → Content-Based = Compelling + strict; Content-Neutral = important + intermediate.
cards.atomizationNotes: Child card focused on content-based vs. content-neutral framework and associated scrutiny levels.
cards.clozeLite: Content-{{c1::based}} speech laws (subject or viewpoint) get {{c2::strict scrutiny}}; content-{{c3::neutral}} time, place, manner rules get {{c4::intermediate scrutiny}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Free Speech – Unprotected and Lesser-Protected Categories
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 039-2. Free Speech – Unprotected and Lesser-Protected Categories
cards.front: Free Speech – Unprotected and Lesser-Protected Categories
cards.frontPrompt: Which types of speech receive lesser or no First Amendment protection, and how are restrictions on those categories analyzed?
cards.backPlain: Some categories of speech receive lesser or no First Amendment protection. Restrictions on these categories are generally analyzed under category-specific tests rather than the usual strict or intermediate scrutiny for fully protected speech. 1. Examples of unprotected or lesser-protected speech: - Obscenity. - Defamation. - Incitement to imminent lawless action. - Commercial speech (protected, but under reduced protection and a special test). 2. Analysis: - For each category, courts apply the specific doctrinal test applicable to that type of speech (e.g., obscenity test, defamation rules, incitement test, commercial speech test). - Because the speech is unprotected or less protected, the government has more leeway to regulate, and full strict scrutiny usually does not apply.
cards.cloze: Some categories of speech receive {{c1::lesser or no First Amendment protection}} and are evaluated under {{c2::category-specific tests}} rather than ordinary strict or intermediate scrutiny. Examples include: - {{c3::Obscenity}}. - {{c4::Defamation}}. - {{c5::Incitement}} to imminent lawless action. - {{c6::Commercial speech}} (protected, but under reduced protection and a specialized test). Because these categories are {{c7::unprotected or lesser-protected}}, the government has {{c8::greater leeway}} to regulate them, and courts apply the {{c9::specific doctrinal test}} for that category.
cards.easyContent: Obscenity, defamation, incitement, and commercial speech are examples of unprotected or lesser-protected speech. Each has its own specific test instead of normal strict or intermediate scrutiny.
cards.mediumContent: Certain speech categories receive no or reduced First Amendment protection, such as obscenity, defamation, incitement to imminent lawless action, and commercial speech. Rather than applying the general content-based/content-neutral scrutiny framework, courts use doctrinal tests tailored to each category, which usually give the government more regulatory leeway than with fully protected speech.
cards.hardContent: In First Amendment doctrine, not all speech receives full constitutional protection. Categories such as obscenity, defamation, incitement to imminent lawless action, and commercial speech are treated as unprotected or lesser-protected. When the government regulates within one of these categories, courts do not typically apply strict or intermediate scrutiny as they would for fully protected speech. Instead, they apply the specialized doctrinal test for that category—for example, the obscenity test, the actual malice and fault standards in defamation, the incitement test, or the commercial speech test. Because the speech is considered unprotected or less protected, the government generally has broader power to regulate it.
cards.mnemonic: ODIC: Obscenity, Defamation, Incitement, Commercial speech.
cards.atomizationNotes: Child card focused on categories of unprotected or lesser-protected speech and their treatment.
cards.clozeLite: Certain {{c1::speech categories}} like {{c2::obscenity}}, {{c3::defamation}}, {{c4::incitement}} and {{c5::commercial speech}} use {{c6::special doctrinal tests}} instead of normal scrutiny.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 039-3. Free Speech – Public Forum Doctrine
cards.front: Free Speech – Public Forum Doctrine
cards.frontPrompt: How does the public forum doctrine affect regulation of speech on government property under the First Amendment?
cards.backPlain: When speech occurs on government property, the public forum doctrine governs how the First Amendment applies. 1. Types of forums: - Traditional public forum: Places historically open to speech, such as streets and parks. - Designated public forum: Government property the government intentionally opens for expressive activity. - Non-public forum (and limited public forum): Government property not traditionally or fully open to public expression. 2. Significance: - The level of scrutiny for speech regulations on government property depends on the forum classification. - Traditional and designated public forums generally receive stronger protection, while non-public forums allow more regulation, so long as it is reasonable and not based on viewpoint. (Details of the exact tests for each forum are covered in separate cards; this card focuses on identifying the role of forum status in the analysis.)
cards.cloze: When speech occurs on {{c1::government property}}, the {{c2::public forum doctrine}} determines how the First Amendment applies. Types of forums: - {{c3::Traditional public forum}} – e.g., streets and parks, historically open to speech. - {{c4::Designated public forum}} – government property the state has intentionally opened for {{c5::expressive activity}}. - {{c6::Non-public forum}} (including limited public forums) – property {{c7::not traditionally or fully open}} to public expression. The forum classification affects the {{c8::level of scrutiny}} and how strictly courts review {{c9::speech regulations}} on that property.
cards.easyContent: On government property, the public forum doctrine applies: classify the property as a traditional public forum, designated public forum, or non-public forum, and the forum type determines how strictly speech regulations are reviewed.
cards.mediumContent: The public forum doctrine governs speech on government property. You must classify the property as a traditional public forum, a designated public forum, or a non-public/limited public forum. Traditional and designated public forums get stronger First Amendment protection, while non-public forums allow more regulation. The forum status, together with whether a regulation is content-based or content-neutral, determines the applicable scrutiny.
cards.hardContent: For speech on government property, the First Amendment analysis incorporates the public forum doctrine. Courts first classify the property as a traditional public forum—such as streets and parks—where expressive activity has historically been allowed; a designated public forum—property the government has intentionally opened for expression; or a non-public or limited public forum—property not traditionally or fully open to public expression. This forum classification is crucial because it shapes the level of scrutiny applied to regulations on speech in that location: traditional and designated public forums receive robust protection, while non-public forums allow more extensive regulation, so long as it is reasonable and not based on viewpoint.
cards.mnemonic: Forums TDN: Traditional, Designated, Non-public—type decides toughness.
cards.atomizationNotes: Child card focused on identifying forum types and their role in First Amendment analysis.
cards.clozeLite: Public forum doctrine classifies government property as {{c1::traditional}}, {{c2::designated}}, or {{c3::non-public/limited}}; {{c4::forum status}} plus {{c5::content-based vs. content-neutral}} sets scrutiny.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Free Speech – Freedom of the Press and Matters of Public Concern
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 039-4. Free Speech – Freedom of the Press and Matters of Public Concern
cards.front: Free Speech – Freedom of the Press and Matters of Public Concern
cards.frontPrompt: What protection does the First Amendment provide to the press when publishing matters of public concern, and what standard applies to restrictions or punishments?
cards.backPlain: The First Amendment protects freedom of the press, including publication of matters of public concern. 1. Right to publish matters of public concern: - The press (and speakers generally) has a strong right to publish information on issues of public concern. 2. Standard for restrictions or punishment: - Any restriction or punishment on such publication must be narrowly tailored to further a state interest of the highest order. - This functions as a form of strict scrutiny: the interest must be extremely important, and the regulation must be narrowly drawn to achieve it.
cards.cloze: The First Amendment protects {{c1::freedom of the press}}, including the right to {{c2::publish matters of public concern}}. Any restriction or punishment on such publication must be {{c3::narrowly tailored}} to further a {{c4::state interest of the highest order}}, which effectively applies {{c5::strict scrutiny}} to such regulations.
cards.easyContent: The press has strong protection to publish matters of public concern. Restrictions or punishments must be narrowly tailored to serve a state interest of the highest order, essentially strict scrutiny.
cards.mediumContent: Freedom of the press under the First Amendment includes a robust right to publish information on matters of public concern. Government efforts to restrict or punish such publication are subject to a demanding standard: they must be narrowly tailored to further a state interest of the highest order, effectively requiring strict scrutiny-level justification.
cards.hardContent: Freedom of the press is a core component of the First Amendment and encompasses the right to publish matters of public concern. When the government seeks to restrict or punish the press for such publication, courts demand that the regulation be narrowly tailored to serve a state interest of the highest order. This is functionally equivalent to strict scrutiny: the interest must be of the highest importance, and the means chosen must be closely drawn to achieve that interest, leaving minimal room for unnecessary suppression of speech on issues of public concern.
cards.mnemonic: Press on public issues needs Highest, Narrow, Strict protection.
cards.atomizationNotes: Child card focused on freedom of the press and the strict standard for regulating publication of matters of public concern.
cards.clozeLite: Press publishing {{c1::matters of public concern}} can be restricted only if laws are {{c2::narrowly tailored}} to a {{c3::state interest of the highest order}} ({{c4::strict scrutiny}}).

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 041-1. Limited/Designated Public Forums – Definition & Test
cards.front: Limited/Designated Public Forums – Definition & Test
cards.backPlain: 1. Limited/designated public forums 1.1 Definition: Government properties that the government affirmatively opens for speech but can close at any time. 1.2 Examples: - Public school facilities made available for outside group meetings (e.g., Girl Scouts, civic groups). - Advertising space in government property (e.g., on buses, in transit stations) opened for private advertisers. 1.3 Test while the forum is open: 1.3.1 The same rules apply as in a traditional public forum. - The government may not discriminate based on viewpoint. - Content-neutral time, place, and manner regulations are allowed if they serve an important government interest and leave open adequate alternative channels (public forum standards). 1.3.2 Content-based restrictions while the forum is open must satisfy strict scrutiny. 1.4 When the forum is closed or restricted: 1.4.1 If the government closes the forum entirely to speech, it is no longer a limited/designated public forum. 1.4.2 If the government restricts the forum to certain types of speech or classes of speakers (e.g., only civic groups or only certain types of ads), the remaining regulation is analyzed under the non-public forum standard (reasonable, viewpoint-neutral).
cards.frontPrompt: What is a limited or designated public forum, and what standards govern speech restrictions in such a forum while it is open and when it is closed or restricted?
cards.cloze: A {{c1::limited/designated public forum}} is a government property that the government {{c2::affirmatively opens for speech}} but {{c3::can close at any time}}. Examples include {{c4::public school facilities}} opened for outside group meetings and {{c5::advertising space in government property}} opened for private ads. While the forum is open, the {{c6::same rules as a traditional public forum}} apply: the government may not {{c7::discriminate based on viewpoint}}, and {{c8::content-based}} restrictions must satisfy {{c9::strict scrutiny}} (while content-neutral time, place, and manner limits must meet public forum standards). If the government {{c10::closes the forum entirely}} to speech, it is no longer a limited/designated public forum. If the government {{c11::restricts}} the forum to certain {{c12::types of speech}} or {{c13::classes of speakers}}, remaining regulations are analyzed under the {{c14::non-public forum}} test (reasonable and viewpoint neutral).
cards.easyContent: A limited or designated public forum is government property the government has opened for speech, like school facilities used for meetings or ad space on buses. While it is open, it is treated like a public forum: no viewpoint discrimination and strict scrutiny for content-based limits. If the government closes it or narrows it to certain types of speech or speakers, then it is treated as a non-public forum.
cards.mediumContent: Limited/designated public forums are government properties the government has affirmatively opened to expressive activity. Examples include public school facilities used for outside meetings or advertising space on government property opened to private advertisers. While the forum is open, the same rules apply as in a traditional public forum: the government may not discriminate by viewpoint; content-neutral time, place, and manner restrictions must meet public forum standards, and content-based regulations must satisfy strict scrutiny. If the government closes the forum to speech or restricts it to certain types of speech or classes of speakers, the remaining speech regulations are analyzed under the non-public forum standard (reasonable and viewpoint neutral).
cards.hardContent: Limited or designated public forums are government properties that are not traditionally open to expressive activity but that the government has chosen to open for speech; they may be closed at any time. Examples include public school auditoriums or classrooms opened for community group meetings and advertising space on buses or in transit stations once opened to private advertisers. While such a forum is open, it is governed by the same standards as a traditional public forum: the government may not engage in viewpoint discrimination, content-neutral time, place, and manner restrictions must be narrowly tailored to serve an important governmental interest and leave open adequate alternative channels, and content-based restrictions on speech must satisfy strict scrutiny. If the government decides to close the forum entirely to speech, it ceases to be a limited/designated public forum. If instead the government restricts access to certain subjects or classes of speakers (e.g., only civic groups or only certain categories of ads), further restrictions are then governed by the non-public forum test, requiring that they be reasonable in light of the forum's purpose and viewpoint neutral.
cards.mnemonic: OPENED = public forum rules; NARROWED = non-public rules.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::limited/designated public forum}} is {{c2::gov't property opened to speech}} and, while open, gets {{c3::public forum rules (no viewpoint bias, strict scrutiny for content-based limits)}}; once {{c4::closed or narrowed}}, remaining rules use the {{c5::non-public forum test (reasonable + viewpoint neutral)}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 041-2. Non-Public Forums – Definition & Test
cards.front: Non-Public Forums – Definition & Test
cards.backPlain: 2. Non-public forums 2.1 Definition: Government property that is not, by tradition or by government designation, a forum for public communication and that can be closed to speech. 2.2 Common examples: - Military bases - Airport terminals - Internal government office mail systems - Government workplaces not opened to public expression 2.3 Test for speech regulation in non-public forums: 2.3.1 The regulation must be reasonably related to a legitimate governmental purpose. 2.3.2 The regulation must be viewpoint neutral. 2.4 Content-neutrality not required: 2.4.1 The government may allow speech on some subjects but not others (subject-based distinctions are permitted). 2.4.2 However, once the government opens a subject to speech, it may not favor one viewpoint over another on that subject. 2.5 Relationship to limited/designated public forums: 2.5.1 When a limited/designated public forum is closed or restricted to certain types or classes of speech, remaining speech restrictions are analyzed as non-public forum regulations using this reasonableness and viewpoint-neutrality test.
cards.frontPrompt: What is a non-public forum, and what standards govern the government's regulation of speech in such forums, including its ability to distinguish among subjects and viewpoints?
cards.cloze: A {{c1::non-public forum}} is government property that is not, by {{c2::tradition or designation}}, a forum for public communication and that can be {{c3::closed to speech}}. Common examples include {{c4::military bases}}, {{c5::airport terminals}}, and {{c6::internal government office mail systems}}. In a non-public forum, the government may regulate speech if the regulation is {{c7::reasonably related}} to a {{c8::legitimate governmental purpose}} and is {{c9::viewpoint neutral}}. Content-neutrality is not required: the government may {{c10::allow some subjects but not others}}. However, once it opens a {{c11::subject}} to speech, it may not favor one {{c12::viewpoint}} over another on that subject. When a {{c13::limited/designated public forum}} is closed or restricted to certain types or classes of speech, further speech restrictions are evaluated under this {{c14::non-public forum}} standard.
cards.easyContent: A non-public forum is government property that is not open for public speech, like military bases, airport terminals, or internal mail systems. The government can limit speech there if its rules are reasonably related to a legitimate purpose and are viewpoint neutral. It can choose which subjects are allowed, but once it allows a subject, it cannot favor one viewpoint over another.
cards.mediumContent: Non-public forums are government properties that are not, by tradition or designation, open for general public expression—for example, military bases, airport terminals, and internal government office mail systems. The government has broad control over speech in these places: it may regulate speech if the rule is reasonably related to a legitimate governmental purpose and is viewpoint neutral. Content neutrality is not required; the government may permit speech on some topics but not others. However, once it allows a subject, it cannot discriminate among viewpoints on that subject. When a limited/designated public forum is closed or restricted to particular topics or speakers, remaining speech limits are analyzed under this same non-public forum standard.
cards.hardContent: A non-public forum is government property that is not, either by historical tradition or by explicit designation, a place for public communication and that the government may keep closed to expressive activity. Examples include military installations, airport terminals, internal government mail systems, and ordinary government workplaces not opened for public expression. In a non-public forum, the government has greater regulatory authority: it may impose speech restrictions that are reasonably related to a legitimate governmental purpose and that are viewpoint neutral. Unlike in traditional or limited/designated public forums, the government need not be content-neutral; it may choose to allow discussion of certain subjects while excluding others entirely. However, once it opens a subject to speech, the First Amendment forbids viewpoint discrimination: the government may not favor one side of the debate over another on that permitted subject. When a limited or designated public forum is closed or narrowed so that only particular types of speech or speakers are allowed, subsequent regulations are evaluated under this non-public forum reasonableness-and-viewpoint-neutrality test.
cards.mnemonic: NON-PUBLIC: Not Open, Narrow—Pick topics, but no viewpoint picks.
cards.clozeLite: In a {{c1::non-public forum}}, the government may regulate speech if rules are {{c2::reasonably related to a legitimate purpose}} and {{c3::viewpoint neutral}}, and may {{c4::choose allowed subjects but not favor viewpoints}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Prior Restraints – Definition and Strict Scrutiny
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 042-1. Prior Restraints – Definition and Strict Scrutiny
cards.front: Prior Restraints – Definition and Strict Scrutiny
cards.backPlain: A prior restraint is a court order or other governmental ban on speech or publication before it occurs. Prior restraints are presumptively invalid and are subject to strict scrutiny, so they are very difficult to uphold. Prior restraints often arise as court orders or injunctions preventing speech or publication before it happens.
cards.frontPrompt: What is a prior restraint on speech, and what level of scrutiny applies to it?
cards.cloze: A {{c1::prior restraint}} is a {{c2::court order or other governmental ban on speech or publication before it occurs}}. Prior restraints are {{c3::presumptively invalid}} and are subject to {{c4::strict scrutiny}}, making them very difficult to uphold. They often arise as {{c5::court orders or injunctions preventing speech or publication}}.
cards.easyContent: A prior restraint is a government order stopping speech before it happens. It is presumptively invalid and must satisfy strict scrutiny.
cards.mediumContent: A prior restraint is a court order or other governmental ban on speech or publication before it occurs. Such restraints are presumptively invalid and subject to strict scrutiny, so they are very difficult to uphold. They most commonly appear as injunctions preventing speech or publication in advance.
cards.hardContent: A prior restraint is a form of government action—usually a court injunction or similar order—that prohibits speech or publication before it occurs. Because prior restraints directly suppress speech in advance, they are presumptively invalid and must satisfy strict scrutiny: the government must show that the restraint is necessary to achieve a compelling interest and is narrowly tailored. As a result, prior restraints are rarely upheld.
cards.mnemonic: Prior restraint: PRE-speech STOP that faces Strict Scrutiny.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::prior restraint}} is a government order stopping speech {{c2::before it occurs}} and is {{c3::presumptively invalid}} and subject to {{c4::strict scrutiny}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Prior Restraints – Substantive and Procedural Requirements
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 042-2. Prior Restraints – Substantive and Procedural Requirements
cards.front: Prior Restraints – Substantive and Procedural Requirements
cards.backPlain: For a prior restraint to be valid, both substantive and procedural requirements must be satisfied. Substantive requirement – significant governmental interest: • The government must show at least a significant governmental interest justifying the restraint—a special societal harm. • National security may qualify as a sufficient interest, but the harm must be more than theoretical or speculative. Procedural safeguards: • The restraint must be narrow, reasonable, and definite. • The scheme must provide a prompt, final judicial determination for those whose speech is restrained.
cards.frontPrompt: What substantive government interest and procedural safeguards are required for a prior restraint on speech to be valid?
cards.cloze: A prior restraint can be valid only if both {{c1::substantive}} and {{c2::procedural}} requirements are met. Substantive requirement – government interest: • There must be at least a {{c3::significant governmental interest}} justifying the restraint—a {{c4::special societal harm}}. • {{c5::National security}} may be a sufficient interest, but the harm must be {{c6::more than theoretical}}. Procedural safeguards: • The restraint must be {{c7::narrow, reasonable, and definite}}. • The scheme must provide a {{c8::prompt, final judicial determination}} for those whose speech is restrained.
cards.easyContent: A valid prior restraint requires a significant government interest (like real national security harm) plus strong procedural safeguards: the order must be narrow, reasonable, and definite, and there must be prompt, final judicial review.
cards.mediumContent: Substantively, a prior restraint must be justified by a significant governmental interest, such as a special societal harm; national security can qualify only if the risk is concrete, not theoretical. Procedurally, the restraint must be narrow, reasonable, and definite, and there must be a prompt, final judicial determination for those whose speech is restrained.
cards.hardContent: To survive constitutional challenge, a prior restraint must satisfy demanding substantive and procedural requirements. Substantively, the government must demonstrate at least a significant interest—a special societal harm—sufficient to justify the restraint. National security can meet this standard only where the harm is concrete and imminent, not merely speculative. Procedurally, prior restraint mechanisms must strictly limit official discretion: the restraint must be narrow, reasonable, and definite, and there must be a prompt, final judicial determination of whether the restraint is permissible, ensuring that speech is not suppressed indefinitely while litigation drags on.
cards.mnemonic: BIG + FAST: Big interest, Fast final review.
cards.clozeLite: A valid prior restraint needs a {{c1::significant governmental interest}} and {{c2::narrow, reasonable, definite terms}} plus {{c3::prompt, final judicial determination}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 042-3. Prior Restraints – Fair-Trial Injunctions
cards.front: Prior Restraints – Fair-Trial Injunctions
cards.backPlain: Courts sometimes issue preliminary injunctions restricting pretrial publicity in order to preserve a fair trial. • A preliminary injunction that prevents pretrial discussion to preserve a fair trial is valid only if it is the only way to preserve a fair trial. • A party must comply with a valid injunction until it is vacated or overturned. • As a general rule, a party may not collaterally challenge an injunction it has already violated; instead, the party must first seek to have the injunction modified, vacated, or overturned.
cards.frontPrompt: When is a prior restraint in the form of a preliminary injunction to preserve a fair trial valid, and what are the rules about obeying and challenging such an injunction?
cards.cloze: A preliminary injunction restricting {{c1::pretrial discussion}} to preserve a fair trial is valid only if it is {{c2::the only way to preserve a fair trial}}. A party must comply with a {{c3::valid injunction}} until it is {{c4::vacated or overturned}}. As a general rule, a party cannot {{c5::collaterally challenge an injunction it has violated}}; the proper course is to seek to have the injunction modified, vacated, or overturned before disobeying it.
cards.easyContent: A gag order to preserve a fair trial is valid only if it is the only way to ensure fairness. Parties must obey valid injunctions until they are overturned and generally cannot collaterally attack an injunction they have already disobeyed.
cards.mediumContent: A prior restraint in the form of a gag order or preliminary injunction limiting pretrial publicity to preserve a fair trial is constitutional only if it is the only way to protect the defendant’s right to a fair trial. Parties must comply with valid injunctions until they are vacated or overturned and ordinarily cannot collaterally challenge an injunction that they have already violated.
cards.hardContent: When courts issue prior restraints to control pretrial publicity—such as gag orders on the parties or media—the order is valid only under extremely narrow conditions. Specifically, a preliminary injunction preventing pretrial discussion to preserve a fair trial is permissible only if it is the sole means of ensuring a fair trial; alternative measures (like voir dire, change of venue, or jury instructions) must be inadequate. Once a court issues a valid injunction, parties are obligated to obey it until it is vacated or overturned on direct review. They generally may not collaterally attack an injunction they have already disobeyed; violating the order and then claiming it was unconstitutional is typically not permitted.
cards.mnemonic: GAG: Gotta Abide till Gone—last resort for fair trial.
cards.clozeLite: A fair-trial {{c1::gag order / prior restraint}} is valid only if it is {{c2::the only way to protect a fair trial}}; parties must {{c3::obey valid injunctions until vacated}} and {{c4::generally cannot collaterally attack one they violated}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Prior Restraints – Licensing and Permit Schemes
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 042-4. Prior Restraints – Licensing and Permit Schemes
cards.front: Prior Restraints – Licensing and Permit Schemes
cards.backPlain: Licensing and permit schemes that regulate speech operate as prior restraints when they require government approval before speaking. • The government may require licenses or permits for speech only if it has a reasonable justification for doing so. • Requirements for permits or licenses must function like a procedural due process scheme: – clear, reasonable standards limiting official discretion; and – mechanisms for review of denied permits or licenses. • A person can challenge a denial of a permit or license on constitutional grounds, even if the person violated the permit or licensing requirement.
cards.frontPrompt: When are licensing or permit schemes for speech permissible as prior restraints, and what procedural protections and challenges must be available?
cards.cloze: Licensing and permit schemes for speech are {{c1::prior restraints}} because they require {{c2::government approval before speaking}}. The government may require licenses or permits for speech only if it has a {{c3::reasonable justification}} for doing so. Such schemes must operate like {{c4::procedural due process}} systems: • They must contain {{c5::clear, reasonable standards}} that limit official discretion; and • They must provide {{c6::review for denied permits or licenses}}. A person may {{c7::challenge a denial of a permit or license on constitutional grounds}}, even if the person has {{c8::violated the permit requirement}}.
cards.easyContent: Permit and licensing schemes that control who may speak are prior restraints. They are allowed only with a reasonable justification, clear standards, and review of denials, and people can attack a denial as unconstitutional even if they broke the permit rule.
cards.mediumContent: Licensing or permit requirements regulating speech are prior restraints because they condition speech on prior government approval. They are permissible only if reasonably justified and structured like procedural due process: they must include clear standards that limit official discretion and provide review of denials. Importantly, a person can challenge a permit denial on constitutional grounds even if they failed to comply with the permit requirement.
cards.hardContent: Permit and licensing systems that regulate expressive activity—such as parade permits or broadcasting licenses—constitute prior restraints because they require prior government permission to speak. They are constitutional only where the government has a reasonable justification (such as managing competing uses of public fora) and the scheme incorporates strong procedural protections: clear, objective standards that meaningfully constrain official discretion and mechanisms for timely review of denials. Moreover, an individual denied a permit may mount a constitutional challenge to the denial or to the scheme itself even if the individual technically violated the permit or licensing requirement; lack of compliance does not bar a First Amendment attack on an unconstitutional prior restraint system.
cards.mnemonic: LICENSE: Lawful If Neutral, Clear, Evenhanded, Standards, & Evaluation.
cards.clozeLite: Speech {{c1::licensing or permit schemes}} are {{c2::prior restraints}} and valid only with {{c3::reasonable justification}}, {{c4::clear standards limiting discretion}}, and {{c5::review of denials}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Defamation – Public Figure, Public Official, Public Concern
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 049-1. Defamation – Status and Public Concern Definitions
cards.front: Defamation – Who Is Public, and What Is Public Concern?
cards.backPlain: First Amendment defamation rules are triggered when the plaintiff is a public official or public figure, or when the speech involves a matter of public concern. 1. Public figure: - One who has pervasive fame or notoriety; OR - One who voluntarily assumes a central role in a particular public matter or controversy. 2. Public official: - A public office holder. 3. Matter of public concern: - A statement that relates to a community interest or concern, including national interests; typically, issues that affect the public at large rather than purely private disputes.
cards.frontPrompt: In First Amendment defamation law, how are a public figure, a public official, and a matter of public concern defined, and when do these categories matter?
cards.cloze: First Amendment defamation rules are triggered when the plaintiff is a {{c1::public official}} or {{c2::public figure}}, or when the speech involves a {{c3::matter of public concern}}. 1. {{c4::Public figure}}: - One who has {{c5::pervasive fame or notoriety}}; OR - One who {{c6::voluntarily assumes a central role}} in a particular {{c7::public matter or controversy}}. 2. {{c8::Public official}}: - A {{c9::public office holder}}. 3. {{c10::Matter of public concern}}: - A statement that relates to a {{c11::community interest or concern}}, including {{c12::national interests}}.
cards.easyContent: First Amendment defamation rules kick in when the plaintiff is a public official or public figure, or the speech is on a matter of public concern. A public figure is someone very famous or who steps into a public controversy; a public official holds public office; a matter of public concern involves community or national interests.
cards.mediumContent: First Amendment constraints on defamation apply when (1) the plaintiff is a public official or public figure, or (2) the statement involves a matter of public concern. A public figure is someone with pervasive fame or notoriety or someone who voluntarily assumes a central role in a particular public matter. A public official is a public office holder. A matter of public concern is speech relating to community or national interests, rather than purely private disputes.
cards.hardContent: Constitutional defamation rules depend on the status of the plaintiff and the subject of the speech. A public figure is either a person with pervasive fame or notoriety or someone who voluntarily thrusts themselves into a particular public controversy and assumes a central role in it. A public official is a public office holder, generally one with responsibility for governmental affairs. A matter of public concern is speech that relates to community or national interests and public issues, as opposed to purely private matters. These definitions determine whether heightened First Amendment protections—such as fault and falsity requirements—apply.
cards.mnemonic: OFFICIAL, FAMOUS, or PUBLIC-topic speech triggers First Amendment defamation rules.
cards.clozeLite: Defamation triggers {{c1::First Amendment}} limits when {{c2::public official}} or {{c3::public figure}} plaintiffs are involved, or speech is on a {{c4::matter of public concern}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
cards.topic: Defamation – Constitutional Falsity and Fault Standards
cards.rawHeader: Con Law 049-2. Defamation – Falsity and Fault
cards.front: Defamation – Falsity and Fault (Public vs. Private Plaintiffs)
cards.backPlain: When defamation involves a public official, a public figure, or a matter of public concern, the First Amendment imposes additional requirements. 1. Falsity: - The plaintiff must prove that the allegedly defamatory statement was false. 2. Fault standards: 2.1 Public officials or public figures: - The plaintiff must prove "actual malice": - Knowledge that the statement was false; OR - Reckless disregard as to its truth or falsity. 2.2 Private figures: - The plaintiff must prove at least negligence regarding the truth or falsity of the statement. - Higher fault (actual malice) may be required to obtain certain types of damages (handled separately in damages rules).
cards.frontPrompt: In defamation cases involving public officials, public figures, or matters of public concern, what must the plaintiff prove about falsity and fault, and how do standards differ for public vs. private plaintiffs?
cards.cloze: When defamation involves a {{c1::public official}}, a {{c2::public figure}}, or a {{c3::matter of public concern}}, the First Amendment adds requirements. 1. {{c4::Falsity}}: - The plaintiff must prove the statement was {{c5::false}}. 2. Fault standards: 2.1 {{c6::Public officials or public figures}}: - Must prove {{c7::actual malice}}: - {{c8::Knowledge}} that the statement was false; OR - {{c9::Reckless disregard}} as to its truth or falsity. 2.2 {{c10::Private figures}}: - Must prove at least {{c11::negligence}} regarding the truth or falsity of the statement.
cards.easyContent: In First Amendment defamation cases, the plaintiff must show the statement was false and that the defendant was at fault. Public officials and public figures must prove actual malice (knowledge of falsity or reckless disregard). Private figures must prove at least negligence about the truth of the statement.
cards.mediumContent: If defamation involves a public official, public figure, or matter of public concern, the plaintiff bears the burden of proving falsity and constitutional fault. Public officials and public figures must prove actual malice—either knowledge that the statement was false or reckless disregard for its truth or falsity. Private figures must prove at least negligence regarding the truth or falsity, with higher fault standards tied to certain types of damages.
cards.hardContent: In defamation cases implicating the First Amendment—those involving public officials, public figures, or matters of public concern—the plaintiff must prove not only the common-law elements but also falsity and constitutional fault. The burden is on the plaintiff to establish that the statement was false. For public officials and public figures, the Constitution requires proof of actual malice: that the defendant either knew the statement was false or acted with reckless disregard for its truth or falsity. For private figures, the minimum constitutional requirement is negligence concerning the truth or falsity of the statement, although some jurisdictions may require more in certain contexts. The precise fault level also interacts with which damages are available, addressed in the damages rules.
cards.mnemonic: Public = FAM (Falsity + Actual Malice); Private = F + Negligence.
cards.clozeLite: In defamation on a {{c1::public official, public figure, or public concern}}, P must prove {{c2::falsity}} and {{c3::constitutional fault}}: {{c4::actual malice for public}} and {{c5::at least negligence for private}}.

cards.subject: Con Law
